The Drama
Epilogue
Sources

The Spanish colonial period lasted from 1565, when Legaspi arrived in Cebu, to 1898, when Aguinaldo declared Philippine Independence in Kawit, Cavite. During this 333-year reign, the Spanish government introduced to the islands the Catholic religion and the Hispanic way of life mainly from Spain and Mexico, which was gradually appropriated by the indigenous culture to form the “lowland folk culture.” This is the culture now shared by the country’s major ethnolinguistic groups like the Ilocano, lbanag, Pangasinan, Pampango, Tagalog, Bikol, Ilonggo, Aklanon, Karay-A, Cebuano, Lineyte Samarnon, and Cuyunon.

Throughout the colonial period and even after it, theater was employed as a means of teaching and propagating the Catholic religion as well as for establishing and maintaining Spanish rule over the islands. Dramatic forms with Hispanic influence preaching Catholic and colonial messages were the komedya, the sinakulo, as well as different playlets associated with Christmas and Lent. After the opening of the archipelago to foreign trade starting in 1834 and the arrival of more and more European artists after the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869, a more secular culture entered the urbanized areas, introducing such forms as the Spanish zarzuela and drama. In the beginning, Filipino artists appeared with Spanish actors in Spanish works, but by the end of the 19th century, Filipino writers, composers, and producers began indigenizing them in both content and form, creating the sarsuwela and dramas in the native languages.

After the American colonization of the islands at the turn of the century, the sarsuwela and the drama captured the imagination of Filipino audiences from the 1900s to the 1920s, first in Manila and the Tagalog provinces, and later in the key cities and towns that spoke Ilocano, Pangasinan, Kapampangan, Bikol, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Waray. By the 1930s, however, these forms began to decline in popularity with the rise of the American-inspired bodabil and the foreign and local talking pictures.

In the post-World War II period, some of these Hispanic forms continued to be performed in some provinces through the sponsorship of hermanos mayores (principal sponsors) during town fiestas. With the resurgence of cultural nationalism in the late 1960s and 1970s, Hispanic plays, especially the sarsuwela, were revived or revitalized to make them more responsive to the conditions and needs of a developing nation.

 

The Komedya

Descended from the Spanish comedia (play) of the 16th century, the local komedya first appeared in Latin and Spanish in 1598 in Cebu. In 1609, the komedya on the martyrdom of Santa Barbara, the first in a native language, facilitated the conversion of the Boholanos to Christianity. Later, in 1637, a famous komedya depicted the defeat of Corralat (Kudarat) at the hands of Sebastian Hurtado de Corcuera. In the 18th century, the komedya depicting conflicts in distant medieval European kingdoms began to be staged. By the 19th century, the komedya had become an institution in Manila theaters and soon after became popular fiesta fare—in Pampanga by the 1830s, in the Ilocos by the 1850s, in Bicol by the 1860s, and in Iloilo and Cebu toward the end of the 19th century. In spite of the attacks on the komedya and the rise of the sarsuwela in the 1900s and bodabil in the 1920s, the komedya still attracted rural audiences even after World War II. Today, the mass media, especially film, has effectively eliminated many traditional drama forms, but the komedya survives in a few towns all over the islands.

The komedya is a play written in verse, usually in octosyllabic or dodecasyllabic quatrains, which uses the conventions of the marcha or march for exits and entrances, batalla (choreographed fighting), and magia (magical effects). At present, the komedya may be divided into two principal types. The first, which may be called komedya de santo, centers on the lives of patron saints, like the Comedia de San Miguel (Play of San Miguel) of Iligan City; the miracles wrought by these saints, like the Haybing of Taal, Batangas; or on certain episodes in the life of a saint or of Christ, like the Comedia de Misterio (Play of Mystery) of Paete, Laguna. The second and more secular type of komedya, also known as kumidya, moro-moro, linambay, coloquio, araquio, tibag, and minoros, may highlight the epic battles between Christian kingdoms in medieval Europe (e.g., Francia, España, Italia, Alemania, Albania) and the Moorish kingdoms of the Middle East (e.g., Turquia, Persia, Arabia), as seen in Doce Pares de Francia (Twelve Peers of France); or the lives and loves of noble Christian or Muslim characters, as seen, respectively, in Don Alejandre y Don Luis (Don Alejandro and Don Luis) and Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira).

The komedya de santo may derive its stories from the awit and korido (metrical romances) narrating the lives of saints, from the hagiographies popularized by books or sermons, or from the stories of miracles attributed to certain saints. The secular komedya, on the other hand, draws most of its stories, characters, and even lines from the awit and korido set in medieval kingdoms that were published as libritos (pamphlets) and sold together with prayer books outside Catholic churches on Sundays. In the decades after World War II, the komedya began to be influenced as well by the movies and popular magazines.

A well-known komedya de santo is the Comedia de San Miguel of Iligan City which is performed in honor of Iligan’s patron saint, San Miguel Arcangel, on his feast day on 29 Sep. In part 1, God asks Lusbel to guard the seven temples while he is away, entrusting him with the key but forbidding him from opening one temple. The arrogant Lusbel resents the prohibition and disobeys God’s order. God then summons San Miguel to put Lusbel in line, but Lusbel is unrepentant. Holding God’s banner and sword, San Miguel rallies his band of good angels and engages Lusbel and his group of rebels in a decisive battle. Lusbel and his cohorts are defeated and consigned to the fires of hell forever. In part 2, which is popularly known as “Yawa-Yawa,” literally “Devil-Devil,” individual demons wearing red costumes and masks and outdoing each other in fun and fantasy, introduce themselves and the evils they represent (including the seven capital sins), while Lusbel, who has been turned into a seven-headed monster, looks on. Part 3, which has not been performed for some time, dramatizes a morality tale contrasting the lives of a rich man who lives a life of indulgence and sin and ends up in hell, and a hermit who denies himself the pleasures of the world and ends up in heaven.

An example of the secular komedya is Biag ni Prinsipe Constantino (Life of Prince Constantine) by Lorenza Pre of Santa Catalina, Ilocos, Sur. Written ca. 1990, the komedya follows a traditional plot. A battle is fought between the Christians of Granada and the Moors of Amorabia. The Christians lose, the king dies, and in the confusion that follows, the king’s children, Princess Proserfina and Prince Constantino, are separated. Similarly, the son of the Moorish emperador (emperor) disappears. To counter the influence of the Moors, the Christians plot to put up a leader of their own, Miguel. The Moors and Christians continue to be at odds. Meanwhile, the Christian king who is getting older wants his daughter Florencia to find a suitable husband. A torneo (tournament) is called, and princes from far away come to try their luck, including Prince Constantino, Princess Proserfina in male disguise, and the missing Muslim prince. Prince Constantino wins the torneo and the hand of Florencia. After the reunion of Prince Constantino and Princess Proserfina, the two are married and the king passes on the crown of Granada to them. The Muslim emperador and his son are also reunited, and in their happiness are convinced to embrace the Christian faith.

Supported by the community, the komedya is usually presented for two or three days to celebrate the feasts of the barrio patron saints. On an elevated platform dominated by a set representing a two- or three-level European castle, the cast, composed mostly of barrio youths who participate in fulfillment of personal religious vows, declaims the verses and acts out the scenes of love, battle, and royal counsel, while clad in colorful costumes that reveal each character’s religion—dark colors for Christians, red for Moors—and position in the political hierarchy—crowns for kings and queens, three-pointed hats for princes. Trained for months by a direktor, who often doubles as the apuntador (prompter), these personahe (cast) do regal marchas (slow marches) and crisp paso dobles (double-step marches), and dance out their fights to the accompaniment of a brass band.

Through the centuries, many traditional komedya propounded the belief that all Christians, by virtue of their baptism, are superior to Moors; that Europeans are a race superior to all others because the Christians are European; that authority is hierarchical, with the king dominating and, in descending order, princes, generals, soldiers, and peasants; that authority must be followed at all costs; and that obedience, humility, and perseverance are the hallmarks of a good Christian subject.

But even as the komedya functioned primarily as a piece of dramatic propaganda for the Spanish colonizer, Filipino artists found a way of either neutralizing its colonial messages or by alluding to the less-than-ideal conditions of life under oppressive and racist rulers. To deemphasize or marginalize the anti-Muslim stories of the komedya species called the moro-moro, Francisco Baltazar (1788-1862) created a number of komedya, many with an all-Muslim cast of characters, where the focus was no longer on the conflict between Christians and Moors inevitably ending in the defeat and/or baptism of the latter, but on human relationships and the themes of love, betrayal, power, and honor. Moreover, as was the custom then, Baltazar used the character of the pusong (trickster), the very popular comedian who lightens the ponderous komedya with jokes, whether written or improvised, to allude to various injustices of the colonial regime, such as the abuses committed by the guardia civil (constable) against ordinary indio (Christianized native).

 

The Playlets

From the colonial regime to the present century, the teachings of the Spanish Catholic Church, specifically on the life and sufferings of Jesus Christ and the Catholic saints, and the superiority of Catholicism over all other faiths, have been taught to the Filipino Catholic laity, not only from the book and the pulpit but also from the stage and the street. Revolving around the important seasons of Christmas, Lent, or the feast days of barrio or town patron saints, religious playlets either embroider on the basic, traditional rituals prescribed by the Roman liturgy or create new dialogue and/or music to dramatize an episode in the life of Christ or a saint.

Of the Christmas plays, the most famous are the Tagalog panunuluyan (seeking entry) and pananawagan (calling out) and the Bikol kagharong (going from house to house), which reenact Mary and Joseph’s search for an inn on the first Christmas Eve. In Kawit, Cavite, where the panunuluyan is known as the maytinis, a young man and a young woman sing their plea to the owners of about five houses—to no avail. Then a procession of about 13 floats depicts characters from the Old Testament like Adam and Eve, Noah, Moses, David, Esther, and Judith; events from the New Testament, like the Annunciation and Visitation; and an allegory of Mother Philippines. Before midnight, the procession winds up in church. At the “Gloria” during the midnight mass, the birth of Jesus in a cave is heralded with the singing of little girls dressed as angels.

Another Christmas playlet is the pastores (shepherds). In Bicol towns, pastores refers to a group of young men and women in shepherd costumes who dance and sing Christmas carols in Bikol and Spanish in front of different houses. In Cebu and Leyte, the pastores is a short play depicting the journey of the shepherds to Bethlehem. In Tolosa, Leyte, the pastores features young shepherdesses with full skirts and wide-brimmed hats. Going from house to house, they sing Christmas songs in their native Waray and dance as they search for the Infant Jesus. On their way, the devil tries to block them. They debate with the devil in verse until he goes away. They then proceed on their journey until they find the newly born Messiah.

The rarest of the Christmas playlets is that of the tatlong hari (Three Kings), which is found only in Gasan, Marinduque. Here, the “kings” parade on horses following a star on a bamboo pole, then end up in front of a stage which depicts Herod’s palace. They ask Herod about the baby boy of Bethlehem, depart, and find the Infant Jesus, but fail to return. Herod is livid with anger and sends his soldiers to kill all babies below two years of age. The play ends with Herod going mad and, until a few years ago, destroying the set. In Floridablanca, Pampanga, the tatlong hari is not a play but a procession featuring three men dressed as Melchor, Gaspar, and Baltazar. In Mabitac, Laguna, the kings are played by three boys, who ride on horses from the church to the munisipyo (town hall). From the munisipyo’s balcony, they throw candies and money to the screaming crowds below.

In the past, on 28 Dec, a play on the niños inocentes (innocent children) used to be performed in Rizal Province to depict the beheading of the innocents by Herod’s soldiers. In Gasan, Marinduque, it was a parade of higante (giants) followed by men giving out animal-shaped rice cakes.

Lent features at least nine different playlets that enact different episodes in the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Found in most Catholic parishes all over the Philippines is the Palm Sunday osana (hosanna), which is based on the liturgy of Palm Sunday. In Santa Isabel, Malolos, Bulacan, the osana, also called humenta (donkey) because it features a karo (float) carrying the image of Christ riding on a donkey, begins with the blessing of the palms in a small visita (chapel) about a kilometer away from the church. From there to the church, the priest who plays Christ leads the faithful in a reenactment of the Savior’s triumphal entry into Jerusalem. Stepping over the tapis (overskirts) laid out by devout old women, the priest walks in front of the karo bearing the image of Christ. He stops in front of each of the four kubol (small balconies) placed in equal distances along the route of the procession. On each kubol, little girls in white dresses and carrying little baskets filled with flower petals sing different versions of the “Hosanna,” praising the Son of David who comes in the name of the Lord to the accompaniment of a brass band. As the procession winds up in the parish church, church bells peal, and the priest then celebrates the Palm Sunday mass.

In most parishes, the via crucis (way of the cross) is a solemn procession of the image of the Nazarene, usually held on the different Sundays of Lent or on Holy Week. The candlelit procession stops to pray at each of the 14 Stations of the Cross enshrined in various parts of the town. The town of Paete in Laguna boasts of a special via crucis called salubong (meeting) on Holy Wednesday for Catholics or Holy Thursday for Aglipayans, and this salubong features moving images manipulated from underneath with an elaborate system of strings and pulleys. Unlike most via crucis, Paete’s does not have altars, and stops to reenact only three scenes. On the first corner, the statue of the Nazareno (Christ carrying the cross), standing firm under the weight of the cross, is greeted by the Virgin Mary, whose hands reach out to her son. Later at another corner is the image of Veronica wiping Christ’s face with a towel. At the last stop, the Virgin meets Veronica, who shows her the three faces of Christ imprinted on her towel. Throughout the procession, a group of singers provides the dialogue between images in hair-raising, high-pitched chant.

In most Catholic and Aglipayan parishes today, the liturgical ritual of the paghuhugas (washing), which dramatizes the washing of the feet of the apostles by Christ in the Last Supper, is the highlight of Maundy Thursday. In the sanctuary and near the altar, the priest, representing Christ, pours water from a pitcher onto a basin to literally wash and kiss the right foot of each of the 12 parishioners dressed as apostles.

In some Tagalog and Bicol towns, another reenactment follows the paghuhugas—the huling hapunan or ultima cena (last supper), which commemorates Jesus’s last meal with his apostles. In Gasan, Marinduque, after the washing of the feet, the priest and the 12 apostles proceed from the church to the principal sponsor’s house, where they partake of a last supper comprised of popular native fare like sweet-and-sour lapu-lapu, pancit, chopsuey, and rice, as a huddle of women chants the episode on the Last Supper from the Tagalog pasyon. Later, all spectators partake of the dinner.

On Good Friday, the siete palabras (seven last words) dramatizes Christ’s agony on the cross from noon to three in the afternoon. In Santa Elena, Buhi, Camarines Sur, a wooden image of Christ hangs from the cross as laymen give homilies on the Seven Last Words. As each of the last words are spoken by the speaker at the beginning of his homily, two or three blasts of fire are launched into the air by fire blowers near the cross. After Christ dies at three o’clock, two men, dressed as Joseph and Nicodemus, take the image down from the cross and lay it out on a stretcher. In a heartrending chant, a woman playing the Virgin weeps and chants an eerie lamentation about Jesus’s hair and the wounds in his hands, feet, and side. After the lamentation, the people wipe the image’s hands and legs with their handkerchiefs.

In Pakil, Laguna, the highlight of Good Friday is the late afternoon or early evening procession of the santo entierro (holy burial). Preceded by the images of San Juan, Maria Cleofe, Maria Salome, Magdalena, and the Mater Dolorosa that are all dressed in black, the image of the dead Christ, which was earlier taken down from the cross from which it hung during the Siete Palabras, is carried on a stretcher by devotees. The procession winds its way around the streets of Pakil, preceded by sacristans sounding wooden clappers, which take the place of the regular bells for a more somber tone, and accompanied by a band playing a mournful punebre (funeral march). Then at each of several estaciones (stations) where an altar has been built and decorated with fronds and flowers, as the choir sings the “Patawad, O Diyos Ko” (Have Mercy, My Lord) to the accompaniment of a violin, the bearers of Christ’s image stop and place the whole stretcher on the altar, under which are containers with live coals burning kamanyang (incense) of dried lanzones and ginger peelings. As prayers are said, the image is smoked like a regular corpse for a few minutes to symbolize the cleansing of all impurities. Then the tambuli (carabao horn) is sounded, and a crier in an eerie voice calls out, “Misericordia, Señor” (Have mercy, Lord). After this, the bearers take the stretcher on their shoulders once again, and the procession moves to the next estacion where the same rituals are repeated. With the intermittent cries of “Misericordia, Señor,” the doleful sounds of the band, and the slowly moving mass of candle-bearing devotees, the procession ends up in church in the early evening.

On the evening of Good Friday or Black Saturday, a procession called soledad (solitude) dramatizes the loneliness of Mary from the death of her son. In Baao, Camarines Sur, the image of a Virgin in black is brought around the poblacion (town proper), accompanied by the karo of San Pedro, San Juan, and Maria Magdalena, among others, and preceded by a group of young musicians called the estudiantina. The procession stops in front of several houses where singers comfort the Virgin with songs in Latin like the “Ave Maria.” On the eve of Easter Sunday, plays depicting the Resurrection of Jesus Christ are performed in some towns. The Resurrection play of Lubao, Pampanga, written in the 1920s, uses special effects. So does the new pagkabuhay in Angono, Rizal, where the events leading to the Resurrection are enacted by the townspeople on a stage in the church plaza on Black Saturday.

Popular in many Catholic and Aglipayan parishes all over the country, the salubong (meeting), which is also known as padafung, encuentro, sugat, sabet, and alleluya, reenacts the meeting of the Virgin and the Risen Christ in the early morning of Easter Sunday. One of the grandest salubong is found in Angono, Rizal. This opens with a spirited dance of the tinyenta (female lieutenant), who waves a short flag. After this, the kapitana (female captain) declaims a long poem speaking of the fulfillment of Christ’s promise. Then birds of bamboo and paper swoop down from the corners of the four-poster structure called galilee, which has a heart hanging at the center that conceals the little angel of the salubong. The angel is then lowered toward the image of the Virgin below. As the angel sing the Latin Antiphon “Regina Coeli, Laetare” (Queen of Heaven, Rejoice), together with the other angels on the ground, she slowly takes off the Virgin’s black veil to signify that the latter’s Son had indeed risen from the dead. The salubong is capped with the kapitana’s dance of exaltation featuring a flag emblazoned with the word “Mabuhay” (Long Live).

In Marinduque, the main feature of the Easter celebration is still the moryonan or moriones (literally, helmets). Wearing folk interpretations of Roman soldiers’s costumes, male penitents dramatize the story of the soldier Longhino who pierced the side of Christ but who was later convinced of Christ’s divinity when he witnessed the Resurrection. Pilate and the Pharisees try to pay him off to keep quiet about what he saw. He refuses and instead runs around the town telling everyone about the risen Christ. Pilate sends his soldiers after Longhino, who is then captured and finally beheaded—that is, his helmet is impaled on a wooden sword and held up for all to see.

With the triumph of good, evil must be punished. Hudas, the ritual burning of Judas Iscariot, is still performed in some Bulacan and Pampanga towns on Easter Sunday. In Santa Rita, Pampanga, the bamboo-and-paper effigy of the traitor Judas Iscariot stands on a bamboo pole in the church patio in the middle of four bamboo posts located near the four corners of the large patio. After the Easter morning mass, churchgoers gather to witness the punishment of the traitor. Christian tradition teaches that Judas’s body hanging from a tree was eaten up by black birds. Thus the firecrackers—coming from each of the bamboo poles in each of the corners—are masked with cardboard figures of black birds. Each of these birds, once “lighted,” rides on a cable connecting the post to Judas’s hands and feet. This way, the birds are made to swoop down to “devour” the limbs of his body. In the end, the torso and, finally, the head are blown up, as the audience of elders and youths scream with delight.

Playlets are likewise performed to celebrate the feasts of patron saints. In some towns in Dumaguete, Negros Oriental, the playlet in Cebuano called San Jose used to feature a man, a woman, and a child dressed as San Jose, the Virgen, and the Santo Niño, respectively, walking around town and finally presiding over the feast prepared by a sponsor. Sometime in May in Camarines Norte, the dotoc shows a group of pilgrims joining up with another group going to Persia to pay homage to the Holy Cross, while the lagaylay features dances by Queen Elena and her son Constantino, accompanied by flag bearers and guards of honor, as they sing antiphonal verses in search and praise of the Holy Cross. On the feast of San Martin de Tours in October and that of the Virgin of Caysasay in December, several young people of Taal perform the lua (praise), a long poem that expresses the gratitude of the people of Taal to their patron saints for favors received as well as their prayer for the continued protection of their town from all calamities, natural and man-made. These poems are declaimed by the luwante on a stage before the image of the patron saint when the procession stops in front of the luwante’s house.

In the 19th century, the most important playlet staged to honor a patron saint was the moros y cristianos, performed by rural folk on the street. Invariably, this dance drama focused on the clash between the Christians and the Moors or non-Christians. On the feast of Santiago on 25 Jul, the Cebuano kinabayo (literally, using horses) of Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte, reenacts the Battle of Covadonga, which supposedly happened in 718 AD, where Santiago came down from the sky on his white horse to help the Christians under Pelayo defeat the Moors under Alkamah. In Ivana, Batanes, on the feast of San Jose on 1 May, three groups of males—young, middle-aged, old—perform the palo-palo (fighting with sticks), which depicts a battle between the Christians and the Moors. In Cabagan, Isabela, the feast of Santo Domingo is celebrated on 8 Aug with the sambali, a choreographed street fight between the Christian Ibanag and the non-Christian Kalinga. In Ibajay, Aklan, the sayaw (dance), which is an offering to the patron Santo Niño every third Sunday of January, features Moorish ambassadors being sent to the Christian Bisaya (Visayan) and a grand battle between the two armies that ends in the defeat of the Moors. The same playlet is called sinulog in Calbiga, Western Samar, curaldal or batalla in some towns of Pampanga, and maglalatik or magbabao in Biñan, Laguna.

A variation of the moros y cristianos is the bakahan (battle) of San Antonio, Laguna, a unique play performed from two to three in the afternoon of Good Friday. The bakahan dramatizes the fight between San Miguel Arcangel, here played by a boy of about 10, and the hudyo (Jews) played by older boys in bizarre masks and costumes. Unique to San Antonio, this story highlights the struggle between good and evil in the hour before Christ’s death.

Many of these playlets flourish to our day because of the support of individuals, civic organizations, and even local government who continue to believe in the teachings of the Catholic religion, in spite of the inroads of mass media and the “modern scientific culture.” As in the past, participation in or sponsorship of these events is a panata (vow), believed to be efficacious in conciliating and persuading Christian deities to grant personal wishes. Moreover, the playlets perform an important social function. Since they involve all classes and sectors of the barrio or town, they effectively reaffirm the values and beliefs shared by the community, thereby strengthening the individual’s commitment to society.

 

The Sinakulo

The sinakulo (literally, cenacle) or passion play probably began as a dramatization of the events depicted in the first pasyon, the Mahal na Passion (The Holy Passion), 1703, by Gaspar Aquino de Belen. By the end of the 19th century and beginning of the 20th, the sinakulo became a formal play with sets and costumes, performed by traveling commercial troupes like the Cenaculistang Pasay in the teatro (theater), on the open-air entablado (stage), and in the sabungan (cockpit) in the barrios of Bulacan and Rizal. Soon Pampanga and Bicol began to organize their own community sinakulo, which usually took the whole of the Semana Santa (Holy Week) to perform.

As it exists today, the sinakulo is a play written in verse (octosyllabic quintillas) or in prose, dramatizing the history of salvation—from the creation of the world and the first human beings to the assumption and coronation of the Virgin Mary in heaven, but paying special attention to the life, sufferings, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Other names for the passion play are tanggal (deposition) in Bicol, taltal (nailing) in Negros, and pasion y muerte (passion and death) in many towns. A shorter form of the sinakulo focusing on the events from the Agony in the Garden to the Crucifixion is usually presented on Good Friday morning and afternoon. These shorter versions are the pagdakip in Malolos, Bulacan, or the penitensiya in Cainta, Rizal. In Cutud, San Fernando, Pampanga, the sinakulo ends up with the actual nailing on the cross of the penitent playing Christ. Over the years the number of penitents being nailed to the cross has increased that Cutud has become a favorite tourist destination every Good Friday.

The sinakulo orihinal uses the popular Pasyong Genesis as its basic text, following the pasyon’s chronology of events and lifts stanzas of dialogue from its episodes. To these are added stories and stanzas taken from the religious awit and korido from other pasyon like the Pasyong Candaba and Pasyon Truncalis, from popular magazines like Liwayway, from religious novels like Martir sa Golgota (Martyr of Golgotha), from other sinakulo scripts, and lately, from “Lenten” movies like the Ten Commandments, The Robe, Quo Vadis, Jesus of Nazareth, and Passion of the Christ. A full sinakulo script would include the following scenes: the seven days of creation, the temptation of Adam and Eve in paradise, the tragedy of Cain and Abel, the flood and Noah’s ark, the birth, education and wedding of the Virgin, the Annunciation, the Visitation, Christ’s nativity, his debate with the doctors in the temple, his recollection in the desert, the miracles in Jesus’s public ministry, the events starting from his entry to Jerusalem on Palm Sunday to his resurrection on Easter Sunday, the Ascension, the descent of the Holy Spirit, and the assumption and coronation of the Virgin in heaven. Apocryphal stories relating to Herod the Great, Magdalena, Boanerhes, Dimas, Barabas, and Samuel Belibet may also be included.

Presented at the public plaza during Lent and especially on Holy Week, the sinakulo uses a proscenium-type stage in the open air. Different types of telon (backdrop) situate the action of the scenes, while props, often with no sense of history, are used as required by the scenes. The whole production usually has a main director, who is assisted by the directors for music, sets, and lights. The sinakulo’s personahe or characters, who perform in fulfillment of religious vows, may use the traditional chant and marches or declaim prose dialogue to canned music. Traditionally, costumes follow those worn by the images of Christ and the saints on Holy Week processions, but nowadays they are imitations of those seen in movies about Christ and the Roman times.

Even when they use modern staging techniques, most contemporary sinakulo continue to propagate values of passivity and blind obedience by highlighting Christ as the model of subservience, a God who is meek as a lamb, and a savior who accepts all the torture inflicted on him with total humility. Such values went a long way in convincing indios to meekly accept all economic and political impositions of the Spanish colonizer for centuries. Today, such passivity and obedience continue to shape contemporary minds, making them noncritical, acquiescent, and predisposed to follow authoritarian rule.

 

The Sarsuwela

The Spanish zarzuela was introduced in Manila in 1878 or 1879, through the performance of Jugar con Fuego (Playing with Fire) by the troupe of Dario Cespedes. In the following years, more groups arrived, notably that of Alejandro Cubero, which presented the zarzuela not only in Manila but in Iloilo, Cebu, Pampanga, and Bicol. Inspired by this new “enlightened” form, Filipinos soon created their own original zarzuela—the sarsuwela —in Tagalog, Pampango, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Waray. The sarsuwela thrived from 1900 to 1940 because of mass support and elite sponsorship, and because of its portrayal of familiar characters, conditions, and concerns.

With the rise of bodabil and the movies in the pre-World War II era, the sarsuwela slowly migrated from stage to screen until it was replaced by the Hollywood-type musical. Today, the traditional sarsuwela is still staged in the Ilocos and a few other towns, while its revitalized form is sometimes done in Manila and in Silay City.

The sarsuwela is a play that is comprised of one to five acts, with songs and dances, and is generally in prose, less often in verse. It portrays typical Filipino situations within the framework of a love story and incorporates contemporary issues. Sarsuwela may depict lofty themes such as love of country during a time of revolution, as in Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1902; satirize the foibles of Filipinos who suffer from colonial mentality, as in Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920; narrate an entertaining love story of children and parents separated at birth, as in Anak ng Dagat (Child of the Sea), 1921; or comment on social climbing and marriages of convenience as in Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919.

An important sarsuwela is Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921. The beautiful Nati, daughter of the landlord Don Juan, has just graduated as a pharmacist. The widower Don Juan and his fiancé, Doña Irene, both notorious usurers, plan to marry her off to a person with influence and money, but Nati loves Mario, the son of the peasants Andong and Maria, who are indebted to Don Juan. Meanwhile, at Nati’s party, Mario introduces Marcelo, who has been sent by the government to establish rural credit for farmers to save them from usurious practices. Later, when Andong and Maria try to pay off their debt to Don Juan, they are shocked to find out that it has more than quintupled in two years’ time. Because Andong cannot pay the huge amount, Don Juan sends the police to confiscate his properties. Andong appeals to the courts, but the judge, who is Don Juan’s friend, sides with the latter. In desperation, the farmers harvest the rice from Don Juan’s fields for themselves. Don Juan blames Mario for this, despite Nati’s explanation that it is Mario who protects Don Juan’s interests. Angry, Don Juan goes to confront the peasants who chase him all the way to his house. Mario intervenes and protects him. Marcelo explains that the court has reversed its decision and will ask Andong to pay back only the original amount that he had borrowed. Don Juan accepts the court’s decision, reconciles with Andong and Maria, and accepts Mario as his daughter’s fiancé.

Since the early decades of the 20th century, the sarsuwela has been presented by commercial troupes like the compañias of Hermogenes Ilagan and Severino Reyes in the early 1900s, in the teatros of big cities like Manila, Iloilo, and Cebu or on open-air entablado in rural areas during town fiestas where they are sponsored by hermanos mayores, usually in fulfilment of a panata to the patron saint of the town in whose honor it is being performed. Painted telones provide the setting for scenes (e.g., facade of a rich man or poor man’s house, interior of a rich man or poor man’s house, a rural landscape), and are complemented with appropriate props (e.g., sala sets for the houses of the rich, benches for poor abodes). Acting and costumes identify the bida (protagonist) and the kontrabida (antagonist). A small or big orchestra accompanies the songs, which usually include kundiman, balitaw, balse, danza, fox-trot, and later, cha-cha, rock and roll, and twist or whatever is popular at a given period. An overall director (or principal director) rehearses the actors, often acts as impresario as well, and coordinates the work of the maestro (music director and band master), who subcontracts musicians, rehearses and conducts them on stage, and rehearses the singing of the actors; the telonero (telon person), who works the telones and sets up the props; the electricista (electrician), who takes care of the lights and special effects; the apuntador or diktador (prompter), who feeds the lines to the actors from a concha (shell) in front of the entablado; and all the other cast and crew connected with the production.

When it first bloomed in the 1900s, the sarsuwela was rightly regarded as an “enlightened” form of theater because it introduced a more realistic way of depicting reality, reorienting the Filipino’s eyes from the fantasy of European kingdoms of the komedya to the social evils confronting him in his time, like oppressive landlords, corrupt politicians, gambling, usury, and colonial mentality. However, although it presented characters, situations, and problems drawn from real life, it painted these characters as types according to the bida and kontrabida mode, and contented itself with describing a range of social and political problems but then solving them in a conciliatory fashion, reducing class contradictions and structural injustice into personal problems. In this sense and in spite of its social conscience, the sarsuwela propagated a worldview and a value system that in the final analysis strengthened the status quo at the expense of the ordinary people who comprised the bulk of its audiences.

 

The Drama

The drama was brought into the country by Spanish troupes, many of whom came after the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869. Although these groups presented principally Spanish melodramas in the theaters of Manila, they also did prose plays without music called “drama” (to be distinguished from “drama” meaning “play” in general in English), which were written by Manila artists. Among the first drama written in Spanish by Filipino-born Spaniards and Spanish mestizos were Cuadros Filipinos (Philippine Scenes), 1882, and Jose el Carpintero (Joseph the Carpenter), 1880. Two of the early dramas written in the native languages were Ang Babai nga Huwaran (The Model Woman), 1878, and R.I.P., 1901.

The drama is a play in prose that revolves around Filipino characters and situations, emphasizing current issues. Sometimes, the drama may feature a song or two to create mood and provide relief from long stretches of dialogue. Dramas were often performed together with the sarsuwela. Sometimes, three of these dramas were combined for an evening’s performance. During the Japanese occupation, the drama was incorporated into the bodabil (local vaudeville) as its main feature, creating a new form called the stage show. As the movies drew audiences away from the theaters, the romantic melodramas and the comic dramas, like the sarsuwela, transferred to the screen and were known as “drama” and “komedi.” Today, the same drama and komedi are heard over the radio or are seen on television.

The drama has three general types: the drama simboliko, which allegorizes stock characters from the romantic drama to comment on a political/social situation, like Tanikalang Guinto (Golden Chain), 1902; the drama romantiko which focuses on a love or family story that may end happily or tragically, like Esperanza, 1916; and the drama comico or comedy, which may use any kind of plot or character in order to create situations, whether satirical, farcical, or slapstick, that will make people laugh, like Mga Santong Tao (People Saints), 1901.

In 1902, Juan Abad and his group of relatives and friends staged Tanikalang Guinto at the Teatro Libertad in Manila. It later caused the author’s incarceration because it exposed America as the new colonizer. In this drama, Liwanag (meaning “light,” representing a free Philippines) is being courted by Kaulayaw (meaning “sweetheart,” representing Filipinos fighting for freedom). But Liwanag’s uncle, Maimbot (“greedy,” representing the United States), puts obstacles to their marriage (freedom of the Philippines). Maimbot gifts Liwanag with a golden bracelet to take her mind away from Kaulayaw, but she is loyal to Kaulayaw. Angry, Maimbot ties her to a tree with the golden bracelet, which now becomes a golden chain, and pays Nagtapon ( “a wastrel,” representing Filipinos who had collaborated with the Americans) to guard Liwanag and keep Kaulayaw, Nagtapon’s brother, away from her. When Kaulayaw tries to save Liwanag, Nagtapon kills him. Liwanag despairs and wants to kill herself but Diwa (representing the spirit of struggle) enters and tells her that Kaulayaw will be brought back to life. In the final tableau, Nagtapon is taken away by the devil and Maimbot by Death. As Liwanag and Diwa are carried to the skies in a bubble, Kaulayaw is crowned by Bat (God).

Like the sarsuwela, the drama draws its themes, characters, and stories from current issues, whether these be political, religious, or social. A typical romantic drama is Manotok by Makahiya [pseud]. Mariano, a poor fisherman, catches his wife Lucia with her lover Don Alvaro, the landlord. Alvaro escapes, and Mariano, in anger, strangles his wife to death. The police arrest Mariano who is then sentenced to a prison term of 15 years. As Mariano serves his term, Pining, Mariano’s daughter, is raised by a kind farmer, Mang Kiko. Pretty and kind Pining, who runs a little bibingka (rice cake) stall, is courted by Arturo, a handsome lieutenant. Mang Kiko approves of Pining’s suitor and everything goes well until Don Alvaro, back from months of traveling abroad, asks to see his tenant Mang Kiko. Alvaro is attracted to Pining and tries to take her by force. She resists and slaps him. When he persists, Manotok, the idiot whom Pining had been kind to, hits Alvaro with a piece of wood. In retaliation, Alvaro dismisses Mang Kiko as his tenant. To make matters worse, Mang Kiko goes blind. In the midst of this double tragedy, Arturo proposes marriage to Pining, and the latter accepts.

Meanwhile, Alvaro has a heated discussion with Mary, a bailarina (nightclub dancer) whom he lives with, who demands that Alvaro make good his promise of marriage to her. Alvaro insults Mary and drives her out of the house. As Mary leaves the house, the idiot Manotok enters Alvaro’s house, picks up a letter Mary drops, and goes away with another letter he takes from Alvaro’s desk. Meanwhile, Alvaro follows Mary to Mang Kiko’s house, kills her, and frames Mang Kiko so he would be blamed for the crime. Arturo has the painful duty of arresting his future father-in-law, who gives himself up peacefully. At the trial presided over by a young idealistic judge (Alvaro’s son), Manotok reveals himself to be Mariano coming to claim justice for himself. Using the letters he got from Alvaro’s house, Mariano proves that Alvaro had an affair with his wife and that it was Alvaro who killed Mary. Mang Kiko is exonerated, and Pining and her father are reunited.

Like the sarsuwela, the drama was presented commercially on the open-air entablado in the provinces during fiestas. Using telones and appropriate props, the drama was performed by professional or by community actors sometimes called dramista, who were taught the techniques of acting for melodrama or for comedy. A director-impresario took charge of fees and arrangements, and hired and supervised actors, composer-conductors, set and property masters, electricians, and other crew members.

Most dramas, like the typical sarsuwela of the pre-World War II period, depicted familiar characters, issues, and situations. However, like the sarsuwela, the drama usually reduced real economic and political contradictions to personal conflicts that could therefore be more easily resolved by the reconciliation of opponents, the contrition and forgiveness of the offenders, the conviction of the culprit or, as in most cases, the change of heart of the gambler, the prostitute, the usurer, or the corrupt politician. A major exception to these types of dramas was the allegorical dramas of 1902 to 1905. These dramas, in spite of the anti-sedition law enforced by the Americans and the threat of incarceration, successfully exposed the political contradiction between Filipino nationalists who fought for the independence earlier won from Spain and the American colonizers who pretended to help the Philippine Revolution against Spain but were now taking that independence away from the Filipinos because of their own colonial intentions. Here for the first time is drama that does not reaffirm but seeks to overthrow a new colonial status quo established through political deceit and superior arms.

 

Epilogue

Most komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and drama continue to propagate ideas that lead to divisiveness (e.g., Muslims are bad, Christians are good), passivity (e.g., to be Christlike submissiveness is always good), authoritarianism (e.g., “Utos ng hari, hindi mababali,” meaning “The king’s word cannot be broken”), and blind acceptance of the status quo (e.g., it is not social structures that are oppressive but abusive individuals). Clearly, values such as these can hardly be called progressive, especially in a new nation such as the Philippines which is trying to create a critical citizenry as well as unity among its varied sectors. Given the continuing popularity of these forms among provincial audiences, however, contemporary playwrights have seen fit to inject into these plays themes and conflicts that are more consonant with current concerns. In 1962, Max Allanigue rejected the divisive messages of the traditional komedya in his Prinsipe Rodante (Prince Rodante), which argues that one is bad not because of one’s religion but because one does not respect justice. In 1983, Rene O. Villanueva reshaped the komedya in his Sandaang Panaginip (A Hundred Dreams), which satirizes a kingdom (the Philippines) made bankrupt by the extravagance of its queen (Imelda Marcos). In 1992, the Cultural Center of the Philippines produced Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura) in komedya form for the grade school students of Dongalo, Parañaque, to encourage the youth to revitalize the komedya with messages that are no longer anti-Muslim but anti-authoritarianism.

The Christ story has likewise been reinterpreted according to current conditions. As early as 1907, Aurelio V. Tolentino’s Bagong Kristo (New Christ) portrayed Christ as a labor leader, who organizes the workers in the city and the countryside to demand decent wages from landlords and factory owners. From 1988 to 1992, Al Santos’s Kalbaryo ng Maralitang Tagalungsod (Calvary of the Urban Poor) focused on the plight of the Manila urban poor, whose calvary is a garbage dump called Smokey Mountain and whose crosses are the various anti-poor ordinances issued by the local government.

Of all the traditional forms, it is the sarsuwela that has had the most number of innovations. In 1977, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Bundok (The Mountain) showed the Cordillera groups linking arms to fight foreigners mining their lands. In 1976, Domingo Landicho’s Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow) satirized the colonial mentality of Filipino balikbayan. In 1980, Isagani R.Cruz’s Ms. Philippines exposed the dreams and frustrations of beauty-contest participants. In 1982, Nicanor Tiongson’s Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907) underscored the conflict between pro-American and pro-Filipino forces in the political, cultural, and economic levels. In 1998, four new sarsuwela were declared winners in the sarsuwela competition sponsored by the National Centennial Commission. Top prize was won by Palasyo ni Valentin (Valentin’s Palace) by Mario O’Hara, which depicted a gothic love triangle between a Spanish theater impresario, an aspiring native sarsuwela star, and the latter’s indio suitor. The second prize was shared by Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom) by George de Jesus III, a love story set during the Philippine revolution of 1896; Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others) by Bienvenido Lumbera, a story about American abuse of women during the Philippine-American War; and Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (Nation: Just One Foot Left) by Melba Padilla Maggay, about the EDSA Revolt and its relation to the 1896 Revolution.

These attempts at revitalization prove that the creative use of traditional dramas for aesthetic expression on contemporary realities is not only possible but necessary, acquiring new meaning for contemporary audiences. If these attempts succeed, these plays will not only help form a new citizenry and nation but also prove themselves significant enough to be considered pillars of a Filipino national theater.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

article.value: The Spanish colonial period lasted from 1565, when Legaspi arrived in Cebu, to 1898, when Aguinaldo declared Philippine Independence in Kawit, Cavite. During this 333-year reign, the Spanish government introduced to the islands the Catholic religion and the Hispanic way of life mainly from Spain and Mexico, which was gradually appropriated by the indigenous culture to form the “lowland folk culture.” This is the culture now shared by the country’s major ethnolinguistic groups like the Ilocano, lbanag, Pangasinan, Pampango, Tagalog, Bikol, Ilonggo, Aklanon, Karay-A, Cebuano, Lineyte Samarnon, and Cuyunon.

Throughout the colonial period and even after it, theater was employed as a means of teaching and propagating the Catholic religion as well as for establishing and maintaining Spanish rule over the islands. Dramatic forms with Hispanic influence preaching Catholic and colonial messages were the komedya, the sinakulo, as well as different playlets associated with Christmas and Lent. After the opening of the archipelago to foreign trade starting in 1834 and the arrival of more and more European artists after the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869, a more secular culture entered the urbanized areas, introducing such forms as the Spanish zarzuela and drama. In the beginning, Filipino artists appeared with Spanish actors in Spanish works, but by the end of the 19th century, Filipino writers, composers, and producers began indigenizing them in both content and form, creating the sarsuwela and dramas in the native languages.

After the American colonization of the islands at the turn of the century, the sarsuwela and the drama captured the imagination of Filipino audiences from the 1900s to the 1920s, first in Manila and the Tagalog provinces, and later in the key cities and towns that spoke Ilocano, Pangasinan, Kapampangan, Bikol, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Waray. By the 1930s, however, these forms began to decline in popularity with the rise of the American-inspired bodabil and the foreign and local talking pictures.

In the post-World War II period, some of these Hispanic forms continued to be performed in some provinces through the sponsorship of hermanos mayores (principal sponsors) during town fiestas. With the resurgence of cultural nationalism in the late 1960s and 1970s, Hispanic plays, especially the sarsuwela, were revived or revitalized to make them more responsive to the conditions and needs of a developing nation.
The Komedya

Descended from the Spanish comedia (play) of the 16th century, the local komedya first appeared in Latin and Spanish in 1598 in Cebu. In 1609, the komedya on the martyrdom of Santa Barbara, the first in a native language, facilitated the conversion of the Boholanos to Christianity. Later, in 1637, a famous komedya depicted the defeat of Corralat (Kudarat) at the hands of Sebastian Hurtado de Corcuera. In the 18th century, the komedya depicting conflicts in distant medieval European kingdoms began to be staged. By the 19th century, the komedya had become an institution in Manila theaters and soon after became popular fiesta fare—in Pampanga by the 1830s, in the Ilocos by the 1850s, in Bicol by the 1860s, and in Iloilo and Cebu toward the end of the 19th century. In spite of the attacks on the komedya and the rise of the sarsuwela in the 1900s and bodabil in the 1920s, the komedya still attracted rural audiences even after World War II. Today, the mass media, especially film, has effectively eliminated many traditional drama forms, but the komedya survives in a few towns all over the islands.

The komedya is a play written in verse, usually in octosyllabic or dodecasyllabic quatrains, which uses the conventions of the marcha or march for exits and entrances, batalla (choreographed fighting), and magia (magical effects). At present, the komedya may be divided into two principal types. The first, which may be called komedya de santo, centers on the lives of patron saints, like the Comedia de San Miguel (Play of San Miguel) of Iligan City; the miracles wrought by these saints, like the Haybing of Taal, Batangas; or on certain episodes in the life of a saint or of Christ, like the Comedia de Misterio (Play of Mystery) of Paete, Laguna. The second and more secular type of komedya, also known as kumidya, moro-moro, linambay, coloquio, araquio, tibag, and minoros, may highlight the epic battles between Christian kingdoms in medieval Europe (e.g., Francia, España, Italia, Alemania, Albania) and the Moorish kingdoms of the Middle East (e.g., Turquia, Persia, Arabia), as seen in Doce Pares de Francia (Twelve Peers of France); or the lives and loves of noble Christian or Muslim characters, as seen, respectively, in Don Alejandre y Don Luis (Don Alejandro and Don Luis) and Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira).

The komedya de santo may derive its stories from the awit and korido (metrical romances) narrating the lives of saints, from the hagiographies popularized by books or sermons, or from the stories of miracles attributed to certain saints. The secular komedya, on the other hand, draws most of its stories, characters, and even lines from the awit and korido set in medieval kingdoms that were published as libritos (pamphlets) and sold together with prayer books outside Catholic churches on Sundays. In the decades after World War II, the komedya began to be influenced as well by the movies and popular magazines.

A well-known komedya de santo is the Comedia de San Miguel of Iligan City which is performed in honor of Iligan’s patron saint, San Miguel Arcangel, on his feast day on 29 Sep. In part 1, God asks Lusbel to guard the seven temples while he is away, entrusting him with the key but forbidding him from opening one temple. The arrogant Lusbel resents the prohibition and disobeys God’s order. God then summons San Miguel to put Lusbel in line, but Lusbel is unrepentant. Holding God’s banner and sword, San Miguel rallies his band of good angels and engages Lusbel and his group of rebels in a decisive battle. Lusbel and his cohorts are defeated and consigned to the fires of hell forever. In part 2, which is popularly known as “Yawa-Yawa,” literally “Devil-Devil,” individual demons wearing red costumes and masks and outdoing each other in fun and fantasy, introduce themselves and the evils they represent (including the seven capital sins), while Lusbel, who has been turned into a seven-headed monster, looks on. Part 3, which has not been performed for some time, dramatizes a morality tale contrasting the lives of a rich man who lives a life of indulgence and sin and ends up in hell, and a hermit who denies himself the pleasures of the world and ends up in heaven.

An example of the secular komedya is Biag ni Prinsipe Constantino (Life of Prince Constantine) by Lorenza Pre of Santa Catalina, Ilocos, Sur. Written ca. 1990, the komedya follows a traditional plot. A battle is fought between the Christians of Granada and the Moors of Amorabia. The Christians lose, the king dies, and in the confusion that follows, the king’s children, Princess Proserfina and Prince Constantino, are separated. Similarly, the son of the Moorish emperador (emperor) disappears. To counter the influence of the Moors, the Christians plot to put up a leader of their own, Miguel. The Moors and Christians continue to be at odds. Meanwhile, the Christian king who is getting older wants his daughter Florencia to find a suitable husband. A torneo (tournament) is called, and princes from far away come to try their luck, including Prince Constantino, Princess Proserfina in male disguise, and the missing Muslim prince. Prince Constantino wins the torneo and the hand of Florencia. After the reunion of Prince Constantino and Princess Proserfina, the two are married and the king passes on the crown of Granada to them. The Muslim emperador and his son are also reunited, and in their happiness are convinced to embrace the Christian faith.

Supported by the community, the komedya is usually presented for two or three days to celebrate the feasts of the barrio patron saints. On an elevated platform dominated by a set representing a two- or three-level European castle, the cast, composed mostly of barrio youths who participate in fulfillment of personal religious vows, declaims the verses and acts out the scenes of love, battle, and royal counsel, while clad in colorful costumes that reveal each character’s religion—dark colors for Christians, red for Moors—and position in the political hierarchy—crowns for kings and queens, three-pointed hats for princes. Trained for months by a direktor, who often doubles as the apuntador (prompter), these personahe (cast) do regal marchas (slow marches) and crisp paso dobles (double-step marches), and dance out their fights to the accompaniment of a brass band.

Through the centuries, many traditional komedya propounded the belief that all Christians, by virtue of their baptism, are superior to Moors; that Europeans are a race superior to all others because the Christians are European; that authority is hierarchical, with the king dominating and, in descending order, princes, generals, soldiers, and peasants; that authority must be followed at all costs; and that obedience, humility, and perseverance are the hallmarks of a good Christian subject.

But even as the komedya functioned primarily as a piece of dramatic propaganda for the Spanish colonizer, Filipino artists found a way of either neutralizing its colonial messages or by alluding to the less-than-ideal conditions of life under oppressive and racist rulers. To deemphasize or marginalize the anti-Muslim stories of the komedya species called the moro-moro, Francisco Baltazar (1788-1862) created a number of komedya, many with an all-Muslim cast of characters, where the focus was no longer on the conflict between Christians and Moors inevitably ending in the defeat and/or baptism of the latter, but on human relationships and the themes of love, betrayal, power, and honor. Moreover, as was the custom then, Baltazar used the character of the pusong (trickster), the very popular comedian who lightens the ponderous komedya with jokes, whether written or improvised, to allude to various injustices of the colonial regime, such as the abuses committed by the guardia civil (constable) against ordinary indio (Christianized native).
