article.value: The Playlets

From the colonial regime to the present century, the teachings of the Spanish Catholic Church, specifically on the life and sufferings of Jesus Christ and the Catholic saints, and the superiority of Catholicism over all other faiths, have been taught to the Filipino Catholic laity, not only from the book and the pulpit but also from the stage and the street. Revolving around the important seasons of Christmas, Lent, or the feast days of barrio or town patron saints, religious playlets either embroider on the basic, traditional rituals prescribed by the Roman liturgy or create new dialogue and/or music to dramatize an episode in the life of Christ or a saint.

Of the Christmas plays, the most famous are the Tagalog panunuluyan (seeking entry) and pananawagan (calling out) and the Bikol kagharong (going from house to house), which reenact Mary and Joseph’s search for an inn on the first Christmas Eve. In Kawit, Cavite, where the panunuluyan is known as the maytinis, a young man and a young woman sing their plea to the owners of about five houses—to no avail. Then a procession of about 13 floats depicts characters from the Old Testament like Adam and Eve, Noah, Moses, David, Esther, and Judith; events from the New Testament, like the Annunciation and Visitation; and an allegory of Mother Philippines. Before midnight, the procession winds up in church. At the “Gloria” during the midnight mass, the birth of Jesus in a cave is heralded with the singing of little girls dressed as angels.

Another Christmas playlet is the pastores (shepherds). In Bicol towns, pastores refers to a group of young men and women in shepherd costumes who dance and sing Christmas carols in Bikol and Spanish in front of different houses. In Cebu and Leyte, the pastores is a short play depicting the journey of the shepherds to Bethlehem. In Tolosa, Leyte, the pastores features young shepherdesses with full skirts and wide-brimmed hats. Going from house to house, they sing Christmas songs in their native Waray and dance as they search for the Infant Jesus. On their way, the devil tries to block them. They debate with the devil in verse until he goes away. They then proceed on their journey until they find the newly born Messiah.

The rarest of the Christmas playlets is that of the tatlong hari (Three Kings), which is found only in Gasan, Marinduque. Here, the “kings” parade on horses following a star on a bamboo pole, then end up in front of a stage which depicts Herod’s palace. They ask Herod about the baby boy of Bethlehem, depart, and find the Infant Jesus, but fail to return. Herod is livid with anger and sends his soldiers to kill all babies below two years of age. The play ends with Herod going mad and, until a few years ago, destroying the set. In Floridablanca, Pampanga, the tatlong hari is not a play but a procession featuring three men dressed as Melchor, Gaspar, and Baltazar. In Mabitac, Laguna, the kings are played by three boys, who ride on horses from the church to the munisipyo (town hall). From the munisipyo’s balcony, they throw candies and money to the screaming crowds below.

In the past, on 28 Dec, a play on the niños inocentes (innocent children) used to be performed in Rizal Province to depict the beheading of the innocents by Herod’s soldiers. In Gasan, Marinduque, it was a parade of higante (giants) followed by men giving out animal-shaped rice cakes.

Lent features at least nine different playlets that enact different episodes in the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Found in most Catholic parishes all over the Philippines is the Palm Sunday osana (hosanna), which is based on the liturgy of Palm Sunday. In Santa Isabel, Malolos, Bulacan, the osana, also called humenta (donkey) because it features a karo (float) carrying the image of Christ riding on a donkey, begins with the blessing of the palms in a small visita (chapel) about a kilometer away from the church. From there to the church, the priest who plays Christ leads the faithful in a reenactment of the Savior’s triumphal entry into Jerusalem. Stepping over the tapis (overskirts) laid out by devout old women, the priest walks in front of the karo bearing the image of Christ. He stops in front of each of the four kubol (small balconies) placed in equal distances along the route of the procession. On each kubol, little girls in white dresses and carrying little baskets filled with flower petals sing different versions of the “Hosanna,” praising the Son of David who comes in the name of the Lord to the accompaniment of a brass band. As the procession winds up in the parish church, church bells peal, and the priest then celebrates the Palm Sunday mass.

In most parishes, the via crucis (way of the cross) is a solemn procession of the image of the Nazarene, usually held on the different Sundays of Lent or on Holy Week. The candlelit procession stops to pray at each of the 14 Stations of the Cross enshrined in various parts of the town. The town of Paete in Laguna boasts of a special via crucis called salubong (meeting) on Holy Wednesday for Catholics or Holy Thursday for Aglipayans, and this salubong features moving images manipulated from underneath with an elaborate system of strings and pulleys. Unlike most via crucis, Paete’s does not have altars, and stops to reenact only three scenes. On the first corner, the statue of the Nazareno (Christ carrying the cross), standing firm under the weight of the cross, is greeted by the Virgin Mary, whose hands reach out to her son. Later at another corner is the image of Veronica wiping Christ’s face with a towel. At the last stop, the Virgin meets Veronica, who shows her the three faces of Christ imprinted on her towel. Throughout the procession, a group of singers provides the dialogue between images in hair-raising, high-pitched chant.

In most Catholic and Aglipayan parishes today, the liturgical ritual of the paghuhugas (washing), which dramatizes the washing of the feet of the apostles by Christ in the Last Supper, is the highlight of Maundy Thursday. In the sanctuary and near the altar, the priest, representing Christ, pours water from a pitcher onto a basin to literally wash and kiss the right foot of each of the 12 parishioners dressed as apostles.

In some Tagalog and Bicol towns, another reenactment follows the paghuhugas—the huling hapunan or ultima cena (last supper), which commemorates Jesus’s last meal with his apostles. In Gasan, Marinduque, after the washing of the feet, the priest and the 12 apostles proceed from the church to the principal sponsor’s house, where they partake of a last supper comprised of popular native fare like sweet-and-sour lapu-lapu, pancit, chopsuey, and rice, as a huddle of women chants the episode on the Last Supper from the Tagalog pasyon. Later, all spectators partake of the dinner.

On Good Friday, the siete palabras (seven last words) dramatizes Christ’s agony on the cross from noon to three in the afternoon. In Santa Elena, Buhi, Camarines Sur, a wooden image of Christ hangs from the cross as laymen give homilies on the Seven Last Words. As each of the last words are spoken by the speaker at the beginning of his homily, two or three blasts of fire are launched into the air by fire blowers near the cross. After Christ dies at three o’clock, two men, dressed as Joseph and Nicodemus, take the image down from the cross and lay it out on a stretcher. In a heartrending chant, a woman playing the Virgin weeps and chants an eerie lamentation about Jesus’s hair and the wounds in his hands, feet, and side. After the lamentation, the people wipe the image’s hands and legs with their handkerchiefs.

In Pakil, Laguna, the highlight of Good Friday is the late afternoon or early evening procession of the santo entierro (holy burial). Preceded by the images of San Juan, Maria Cleofe, Maria Salome, Magdalena, and the Mater Dolorosa that are all dressed in black, the image of the dead Christ, which was earlier taken down from the cross from which it hung during the Siete Palabras, is carried on a stretcher by devotees. The procession winds its way around the streets of Pakil, preceded by sacristans sounding wooden clappers, which take the place of the regular bells for a more somber tone, and accompanied by a band playing a mournful punebre (funeral march). Then at each of several estaciones (stations) where an altar has been built and decorated with fronds and flowers, as the choir sings the “Patawad, O Diyos Ko” (Have Mercy, My Lord) to the accompaniment of a violin, the bearers of Christ’s image stop and place the whole stretcher on the altar, under which are containers with live coals burning kamanyang (incense) of dried lanzones and ginger peelings. As prayers are said, the image is smoked like a regular corpse for a few minutes to symbolize the cleansing of all impurities. Then the tambuli (carabao horn) is sounded, and a crier in an eerie voice calls out, “Misericordia, Señor” (Have mercy, Lord). After this, the bearers take the stretcher on their shoulders once again, and the procession moves to the next estacion where the same rituals are repeated. With the intermittent cries of “Misericordia, Señor,” the doleful sounds of the band, and the slowly moving mass of candle-bearing devotees, the procession ends up in church in the early evening.

On the evening of Good Friday or Black Saturday, a procession called soledad (solitude) dramatizes the loneliness of Mary from the death of her son. In Baao, Camarines Sur, the image of a Virgin in black is brought around the poblacion (town proper), accompanied by the karo of San Pedro, San Juan, and Maria Magdalena, among others, and preceded by a group of young musicians called the estudiantina. The procession stops in front of several houses where singers comfort the Virgin with songs in Latin like the “Ave Maria.” On the eve of Easter Sunday, plays depicting the Resurrection of Jesus Christ are performed in some towns. The Resurrection play of Lubao, Pampanga, written in the 1920s, uses special effects. So does the new pagkabuhay in Angono, Rizal, where the events leading to the Resurrection are enacted by the townspeople on a stage in the church plaza on Black Saturday.

Popular in many Catholic and Aglipayan parishes all over the country, the salubong (meeting), which is also known as padafung, encuentro, sugat, sabet, and alleluya, reenacts the meeting of the Virgin and the Risen Christ in the early morning of Easter Sunday. One of the grandest salubong is found in Angono, Rizal. This opens with a spirited dance of the tinyenta (female lieutenant), who waves a short flag. After this, the kapitana (female captain) declaims a long poem speaking of the fulfillment of Christ’s promise. Then birds of bamboo and paper swoop down from the corners of the four-poster structure called galilee, which has a heart hanging at the center that conceals the little angel of the salubong. The angel is then lowered toward the image of the Virgin below. As the angel sing the Latin Antiphon “Regina Coeli, Laetare” (Queen of Heaven, Rejoice), together with the other angels on the ground, she slowly takes off the Virgin’s black veil to signify that the latter’s Son had indeed risen from the dead. The salubong is capped with the kapitana’s dance of exaltation featuring a flag emblazoned with the word “Mabuhay” (Long Live).

In Marinduque, the main feature of the Easter celebration is still the moryonan or moriones (literally, helmets). Wearing folk interpretations of Roman soldiers’s costumes, male penitents dramatize the story of the soldier Longhino who pierced the side of Christ but who was later convinced of Christ’s divinity when he witnessed the Resurrection. Pilate and the Pharisees try to pay him off to keep quiet about what he saw. He refuses and instead runs around the town telling everyone about the risen Christ. Pilate sends his soldiers after Longhino, who is then captured and finally beheaded—that is, his helmet is impaled on a wooden sword and held up for all to see.

With the triumph of good, evil must be punished. Hudas, the ritual burning of Judas Iscariot, is still performed in some Bulacan and Pampanga towns on Easter Sunday. In Santa Rita, Pampanga, the bamboo-and-paper effigy of the traitor Judas Iscariot stands on a bamboo pole in the church patio in the middle of four bamboo posts located near the four corners of the large patio. After the Easter morning mass, churchgoers gather to witness the punishment of the traitor. Christian tradition teaches that Judas’s body hanging from a tree was eaten up by black birds. Thus the firecrackers—coming from each of the bamboo poles in each of the corners—are masked with cardboard figures of black birds. Each of these birds, once “lighted,” rides on a cable connecting the post to Judas’s hands and feet. This way, the birds are made to swoop down to “devour” the limbs of his body. In the end, the torso and, finally, the head are blown up, as the audience of elders and youths scream with delight.

Playlets are likewise performed to celebrate the feasts of patron saints. In some towns in Dumaguete, Negros Oriental, the playlet in Cebuano called San Jose used to feature a man, a woman, and a child dressed as San Jose, the Virgen, and the Santo Niño, respectively, walking around town and finally presiding over the feast prepared by a sponsor. Sometime in May in Camarines Norte, the dotoc shows a group of pilgrims joining up with another group going to Persia to pay homage to the Holy Cross, while the lagaylay features dances by Queen Elena and her son Constantino, accompanied by flag bearers and guards of honor, as they sing antiphonal verses in search and praise of the Holy Cross. On the feast of San Martin de Tours in October and that of the Virgin of Caysasay in December, several young people of Taal perform the lua (praise), a long poem that expresses the gratitude of the people of Taal to their patron saints for favors received as well as their prayer for the continued protection of their town from all calamities, natural and man-made. These poems are declaimed by the luwante on a stage before the image of the patron saint when the procession stops in front of the luwante’s house.

In the 19th century, the most important playlet staged to honor a patron saint was the moros y cristianos, performed by rural folk on the street. Invariably, this dance drama focused on the clash between the Christians and the Moors or non-Christians. On the feast of Santiago on 25 Jul, the Cebuano kinabayo (literally, using horses) of Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte, reenacts the Battle of Covadonga, which supposedly happened in 718 AD, where Santiago came down from the sky on his white horse to help the Christians under Pelayo defeat the Moors under Alkamah. In Ivana, Batanes, on the feast of San Jose on 1 May, three groups of males—young, middle-aged, old—perform the palo-palo (fighting with sticks), which depicts a battle between the Christians and the Moors. In Cabagan, Isabela, the feast of Santo Domingo is celebrated on 8 Aug with the sambali, a choreographed street fight between the Christian Ibanag and the non-Christian Kalinga. In Ibajay, Aklan, the sayaw (dance), which is an offering to the patron Santo Niño every third Sunday of January, features Moorish ambassadors being sent to the Christian Bisaya (Visayan) and a grand battle between the two armies that ends in the defeat of the Moors. The same playlet is called sinulog in Calbiga, Western Samar, curaldal or batalla in some towns of Pampanga, and maglalatik or magbabao in Biñan, Laguna.

A variation of the moros y cristianos is the bakahan (battle) of San Antonio, Laguna, a unique play performed from two to three in the afternoon of Good Friday. The bakahan dramatizes the fight between San Miguel Arcangel, here played by a boy of about 10, and the hudyo (Jews) played by older boys in bizarre masks and costumes. Unique to San Antonio, this story highlights the struggle between good and evil in the hour before Christ’s death.

Many of these playlets flourish to our day because of the support of individuals, civic organizations, and even local government who continue to believe in the teachings of the Catholic religion, in spite of the inroads of mass media and the “modern scientific culture.” As in the past, participation in or sponsorship of these events is a panata (vow), believed to be efficacious in conciliating and persuading Christian deities to grant personal wishes. Moreover, the playlets perform an important social function. Since they involve all classes and sectors of the barrio or town, they effectively reaffirm the values and beliefs shared by the community, thereby strengthening the individual’s commitment to society.
The Sinakulo

The sinakulo (literally, cenacle) or passion play probably began as a dramatization of the events depicted in the first pasyon, the Mahal na Passion (The Holy Passion), 1703, by Gaspar Aquino de Belen. By the end of the 19th century and beginning of the 20th, the sinakulo became a formal play with sets and costumes, performed by traveling commercial troupes like the Cenaculistang Pasay in the teatro (theater), on the open-air entablado (stage), and in the sabungan (cockpit) in the barrios of Bulacan and Rizal. Soon Pampanga and Bicol began to organize their own community sinakulo, which usually took the whole of the Semana Santa (Holy Week) to perform.

As it exists today, the sinakulo is a play written in verse (octosyllabic quintillas) or in prose, dramatizing the history of salvation—from the creation of the world and the first human beings to the assumption and coronation of the Virgin Mary in heaven, but paying special attention to the life, sufferings, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Other names for the passion play are tanggal (deposition) in Bicol, taltal (nailing) in Negros, and pasion y muerte (passion and death) in many towns. A shorter form of the sinakulo focusing on the events from the Agony in the Garden to the Crucifixion is usually presented on Good Friday morning and afternoon. These shorter versions are the pagdakip in Malolos, Bulacan, or the penitensiya in Cainta, Rizal. In Cutud, San Fernando, Pampanga, the sinakulo ends up with the actual nailing on the cross of the penitent playing Christ. Over the years the number of penitents being nailed to the cross has increased that Cutud has become a favorite tourist destination every Good Friday.

The sinakulo orihinal uses the popular Pasyong Genesis as its basic text, following the pasyon’s chronology of events and lifts stanzas of dialogue from its episodes. To these are added stories and stanzas taken from the religious awit and korido from other pasyon like the Pasyong Candaba and Pasyon Truncalis, from popular magazines like Liwayway, from religious novels like Martir sa Golgota (Martyr of Golgotha), from other sinakulo scripts, and lately, from “Lenten” movies like the Ten Commandments, The Robe, Quo Vadis, Jesus of Nazareth, and Passion of the Christ. A full sinakulo script would include the following scenes: the seven days of creation, the temptation of Adam and Eve in paradise, the tragedy of Cain and Abel, the flood and Noah’s ark, the birth, education and wedding of the Virgin, the Annunciation, the Visitation, Christ’s nativity, his debate with the doctors in the temple, his recollection in the desert, the miracles in Jesus’s public ministry, the events starting from his entry to Jerusalem on Palm Sunday to his resurrection on Easter Sunday, the Ascension, the descent of the Holy Spirit, and the assumption and coronation of the Virgin in heaven. Apocryphal stories relating to Herod the Great, Magdalena, Boanerhes, Dimas, Barabas, and Samuel Belibet may also be included.

Presented at the public plaza during Lent and especially on Holy Week, the sinakulo uses a proscenium-type stage in the open air. Different types of telon (backdrop) situate the action of the scenes, while props, often with no sense of history, are used as required by the scenes. The whole production usually has a main director, who is assisted by the directors for music, sets, and lights. The sinakulo’s personahe or characters, who perform in fulfillment of religious vows, may use the traditional chant and marches or declaim prose dialogue to canned music. Traditionally, costumes follow those worn by the images of Christ and the saints on Holy Week processions, but nowadays they are imitations of those seen in movies about Christ and the Roman times.

Even when they use modern staging techniques, most contemporary sinakulo continue to propagate values of passivity and blind obedience by highlighting Christ as the model of subservience, a God who is meek as a lamb, and a savior who accepts all the torture inflicted on him with total humility. Such values went a long way in convincing indios to meekly accept all economic and political impositions of the Spanish colonizer for centuries. Today, such passivity and obedience continue to shape contemporary minds, making them noncritical, acquiescent, and predisposed to follow authoritarian rule.
The Sarsuwela

The Spanish zarzuela was introduced in Manila in 1878 or 1879, through the performance of Jugar con Fuego (Playing with Fire) by the troupe of Dario Cespedes. In the following years, more groups arrived, notably that of Alejandro Cubero, which presented the zarzuela not only in Manila but in Iloilo, Cebu, Pampanga, and Bicol. Inspired by this new “enlightened” form, Filipinos soon created their own original zarzuela—the sarsuwela —in Tagalog, Pampango, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Waray. The sarsuwela thrived from 1900 to 1940 because of mass support and elite sponsorship, and because of its portrayal of familiar characters, conditions, and concerns.

With the rise of bodabil and the movies in the pre-World War II era, the sarsuwela slowly migrated from stage to screen until it was replaced by the Hollywood-type musical. Today, the traditional sarsuwela is still staged in the Ilocos and a few other towns, while its revitalized form is sometimes done in Manila and in Silay City.

The sarsuwela is a play that is comprised of one to five acts, with songs and dances, and is generally in prose, less often in verse. It portrays typical Filipino situations within the framework of a love story and incorporates contemporary issues. Sarsuwela may depict lofty themes such as love of country during a time of revolution, as in Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1902; satirize the foibles of Filipinos who suffer from colonial mentality, as in Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920; narrate an entertaining love story of children and parents separated at birth, as in Anak ng Dagat (Child of the Sea), 1921; or comment on social climbing and marriages of convenience as in Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919.

An important sarsuwela is Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921. The beautiful Nati, daughter of the landlord Don Juan, has just graduated as a pharmacist. The widower Don Juan and his fiancé, Doña Irene, both notorious usurers, plan to marry her off to a person with influence and money, but Nati loves Mario, the son of the peasants Andong and Maria, who are indebted to Don Juan. Meanwhile, at Nati’s party, Mario introduces Marcelo, who has been sent by the government to establish rural credit for farmers to save them from usurious practices. Later, when Andong and Maria try to pay off their debt to Don Juan, they are shocked to find out that it has more than quintupled in two years’ time. Because Andong cannot pay the huge amount, Don Juan sends the police to confiscate his properties. Andong appeals to the courts, but the judge, who is Don Juan’s friend, sides with the latter. In desperation, the farmers harvest the rice from Don Juan’s fields for themselves. Don Juan blames Mario for this, despite Nati’s explanation that it is Mario who protects Don Juan’s interests. Angry, Don Juan goes to confront the peasants who chase him all the way to his house. Mario intervenes and protects him. Marcelo explains that the court has reversed its decision and will ask Andong to pay back only the original amount that he had borrowed. Don Juan accepts the court’s decision, reconciles with Andong and Maria, and accepts Mario as his daughter’s fiancé.

Since the early decades of the 20th century, the sarsuwela has been presented by commercial troupes like the compañias of Hermogenes Ilagan and Severino Reyes in the early 1900s, in the teatros of big cities like Manila, Iloilo, and Cebu or on open-air entablado in rural areas during town fiestas where they are sponsored by hermanos mayores, usually in fulfilment of a panata to the patron saint of the town in whose honor it is being performed. Painted telones provide the setting for scenes (e.g., facade of a rich man or poor man’s house, interior of a rich man or poor man’s house, a rural landscape), and are complemented with appropriate props (e.g., sala sets for the houses of the rich, benches for poor abodes). Acting and costumes identify the bida (protagonist) and the kontrabida (antagonist). A small or big orchestra accompanies the songs, which usually include kundiman, balitaw, balse, danza, fox-trot, and later, cha-cha, rock and roll, and twist or whatever is popular at a given period. An overall director (or principal director) rehearses the actors, often acts as impresario as well, and coordinates the work of the maestro (music director and band master), who subcontracts musicians, rehearses and conducts them on stage, and rehearses the singing of the actors; the telonero (telon person), who works the telones and sets up the props; the electricista (electrician), who takes care of the lights and special effects; the apuntador or diktador (prompter), who feeds the lines to the actors from a concha (shell) in front of the entablado; and all the other cast and crew connected with the production.

When it first bloomed in the 1900s, the sarsuwela was rightly regarded as an “enlightened” form of theater because it introduced a more realistic way of depicting reality, reorienting the Filipino’s eyes from the fantasy of European kingdoms of the komedya to the social evils confronting him in his time, like oppressive landlords, corrupt politicians, gambling, usury, and colonial mentality. However, although it presented characters, situations, and problems drawn from real life, it painted these characters as types according to the bida and kontrabida mode, and contented itself with describing a range of social and political problems but then solving them in a conciliatory fashion, reducing class contradictions and structural injustice into personal problems. In this sense and in spite of its social conscience, the sarsuwela propagated a worldview and a value system that in the final analysis strengthened the status quo at the expense of the ordinary people who comprised the bulk of its audiences.
The Drama

The drama was brought into the country by Spanish troupes, many of whom came after the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869. Although these groups presented principally Spanish melodramas in the theaters of Manila, they also did prose plays without music called “drama” (to be distinguished from “drama” meaning “play” in general in English), which were written by Manila artists. Among the first drama written in Spanish by Filipino-born Spaniards and Spanish mestizos were Cuadros Filipinos (Philippine Scenes), 1882, and Jose el Carpintero (Joseph the Carpenter), 1880. Two of the early dramas written in the native languages were Ang Babai nga Huwaran (The Model Woman), 1878, and R.I.P., 1901.

The drama is a play in prose that revolves around Filipino characters and situations, emphasizing current issues. Sometimes, the drama may feature a song or two to create mood and provide relief from long stretches of dialogue. Dramas were often performed together with the sarsuwela. Sometimes, three of these dramas were combined for an evening’s performance. During the Japanese occupation, the drama was incorporated into the bodabil (local vaudeville) as its main feature, creating a new form called the stage show. As the movies drew audiences away from the theaters, the romantic melodramas and the comic dramas, like the sarsuwela, transferred to the screen and were known as “drama” and “komedi.” Today, the same drama and komedi are heard over the radio or are seen on television.

The drama has three general types: the drama simboliko, which allegorizes stock characters from the romantic drama to comment on a political/social situation, like Tanikalang Guinto (Golden Chain), 1902; the drama romantiko which focuses on a love or family story that may end happily or tragically, like Esperanza, 1916; and the drama comico or comedy, which may use any kind of plot or character in order to create situations, whether satirical, farcical, or slapstick, that will make people laugh, like Mga Santong Tao (People Saints), 1901.

In 1902, Juan Abad and his group of relatives and friends staged Tanikalang Guinto at the Teatro Libertad in Manila. It later caused the author’s incarceration because it exposed America as the new colonizer. In this drama, Liwanag (meaning “light,” representing a free Philippines) is being courted by Kaulayaw (meaning “sweetheart,” representing Filipinos fighting for freedom). But Liwanag’s uncle, Maimbot (“greedy,” representing the United States), puts obstacles to their marriage (freedom of the Philippines). Maimbot gifts Liwanag with a golden bracelet to take her mind away from Kaulayaw, but she is loyal to Kaulayaw. Angry, Maimbot ties her to a tree with the golden bracelet, which now becomes a golden chain, and pays Nagtapon ( “a wastrel,” representing Filipinos who had collaborated with the Americans) to guard Liwanag and keep Kaulayaw, Nagtapon’s brother, away from her. When Kaulayaw tries to save Liwanag, Nagtapon kills him. Liwanag despairs and wants to kill herself but Diwa (representing the spirit of struggle) enters and tells her that Kaulayaw will be brought back to life. In the final tableau, Nagtapon is taken away by the devil and Maimbot by Death. As Liwanag and Diwa are carried to the skies in a bubble, Kaulayaw is crowned by Bat (God).

Like the sarsuwela, the drama draws its themes, characters, and stories from current issues, whether these be political, religious, or social. A typical romantic drama is Manotok by Makahiya [pseud]. Mariano, a poor fisherman, catches his wife Lucia with her lover Don Alvaro, the landlord. Alvaro escapes, and Mariano, in anger, strangles his wife to death. The police arrest Mariano who is then sentenced to a prison term of 15 years. As Mariano serves his term, Pining, Mariano’s daughter, is raised by a kind farmer, Mang Kiko. Pretty and kind Pining, who runs a little bibingka (rice cake) stall, is courted by Arturo, a handsome lieutenant. Mang Kiko approves of Pining’s suitor and everything goes well until Don Alvaro, back from months of traveling abroad, asks to see his tenant Mang Kiko. Alvaro is attracted to Pining and tries to take her by force. She resists and slaps him. When he persists, Manotok, the idiot whom Pining had been kind to, hits Alvaro with a piece of wood. In retaliation, Alvaro dismisses Mang Kiko as his tenant. To make matters worse, Mang Kiko goes blind. In the midst of this double tragedy, Arturo proposes marriage to Pining, and the latter accepts.

Meanwhile, Alvaro has a heated discussion with Mary, a bailarina (nightclub dancer) whom he lives with, who demands that Alvaro make good his promise of marriage to her. Alvaro insults Mary and drives her out of the house. As Mary leaves the house, the idiot Manotok enters Alvaro’s house, picks up a letter Mary drops, and goes away with another letter he takes from Alvaro’s desk. Meanwhile, Alvaro follows Mary to Mang Kiko’s house, kills her, and frames Mang Kiko so he would be blamed for the crime. Arturo has the painful duty of arresting his future father-in-law, who gives himself up peacefully. At the trial presided over by a young idealistic judge (Alvaro’s son), Manotok reveals himself to be Mariano coming to claim justice for himself. Using the letters he got from Alvaro’s house, Mariano proves that Alvaro had an affair with his wife and that it was Alvaro who killed Mary. Mang Kiko is exonerated, and Pining and her father are reunited.

Like the sarsuwela, the drama was presented commercially on the open-air entablado in the provinces during fiestas. Using telones and appropriate props, the drama was performed by professional or by community actors sometimes called dramista, who were taught the techniques of acting for melodrama or for comedy. A director-impresario took charge of fees and arrangements, and hired and supervised actors, composer-conductors, set and property masters, electricians, and other crew members.

Most dramas, like the typical sarsuwela of the pre-World War II period, depicted familiar characters, issues, and situations. However, like the sarsuwela, the drama usually reduced real economic and political contradictions to personal conflicts that could therefore be more easily resolved by the reconciliation of opponents, the contrition and forgiveness of the offenders, the conviction of the culprit or, as in most cases, the change of heart of the gambler, the prostitute, the usurer, or the corrupt politician. A major exception to these types of dramas was the allegorical dramas of 1902 to 1905. These dramas, in spite of the anti-sedition law enforced by the Americans and the threat of incarceration, successfully exposed the political contradiction between Filipino nationalists who fought for the independence earlier won from Spain and the American colonizers who pretended to help the Philippine Revolution against Spain but were now taking that independence away from the Filipinos because of their own colonial intentions. Here for the first time is drama that does not reaffirm but seeks to overthrow a new colonial status quo established through political deceit and superior arms.
Epilogue

Most komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and drama continue to propagate ideas that lead to divisiveness (e.g., Muslims are bad, Christians are good), passivity (e.g., to be Christlike submissiveness is always good), authoritarianism (e.g., “Utos ng hari, hindi mababali,” meaning “The king’s word cannot be broken”), and blind acceptance of the status quo (e.g., it is not social structures that are oppressive but abusive individuals). Clearly, values such as these can hardly be called progressive, especially in a new nation such as the Philippines which is trying to create a critical citizenry as well as unity among its varied sectors. Given the continuing popularity of these forms among provincial audiences, however, contemporary playwrights have seen fit to inject into these plays themes and conflicts that are more consonant with current concerns. In 1962, Max Allanigue rejected the divisive messages of the traditional komedya in his Prinsipe Rodante (Prince Rodante), which argues that one is bad not because of one’s religion but because one does not respect justice. In 1983, Rene O. Villanueva reshaped the komedya in his Sandaang Panaginip (A Hundred Dreams), which satirizes a kingdom (the Philippines) made bankrupt by the extravagance of its queen (Imelda Marcos). In 1992, the Cultural Center of the Philippines produced Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura) in komedya form for the grade school students of Dongalo, Parañaque, to encourage the youth to revitalize the komedya with messages that are no longer anti-Muslim but anti-authoritarianism.

The Christ story has likewise been reinterpreted according to current conditions. As early as 1907, Aurelio V. Tolentino’s Bagong Kristo (New Christ) portrayed Christ as a labor leader, who organizes the workers in the city and the countryside to demand decent wages from landlords and factory owners. From 1988 to 1992, Al Santos’s Kalbaryo ng Maralitang Tagalungsod (Calvary of the Urban Poor) focused on the plight of the Manila urban poor, whose calvary is a garbage dump called Smokey Mountain and whose crosses are the various anti-poor ordinances issued by the local government.

Of all the traditional forms, it is the sarsuwela that has had the most number of innovations. In 1977, Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Bundok (The Mountain) showed the Cordillera groups linking arms to fight foreigners mining their lands. In 1976, Domingo Landicho’s Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow) satirized the colonial mentality of Filipino balikbayan. In 1980, Isagani R.Cruz’s Ms. Philippines exposed the dreams and frustrations of beauty-contest participants. In 1982, Nicanor Tiongson’s Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907) underscored the conflict between pro-American and pro-Filipino forces in the political, cultural, and economic levels. In 1998, four new sarsuwela were declared winners in the sarsuwela competition sponsored by the National Centennial Commission. Top prize was won by Palasyo ni Valentin (Valentin’s Palace) by Mario O’Hara, which depicted a gothic love triangle between a Spanish theater impresario, an aspiring native sarsuwela star, and the latter’s indio suitor. The second prize was shared by Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom) by George de Jesus III, a love story set during the Philippine revolution of 1896; Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others) by Bienvenido Lumbera, a story about American abuse of women during the Philippine-American War; and Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (Nation: Just One Foot Left) by Melba Padilla Maggay, about the EDSA Revolt and its relation to the 1896 Revolution.

These attempts at revitalization prove that the creative use of traditional dramas for aesthetic expression on contemporary realities is not only possible but necessary, acquiring new meaning for contemporary audiences. If these attempts succeed, these plays will not only help form a new citizenry and nation but also prove themselves significant enough to be considered pillars of a Filipino national theater.

With the establishment of American colonial rule in 1901, the United States introduced into the Philippines American ideals and lifestyle through a nationwide grassroots-level educational system and later through print and broadcast media, and film. In the decades that followed and even beyond American rule that ended in 1946, what came into the country were the American forms of art, and with them, the European, too—specifically, the English.

The American tradition in Philippine theater is evidenced in the bodabil; the Western plays done in the English language or translated in Filipino; and the original plays produced by contemporary theater actors which use styles like theater of the absurd, epic theater, expressionism, and various forms of realism. The American tradition entered the Philippine stage principally through the educational system established in 1901 and since then has continued, developing with fresh inputs; merging with or transforming traditional theater; siring translations and adaptations; participating in the formation of new playwrights, new trends, new theater; and on the whole, contributing ideas and energy to Philippine theater.

The colonizers who arrived in the Philippines to establish the American Insular Government came upon a theater scene they could not understand. They found religious dramas and dramatizations, long “hyperbolic” verse plays, and the plays they came to call “seditious” because these had the temerity to espouse Philippine independence from the United States. Even if Arthur Riggs, military journalist and eyewitness, did not consider the Filipino stage worthy of the name “theater,” the native dramatic tradition continued to flourish in the form of the rites and rituals, verse debates, songs and dances of the indigenous theater, as well as folk theater represented by the komedya, and the budding drama and sarsuwela. Each simply found its place on the different stages, whether outdoors or indoors, in barrios, towns, and cities, with its own audience, whether paying or not, during religious feast days, town fiestas, civic occasions, and eventually evenings at the theater. Inevitably, however, the entry of a new culture would have its indelible effect on the Filipino stage.

 

Bodabil

Vaudeville was the first visible influence from America. Although a French form, it was adapted in the United States as a show made up of an assortment of entertainment numbers. These shows composed of songs and dances, magic and music acts, skits and stand-up comedy, and chorus girls and comedians, were first brought in to entertain the American soldiers at about the turn of the century. They entertained the native audience as well, who found them convenient and portable showcases for entertainment spectacles.

The songs and dances of bodabil, vaudeville’s Filipinized word (vodavil, for writers in Spanish) were fill-ins between short sarsuwela or between acts of a long one. They were called stage shows during the Japanese occupation, and much later, variety shows. In some provinces, the bodabil intermissions were called jamboree, a word that had originally been applied to the opening musical numbers of stage shows.

Bodabil eventually went on stage in such venues as the Manila Grand Opera House and the Savoy Theater (later Clover Theater), forming images of what entertainment was in the minds of Filipino audiences. Bodabil-type acts appeared on political stages and decades later deteriorated into burlesque and strip shows in cheap theaters in suburbs or around the American bases.

While it reigned, bodabil created musical trends and performance genres, and helped establish the careers of musicians and other performers. Lou Borromeo tuned to jazz music. Dancers like Benny Mack and Bayani Casimiro, called “the Filipino Fred Astaire,” comic magicians like Canuplin who was billed as “the local Chaplin,” a superb torch singer a la Sophie Tucker called Katy de la Cruz, singers like Diana Toy and Miami Salvador, and much later, Eddie Mesa, “the Filipino Elvis Presley,” Diomedes Maturan, “the local Perry Como,” and Nora Aunor who started as “the Pinay Timi Yuro,” all became popular in the following decades, proving how limber Filipino entertainers were—how easy it was for them to tune in to American rhythms. Their rise also showed the impact and influence of American popular entertainment and how painless and effective a tool popular culture was in the Americanization of the Filipino. The songs, dances, and entertainment forms of most Filipinos until the 1960s were undeniably patterned after “the American dream.” In American popular culture were embodied, for decades, their images of beauty and excellence, of life and self.

Bodabil may have lapsed in popularity, but productions still occasionally feature this form or personalities from the bodabil era, such as in the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s (PETA) play Canuplin, 1980, written by Manny Pambid, which centered on the life of bodabil star Canuto Francia; Musical Theater Philippines’s musical Katy!, 1988, music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Jose Javier Reyes, a biography of the “Queen of Philippine Bodabil” Katy de la Cruz; and Tanghalang Pilipino’s Stageshow, 2012, libretto by Mario O’Hara and music by Jeffrey Hernandez, a recounting of the plight of a small group of dedicated bodabil artists during the twilight years of their careers.

 

Filipino Theater in English

Historically, the next and certainly the biggest American influence on Philippine theater was the English language propagated through the educational system established so systematically in 1901. Unlike the Spaniards who had reluctantly and only sporadically taught the Filipinos their language, the Americans established a public school system and teacher-training institutions immediately upon the installation of an insular government. English, it was decided, would be the vehicle of education, and to accomplish this, American teachers were fielded. At first, they were just the soldiers and their wives. Eventually, the Thomasites, a shipload of teachers who came on the USS Thomas in 1901, were sent expressly to teach Filipinos English and, perhaps unbeknownst even to the teachers, the culture loaded in the language.

Theater in English was the immediate result of both the language and the educational system. Considering, however, that these teachers were the fruits of a Victorian education (i.e., not enthusiastic about theater), and had only witnessed, if at all, an American theater in its infancy, the effects of American-style education were not immediately felt in the theater but in the classroom.

There was the change of language, first of all, which inferentially made vernacular theater fit only for the provinces, for the fiestas, and for the unschooled, while English became the language of the schooled and eventually the learned. Certainly the sinakulo and komedya would not be performed or mentioned, much less studied, in schools. And then there were the examples of drama discussed in classrooms: these were textbook plays aimed at teaching the language and serving as practice for the students in speaking English and not linked to the life outside the classroom the way folk plays were so deeply entrenched in community and folk life. Thus, plays staged in classrooms as language exercises came to be many a student’s first and lasting impression of theater. Stories like “The Monkey’s Paw” were dramatized, as was Longfellow’s poem “Evangeline.” A few playlets, dramatizations, and longer plays like Arms and the Man and Polly with a Past, directed by Jean Garrot Edades, were staged at the University of the Philippines (UP).

Eventually there came out of the classrooms native playwrights who spoke the new language with some ease and who wrote plays based on the classroom examples. The first play written in English by Filipinos was A Modern Filipina, 1915, by Jesusa Araullo and Lino Castillejo, both from the Philippine Normal College. The play is about a young woman who speaks her mind and plans her future quite independently then decides to accept a suitor who uses an old trick—he falls out of a tree and plays on her sympathy—because she has really liked him from the start. With mastery of the language came more playwrights like Jorge Bocobo, Carlos P. Romulo, and Vidal Tan, all of them eventually becoming UP presidents, who progressed from writing occasional plays for Rizal Day, school foundation days, and similar occasions, to commenting on local mores (e.g., marriage, customs, and election promises). While the folk play had been written for fiestas and religious feasts like Holy Week and Christmas, the new plays came to be connected to civic occasions. The best of these plays, such as Vidal Tan’s The Husband of Mrs. Cruz, 1929, a comic rendering of elections and their effect on community and family relationships, showed the Filipino’s ease with the language and with the one-act play, and his successful adaptation of both Philippine subject matter and life.

Soon came the concept of legitimate theater on legitimate stages, as distinguished from the temporary, open-air, built-for-the-occasion, or built-for-other-purposes stages of folk theater. The legitimate stage was only for drama and to access it, the audience had to purchase tickets to a play that was an event in itself and not part of a community or religious celebration. Legitimate theater required not only a playwright and a director but a support organization for production, publicity, and the box office. Unlike folk theater, there was a clear division between performers and audience, between stage and backstage, and between theater and the life out there.

By the 1940s and 1950s, when drama had moved out of the classroom and onto school and legitimate stages, and Shakespeare and the Greek tragedies had been performed in public by the Ateneo de Manila and the UP theater groups, playwrights such as Severino Montano, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, and later, Alberto Florentino, developed. For them, theater was no classroom exercise but a real and earnest art. Montano, who had studied drama in the United States, still considered it a means of education and established the Arena Theater at the Philippine Normal School (now a university), fielding plays with teachers-actors, like Parting at Calamba and Sabina, 1953, throughout the country to bring modern drama to the schools and communities. Realizing that not many communities could provide real stages, he presented his plays in school auditoriums and classrooms, meeting halls, and open spaces. He also introduced the arena style of production. His most popular play, The Love of Leonor Rivera, 1953, which was about the undying love of Leonor Rivera for Jose Rizal, even through marriage to someone else and even beyond death, had continuous productions all over the Philippines from 1953 to 1964. Though the lyricism was in English, the view of the national hero as suffering man and the object of romantic love was most compatible with native sensibilities.

Guerrero, who taught at UP, wrote about the emerging middle class who were being educated in English and who were adapting the mores and manners of the Americans they read about and watched in the movies. His most popular plays include Wanted: A Chaperone, 1940; Forever, 1941; Condemned, 1943; and The Three Rats, 1948. His UP Mobile Theater took the substance and techniques of his theater around the country, while his UP Dramatic Club trained the actors and directors of future productions in and outside of UP. His plays about basketball players, movie actors, parents and children, suitors and chaperones put the Americanized Philippine world on campus and other stages. The plays from Anglo-American repertories that he staged at UP provided theater experience and ideas for audiences of many ages, among them those who later became leaders in the arts as well as in politics.

Florentino brought to the attention of theater directors and audiences the world outside the English-speaking universe—i.e., the slums and denizens of Tondo, which were the bases for his plays like Cadaver and The World Is an Apple, both in 1954, and Cavort with Angels, 1959. Clear proof of the English dominance in theater was the fact that Florentino’s audiences accepted without question or discomfort the fact that his Tondo stevedores, prostitutes, and slum children spoke correct and idiomatic English. Years later, these plays would be staged in Tagalog translations, and Florentino himself would declare an end to his writing plays in English.

Aside from plays in English about contemporary Philippines, Montano, Guerrero, and Florentino introduced realism, an element not in the sinakulo and the komedya, and only nascent in the sarsuwela. The Biblical stories, apocryphals like the tales of Samuel Belibet and Boanerhes, the romances of the royalty of Albania and Persia, as well as those of the Estrellas and Angelitas of sarsuwela land and the poets and professionals who love them, were now replaced by stories about a country lass falling in love with a married American, politicians and their empty promises, basketball players and movie stars, love triangles, and the plight of stevedores, prostitutes, and squatters. The real Philippine society was creeping onto the stage and creating a new theater.

In schools, drama groups without resident playwrights—the Aquinas Theater Guild at the University of Santo Tomas, the Ateneo de Manila High School’s Dramatic Society, which later became Dulaang Sibol, the Paulinian Players Guild at St. Paul College, the Arellano University Dramatic Club, the Far Eastern University’s Drama Department, the Philippine Women’s University Experimental Theater, the Manuel L. Quezon Dramatic Club, and the University of the East Dramatic Guild—staged American and British plays by Shakespeare, James Barrie, George Bernard Shaw, Gilbert and Sullivan, and occasionally European plays in English translation like Edmond Rostand’s Cyrano de Bergerac and the Greek tragedies. These plays became the lexicon, models, and experience of drama for the Filipino urban youth. For them and for all the theater lovers who watched European classics at Ateneo and modern theater at UP, English was the only language for theater and Anglo-American plays and English translations the only models for world theater.

Thus, although theater in the 1950s was fairly active, it had no connection or relation to vernacular theater, the chasm between them having been widened by both language and ignorance. The centuries-old theater tradition, which was community-based, often outdoors, and staged in various vernaculars, effectively linking indigenous communities to the Hispanized regional cultures, was effectively wiped out by this new theater that defined legitimate theater as being schooled, enclosed in edifices, and staged in English. This was the time, therefore, of such nonschool groups such as the Barangay Theater Guild, the Manila Theater Guild, and the Penmouth Playhouse aiming for legitimate theater and suffering from a lack of funds and audiences, which the school groups had, even though in modest numbers.

It was through the educational system that the idea of modern theater was sold. Students came to be conversant with Shakespeare and Greek tragedy, with George Bernard Shaw and Longfellow, and later with Arthur Miller and Tennessee Williams, without ever having heard of the sarsuwela. The following concepts came as well with these dramas: proscenium stages, box sets, hand props, the fourth wall, later Stanislavsky and the Method, even later the various manifestations of realism and Brecht and other trends and techniques.

This idea of modern theater was reinforced by the movies and later by television shows and videotapes, as well as by materials in print media. The images of musical theater the schooled and the young had were generally not the sarsuwela and Rogelio de la Rosa–Carmen Rosales romances but the Broadway musical kind, as typified by Oklahoma, Carousel, and South Pacific, and the Hollywood musical extravaganza, as exemplified by the musicals from Busby Berkeley and the Ziegfeld Follies to Singing in the Rain. From the movies, too, would come models of heavy drama or light comedy, the classics in traditional or new modes, schools of acting and directing, techniques of staging and presentation. Thus, in the contemporary plays, playwrights and directors might refer to and were certainly influenced by the acting of Greta Garbo and Clark Gable, or situations like those in Back Street, Gone with the Wind, and Casablanca . The idea of theater, its form and content, and its social function of educating and entertaining were, for the schooled Filipinos of the first half of the 20th century, according to the American model. Because of the gap between vernacular and English theaters, there was no consciousness of the community base of Philippine theater or of the forms it had taken before the advent of English and the American educational system.

After Guerrero, Montano, and Florentino, Filipino theater in English continued with the works of Filipino playwrights who wrote original Filipino plays in English. These include Marcelino Agana Jr, who wrote New Yorker in Tondo; Wilfrido D. Nolledo, Island of the Heart, Legend of the Filipino Guitar, and Turn Red the Sea; Jesus T. Peralta, Play the Judas, The Sign of the Sea Gulls, and Longer Than Mourning; Julian E. Dacanay Jr, The Celebrants and The Executives; Estrella D. Alfon, With Patches of Many Hues; Virginia Moreno, Mariang Makiling, Glass Altars, Straw Patriot, The Onyx Wolf, and Indio Spoliarium; Rolando S. Tinio, It’s April, What Are We Doing Here?, and A Life in the Slums; Nestor Torre Jr, No Sadder Race, And a Happy Birthday, A Second Generation, and Dialogue; and Mar Puatu, The Summit. This generation of playwrights was followed by Elsa M. Coscolluela who penned Burning, Katalona, and In My Father’s House; Maidan T. Flores, The Grostesque Among Us; Ricaredo Demetillo, The Heart of Emptiness Is Black; Nick Joaquin, The Beatas; Paul Stephen Lim, Points of Departure; Dong de los Reyes, Earthworms and Penumbra; Isagani R. Cruz, Wedding Night; Tony Perez, Sacraments of the Dead; Herminia Sison, Waiting for Noriyushi; and Felix A. Clemente, The Chieftain’s Daughter.

In the succeeding years, when more Filipino playwrights were already writing original plays written in Filipino and other Philippine languages, a major factor that ensured the continuance of Filipino plays in English was the Palanca Memorial Awards, which had one-act and full-length English plays in its categories.

English-language theater still exists in some schools and most prominently in Repertory Philippines (Rep), founded in 1967, which has regular seasons featuring current successes on Broadway and the London West End. In effect, it continues the training in English-language theater, this time on a professional level, and its successful proponents, such as Lea Salonga, have gone into careers in theater abroad.

Building on Rep’s pioneering efforts in professionalizing English-language theater were Rep alumni who founded several theater groups such as Triumphant People’s Evangelistic Theater Society or Trumpets founded by Audie Gemora, 1990; Actor’s Actors Inc by Bart Guingona, 1992; New Voice Company by Monique Wilson, 1994; 9 Works Theatrical by Robbie Guevara, 2009; and Red Turnip Theater Company by Ana Abad Santos, Topper Fabregas, Jenny Jamora, Cris Villonco, and Rem Zamora, 2013. Other groups focusing on English productions include Atlantis Productions founded by Bobby Garcia, 1999, renamed Atlantis Theatricals Entertainment Group in 2015; and Full House Theater Company, established by the casino Resorts World Manila, 2014, with Michael Williams and Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, both Rep alumni, as co-artistic directors. These groups continue to stage English-language productions.

 

Filipino Theater in the Local Language

Bridging the gap, as well as linking the indigenous, Spanish, and American traditions of Philippine theater, became possible in the late 1960s because of the nationalist movement. An awareness of the inordinate impact of the American orientation on Philippine cultural life was a hallmark of this movement. There was a conscious search for Filipino artifacts, culture, identity, and language.

In theater, this took the form of research into pre-American theater. Theses and shorter studies explored the komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and other native theater forms. Scholars and librarians undertook the retrieval of texts kept by writers and their families in trunks and under beds and thatched roofs. Theater groups like Dulaang Babaylan, PETA, and the UP Repertory Company realized that research was one of their primary tasks, along with revival and revitalization. In lectures and discussions, there was a deliberate effort to synthesize Philippine theater tradition and influences.

Just before the imposition of martial law in 1972, some kind of merging happened among these theater traditions through the activist theater, also called street or protest theater. Influences from American, European, Chinese, and native theaters converged with the need to convey urgent messages of protest and change, and resulted in the street plays staged at Plaza Miranda, in front of factories and buildings, and during rallies and demonstrations. Adaptations were made of Clifford Odets’s Waiting for Lefty, Lope de Vega’s Fuenteovejuna, and the Chinese opera Taking Tiger Mountain by Strategy, sometimes in combination with Philippine folk songs and dances. Young playwrights, directors, and actors were calling on everything they knew and remembered of theater in the urgency of their expression. The language was Filipino—or Tagalog, Cebuano, Ilocano—but the theater experience reflected in the plays was an amalgam of traditions.

Education at the primary, secondary, and tertiary levels was still strongly Anglo-American during these decades. Dramas were read and discussed in English, the choices determined by the availability of American textbooks, and the tastes of teachers trained in America. The pensionado, Fulbright, and other grant programs were not only convenient and helpful, but also seen as highly desirable, necessary for ascent in the academic and cultural ladders. Few went for higher education anywhere but to the United States, and thus the first directors, actors, and theater specialists who pursued careers in Philippine theater knew the American theatrical scene well and held it up as model and ideal.

The theater groups formed in this intercultural matrix, such as the UP Repertory, PETA, the Ateneo Experimental Theater, Repertory Philippines, and Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP), as well as the directors who led them—Behn Cervantes, Cecile Guidote, Rolando S. Tinio, Zeneida Amador, and Antonio Mabesa—were a potent factor in the absorption of foreign theater influences and the formation of contemporary Philippine theater. The directors not only staged plays written by Filipinos but interacted with playwrights, making the plays richer and more stageable.

In effect, the educational system and academic scholarships supported the Anglo-American orientation of Philippine theater, and although attention started to be given to the native-born and Hispanic theaters, these did not have the books, scholars, films and videos, touring opportunities, grants for workshops and conferences, and the glamour of Anglo-American theater in the educated Filipino’s eyes. Add to this scenario the visiting American theater troupes and lecturers who visited universities and provincial centers, the American directors and actors who gave masteral classes, the books on theater available at the Thomas Jefferson Cultural Center and the British Council, and the American films and videos shown to classes and workshops, and one could understand the ease with which Anglo-American theater entered the Philippine experience and consciousness.

 

Plays of Realism

Realism soon stretched into the other areas it already occupied in Western theater. Psychological realism, which puts emphasis on interior characterization motives, is seen in Tony Perez’s explorations of usap-usapan (human interaction) within the family, school, and workplace, among intimates, peers, and superiors, as seen in his Biyaheng Timog (Trip to the South), 1984, and Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), 1988; in Bienvenido Noriega’s inquiry into ideas of home among Filipino expatriates in Europe in Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), 1975; in Elsa Martinez-Coscolluela’s evocation of individual and familial disintegration in In My Father’s House, 1987; and in Kanakan Balintagos’s (also known as Auraeus Solito) Mga Buhay na Apoy (A Breath of Fire), 2015, which is about a family’s struggle to come to terms with its indigenous roots. Perez also wrote a trilogy of plays that touch on middle-class characters dealing with the psychological underpinnings of love and loss: Saan Ba Tayo Ihahatid ng Disyembre? (Where Will December Bring Us?), 2009, staged by PETA, Oktubre, Noong Tayo’y Nagmamahalan Pa (October, When We Were Still in Love), 1993, and Nobyembre, Noong Akala Ko’y Mahal Kita (November, When I Thought I Love You), 1994, the last two staged by Tanghalang Pilipino.

Focusing on people and their formation, aspirations, and interaction in the context of society, plays of social realism have explored many levels and angles. Rogelio Sicat’s Moses,Moses , 1968, is about the actual practice of “justice,” with some people being “more equal” than others; Rene O. Villanueva’s May Isang Sundalo (There Was a Soldier), 1982, is an exchange of life stories and beliefs between a soldier and a prostitute; Reuel Molina Aguila’s In Dis Korner (In This Corner), 1978, examines the fate of young boxers in the fight-fixing game; Chris Millado’s Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major), 1985, weaves together stories of farmers, urban workers, socialites, insurgents and their families, the religious, and students struggling and surviving in the post-martial law and pre-Aquino era. Paul Dumol’s historical play Francisco Maniago, 1987, dramatizes Maniago’s realization that one can only be loyal to the king of Spain at the expense of one’s devotion to self, family, and the community. Plays related to the martial law years and its aftereffects, political activism, and human rights violations such as forced disappearances would still continue to be staged, such as Chris Millado’s Desaparecidos (The Disappeared), 1986, Reuel Aguila’s Maliw (Fading), 2009, and Nick Pichay’s Isang Araw sa Karnabal (A Day in the Carnival), 2010.

Plays that comment on ongoing social and cultural concerns have been written. Ricky Lee’s DH: Domestic Helper, 1992, is about domestic helpers; Dennis Marasigan’s Ang Buhay Ay Pelikula (Life Is a Movie), 1994, touches on the local movie industry; Elmer Gatchalian’s Ambon ng Kristal (The Crystal’s Drizzle), 1994, focuses on teenagers and drug addiction; Tumawag kay Libby Manaoag (Call Libby Manaoag), 1998, is about domestic violence; Layeta Bucoy’s Ellas Inocentes, 2007, deals with incest; and Bucoy’s Melanie, 2014, focuses on HIV awareness.

 

Expressionism and Brechtian Styles

The elements of expressionism learned from Brecht’s theater of instruction and Augusto Boal’s theater of the oppressed suited the martial law strictures against the realistic portrayal of oppression and served well such plays as Al Santos’s Mene, Mene Thekel Upharsin (Your Days Are Numbered), 1981, with its scenes of political prisoners and torture, and such musicals as Nukleyar! (Nuclear!), 1983, and Dong de los Reyes’s Bien Aligtad, 1985, in which music, alongside the dialogue, expresses the feelings generated by the surrounding reality. The documentary style is effective in Bonifacio Ilagan’s Pagsambang Bayan (A People’s Veneration), 1977, especially the later versions, where slides and statistics serve as counterpoint to the ongoing mass and its questioning congregation; and in Al Santos’s Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata (May 21 and Other Chapters), 1977, which juxtaposes the person and aspirations of Lapiang Malaya leader Valentin de los Santos with the perceptions of the state, and the street massacre that resulted therefrom.

Plays like Oratoryo ng Bayan (People’s Oratorio), 1983, which is based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the transgressions thereof in Philippine life, and Panata sa Kalayaan (Oath to Freedom), 1987, which focuses on the freedom lost and won in recent times, combine chanting, singing, monologues, documentary and expressionist theater, bodabil, forum theater, and folk forms like carnivals and games to express the multifaceted reality of the Philippine present.

Elements of absurdist theater have surfaced in such works as Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), 1968, where loving is a crime and eye-gouging a form of kindness because blindness is an asset for beggars. In Al Santos’s Ang Sistema ni Propesor Tuko (Professor Gecko’s Way), 1980, the absurdity of an underpaid and overworked teacher’s situation generates equally absurd teaching practices and students. In Joshua Lim So’s Joe Cool: Aplikante (Joe Cool: Applicant), 2012, the application process is presented in a rather strange way to demonstrate the struggles of a man to secure a job.

The contemporary Filipino playwright has obviously learned well from his American texts and teachers, and has successfully synthesized this learning with that from other teachers and with his own Philippine and Asian dramatic heritage. It is not only a predilection for performance that has made this possible. It is also the press of circumstance, the situation of struggle, the onus of oppression, all of which demand a public expression for the community. And theater provides the very best possible venue for such an expression. As theater and film actor-director Laurice Guillen told other directors at an international conference, modern theater in the Philippines does not follow trends or evolve styles for artistic reasons alone. Theater is a need and an urgency, not a luxury nor mere entertainment. It is a part of life. It becomes art because of the artists in it, but it is urgency first. And it was this urgency that took the theater in English from the classrooms and legitimate stages back home to the community.

Although the theater of modern times, with its American influence, makes use of the concepts, structures, philosophies, and styles of Western theater, it is at its base still a theater born in and serving the community. The community may be a small village or town or, in many cases, it could be a bigger cultural or political community, a region, and even the nation.

Since there are very few local schools, degrees, or courses for playwriting and stagecraft, and since local theater groups and institutions like the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) offer only workshops and apprenticeships, purposive training for the theater is still obtained mainly in the United States and in England, and occasionally in Europe. Only very recently have there been workshops on how to write a komedya or a sarsuwela for the modern audience, but there are usually courses and workshops on the structure of the tragedy, or the three-act play. Only in recent years has there been contact with Japanese, Chinese, and Indonesian theater, or with Brechtian theater in Germany and mime in France. The contemporary theater scene is enriched by a synthesis of all the traditions that have entered and influenced Philippine culture. The indigenous and Hispanic theater is seen not only as revived and revitalized but also as recreated for the modern stage as seen in new sarsuwela like Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907), 1982; new komedya like Max Allanigue’s Prinsipe Rodante (Prince Rodante), 1962; contemporary panunuluyan and sinakulo; and dance drama like Al Santos, Rody Vera, and Denisa Reyes’s Diablos (Demons), 1989, Agnes Locsin’s Hinilawod (Tales from the Mouth of the Halawod River), 1992, and Al Santos, Joey Ayala, and Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress), 1992. Puppet theater, children’s theater, mime, masks, and Brecht in translation and adaptation prove the presence as well of various Asian and European theater influences.

Productions are now rarely crafted in the vein or structures of komedya and sarsuwela; instead, they use the structures and conventions found in Western forms such as one-act or two-act plays, musicals, or sung-through musicals. However, theater groups occasionally still stage these classic forms with updated staging or adaptations to allow contemporary audiences to relate to the material as in the komedya Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1994, directed by Jonas Sebastian that incorporate modern dances such as cha-cha and boogie and music such as rap, and Gantimpala Theater’s annual staging of Florante at Laura as a komedya using choreography sourced from different Philippine areas like San Dionisio, Parañaque; Nabuan, Isabela; and Batanes.

Tanghalang Pilipino has revived existing sarsuwela such as Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1987; Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1989; Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1994; and Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1995. New sarsuwela include Mario O’Hara’s Palasyo ni Valetin (Valentin’s Palace), music by Minda Azarcon, staged by PETA in 1998; George de Jesus’s Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom), music by Jesse Lucas, staged by Tanghalang Pilipino in 2000; Bienvenido Lumbera’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), music by Lucien Letaba, staged by DUP in 2002; Melba Padilla Maggay’s Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (Nation: Just One Foot Left ), music by Lucio San Pedro, staged by Institute for Studies in Asian Church and Culture in 2002; Alejandro Roces’s Something to Crow About, staged in Manila in 2006 and in New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco in 2007; Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), music by Joy Marfil, staged by DUP in 2007; and Bonifacio Ilagan’s Ang Señorita at ang Hukbo (The Lady and the Soldier), music by Lucien Letaba, 2008.

Newer stagings of the sinakulo include Martir sa Golgota (Martyr at Golgotha) in Manila by Tanghalang Santa Ana since 1989; and Ang Tagapagligtas (The Savior) in Morong, Rizal, by Pangkalinangang Kilusan ng mga Taga-Morong since 1993. In Quezon City, Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas has staged Papet Pasyon (The Passion of Jesus Christ in Puppetry), the only children’s puppet sinakulo in the country, since 1985.

 

Filipino Theater Artists in the United States

The influence of Anglo-American theater among Filipino artists reaches a sort of ironic reversal when considering the diaspora of Filipinos to the United States. For with this exodus, notably during the martial law years, Filipino theater artists, some of whom had been part of or had been trained by PETA, brought their theater experiences from the Philippines and established Filipino-American theater groups in the United States.

Ma-Yi Theater Company was formed in New York in 1989, with Chito Jao Garces as its founding artistic director, followed by Ralph Peña since 1995. While it has staged Ralph Peña’s Flipzoids, which was about the immigration experiences of Filipino-Americans, and Lonnie Carter’s The Romance of Magno Rubio, which was based on a short story by Carlos Bulosan, the group eventually expanded into an Asian-American theater group in 1998.

In San Francisco, Teatro ng Tanan was established in 1988 by a group of immigrant Filipino theater artists facilitated by Chris Millado. It produced original plays focusing on immigrant experiences and had outreach performances for Filipino World War II veterans. The group was active until 2001. Also in San Francisco, Al Manalo, starting in 1998, reformulated the programming of Bindlestiff Studio, an arts space and theater venue, to nurture and celebrate Filipino-American performing artists and works. Bindlestiff Studio has produced original plays, music festivals, stand-up and sketch comedy shows, dance, visual and video arts created by Filipino-Americans.

In Chicago, CIRCA Pintig theater group was founded in 1991 initially as the Pintig Cultural Group. Its inaugural production was America Is in the Heart, based on the novel by Carlos Bulosan. The Center for Immigrant Resources and Community Arts (CIRCA) became one entity with Pintig in 2006. The new group has staged plays by Filipino and Filipino-American playwrights such as Bells of Balangiga, Nanay Isog and Her Children (Mother Isog and Her Children), Sky Legends, Dreamweavers, and Allos: The Story of Carlos Bulosan.

In Los Angeles, San Dionisio sa America was established in the late 1990s by families originally from San Dionisio, Parañaque City, and they brought to the United States an older theater form: sarsuwela productions in Filipino. This group has staged Ang Kambal ng Valencia (The Twins of Valencia), 2002; Hermano de la Paz, 2004; Nerissa at Bolivar (Nerrisa and Bolivar), 2006; and Mike Llamas’s Esperanza at Caridad (Esperanza and Caridad), 2008, and Mga Prinsesa ng Cordova (Princesses of Cordova), 2010.

With exposure to American forms and ways of doing theater, Filipino-Americans, whether immigrants or natural-born, are able to adapt and adjust quickly to the US theater industry. Notable Filipino-American theater artists include Jose Llana and Paolo Montalban, both of whom have played lead roles on Broadway; set designers Loy Arcenas and Clint Ramos, both of whom have won awards for their design work off-Broadway; and playwright Jessica Hagedorn, whose plays have been staged in New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco.

 

Conclusion

The American influence is still undoubtedly the most strongly felt in Philippine theater, not only in the training of playwrights and theater artists but also in the management of theaters and theater groups, the structure and presentation of plays, and the idea of professional theater. Even when playwrights like Tony Perez, Bienvenido Noriega Jr, Reuel Aguila, Malou Jacob, Rody Vera, Nick Pichay, Floy Quintos, Liza Magtoto, and Layeta Bucoy write plays solidly founded on Philippine experience and ethos, the European and American influence of their education, reading, and play viewing is visible, and this is usually for the good.

Certainly, there are plays shaped by Philippine social forces, artistic forms, historical perspective, community traditions, and values, such as Paul Dumol’s Francisco Maniago; Domingo Landicho’s Dupluhang Bayan (People’s Poetic Joust), 1975; Malou Jacob’s Anatomiya ng Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption), 1992; Layeta Bucoy’s Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan (Doc Resureccion: Will Heal the Nation), 2009, and Walang Kukurap (Let No One Blink), 2012. But it would be almost impossible to distinguish the native impulse from the shaping, given that the playwright’s art is shaped by one’s education and American bias.

The American influence on Philippine theater, therefore, is found in the tradition that grew out of the educational system, which, with its English language, textbooks, and training, produced certain preferences and orientation; the theater experience acquired through training in the United States and, to a lesser extent, in England, thanks not only to available scholarships but also to the choice and predilection of the trainees; the theater exposure acquired through films, videos, workshops, conferences, libraries, visiting experts, and the mass media; the models created by all these factors; and the continuing consciousness bred by all these, together with the colonial experience. It is an influence that, at worst, reflects the colonial cast of mind, in which the foreign is seen as always superior and preferable to the homegrown. But at best, it is enriching, serving as the avenue for entry into Philippine theater of the tried and the proven, the new, the experimental, the alternative, as well as for experiencing other ways of thinking and discourse, other cultures, and other theaters that, as in the beginning, merge with and/or transform traditional theater.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Walter Ang, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson
