Sections

Theater Groups
Education and Training
Venues and Spaces
Scholarship
Theater Forms
Conclusion
Sources

Historical Background

On 4 Jul 1946, the Philippines declared its independence from the Americans. Despite the formal declaration, however, foreign control persisted. From being a colony, the Philippines became a neocolony.

The Philippines’s status as a neocolony was primarily defined by the economic and military treaties it was forced to forge with the United States (US). The Philippine Trade Act of 1946, also known as the Bell Trade Act, reflected the lopsided tariff agreements in favor of the United States. When the Bell Trade Act was severely criticized by Filipino nationalists, the Laurel-Langley Agreement of 1955 was passed. This new agreement removed some of the provisions that give preferentiality for the former colonizer, but it still guaranteed equal opportunities for US and Filipino business interests in all areas of the Philippine economy (Schirmer and Shalom 1987, 87-88, 95). Moreover, the Military Bases Agreement of 1947 provided the United States with extensive military facilities in many parts of the Philippines for a period of 99 years. Unlike similar agreements for US military bases in other countries, the treaty placed no restrictions on the use of the bases, including the types of weapons that could be stored in these facilities (Ibid., 96-97).

The Philippines became a neocolony of the United States not only politically and economically but ideologically as well. The American educational system continued to function as the most important bearer of American ideology. The public educational system under American colonial rule taught Filipinos to accept the Americans as benefactors, to forget their struggles for freedom, and to help pacify domestic opposition to US policy in the Philippines (Schirmer and Shalom 1987, 45). The curriculum taught Filipinos to trust in its relations with foreigners and to be uncritical about foreign economic control. After the war, the educational system, which remained Western and pro-American, produced a generation of young educated Filipinos who were even more receptive to the American way of life and its accompanying individualistic, competitive, and consumerist attitudes. Much of the success of the educational system in carrying out its function as a strategy of colonization is rooted in the use of English as the medium of instruction and learning. The use of English to teach and to learn “became the wedge that separated the Filipinos from their past and later was to separate educated Filipinos from the masses of their countrymen” (Constantino 1966, 45).

The educational system implemented in the country was supplemented by educational exchange programs supported by Fulbright, Rockefeller, and Ford. These programs were supposed to provide venues for the exchange of cultural influences. However, the one-way cultural transmission that actually happened only intensified the Americanization of Filipinos, especially of the educated class. Recipients of these programs, mostly artists, writers, and academicians, were given grants to stay in the United States to study, lecture, observe, and immerse themselves in the American culture. Upon their return to the Philippines, they became effective carriers of foreign ideas that spread throughout Philippine academic institutions and other domains of Philippine society (Lumbera 1997, 180). Also important were the visits to the Philippines of American professors and artists who would influence the direction of Philippine arts and culture (Legasto 2008, 76).

Developments in radio, television, and film would have a great impact on theater since these forms of mass media were some of the primary channels through which Western culture entered the Philippines. Radio stations aired the latest American pop songs, while television showed canned shows from the United States, including comedies, dramas, horror shows, action dramas, and variety shows. While the film industry tried to come up with original Filipino cinema, it was inundated by well-funded commercial films from Hollywood, including American melodramas, comedies, actions films (cowboy, secret agent, martial arts), and horror thrillers as well as European soft-core sex films and Italian cowboy movies. In order to compete with these imported films, some local movies produced local versions of these foreign genres.

The political, economic, educational, and cultural opportunities benefited only a small sector of Philippine society. As a result, the economic gap between the rich and the poor widened. Toward the mid-1960s, the living conditions of the great majority of Filipinos were getting worse. The US influence on Philippine politics and economy continued, its military privileges protected and strengthened. Opposition against the government and the status quo grew louder and stronger. Because of worsening poverty, workers in the urban areas and peasants in the regions became more radical. In various schools and universities, militant student movement emerged. Mass rallies and demonstrations were met with violence. The so-called First Quarter Storm took place, marked by the following historic events: the Battle of Mendiola in Jan 1970; the people’s congresses at Plaza Miranda, Congress, and the US Embassy, Feb-Mar 1971; and the Diliman Commune and University of the Philippines (UP) Barricades in Feb 1971 (Legasto 2004, 172-73). These changing conditions were reflected in the changes that happened in Philippine theater.

 

Theater Groups

School-Based Theater Groups. One of the main channels through which American ideology and way of life continued to be passed on to generations of young Filipino was the staging of foreign plays in English. Plays written by American or European playwrights that have so-called “artistic merits” based on Western standards dominated the theater scene after World War II. The school setting remained to be the center of legitimate theater productions in English. After the war, other school-based theater groups followed the lead of the Ateneo Players Guild established in 1921: the UP Dramatic Club, 1930, and the Far Eastern University (FEU) Theater Guild, 1934. Some of the theater figures who established theater groups after the war were part of these earlier groups. For example, Onofre Pagsanghan, who established Dulaang Sibol was part of the Ateneo Players’ Guild, while Severino Montano, who organized the Arena Theater, was a member of the UP Dramatic Club. Just like their predecessors, most of the postwar theater groups mounted original foreign plays in English or English translations of foreign plays.

The Paulinian Players Guild was founded in the early 1950s at the St. Paul College in Manila. Some of the plays it mounted were Edmond Rostand’s L’Aiglon, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II’s The Sound of Music and Carousel, and Alan Jay Lerner’s Brigadoon. The Aquinas Dramatic Guild also started in the early 1950s at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) and was an offshoot of a series of radio plays in 1952. It was initially called the Aquinas Radio Dramatic Guild, which later became the Aquinas Dramatic Guild when it staged Antonio Molina’s His Eminence, an English translation of Jose Maria Peman’s El Gran Cardenal. The group founded by Onofre Pagsanghan at the Ateneo de Manila High School was first organized in 1956 as the Ateneo de Manila High School’s Dramatic Society. In 1966, it became the Dulaang Sibol. The earlier group regularly produced Shakespearean plays such as Macbeth and Hamlet, and even Rostand’s Cyrano de Bergerac. Other school-based theater groups that mounted similar repertoire included the Arellano University Dramatic Club, FEU’s Drama Department, the Philippine Women’s University Experimental Theater, the Manuel L. Quezon Dramatic Club, and the University of the East Dramatic Guild.

Aside from these theater groups, school-based organizations such as fraternities and sororities, as well as student religious groups, would often stage plays in English to celebrate important occasions, to raise funds for the organization, or to use theater to project an image for the organization. In UP, fraternities and sororities that ventured into theater production were the Tau Alpha, Upsilon Sigma Phi, Sigma Rho, Aztecs Confraternity, Phi Kappa Mu, Upsilon Sigma Phi, Alpha Phi Omega, Beta Sigma, Alpha Phi Beta, Sigma Alpha Sorority, Delta Lambda Sigma Sorority, Sigma Delta Phi Sorority, Sigma Beta Sorority, Phi Delta Alpha Sorority, Kappa Phi Omega Sorority, and Sigma Delta Phi. The University of the Philippines Student Catholic Action established Dramatic Guild, which later became Dulaang Delaney, and the University of the Philippines Christian Youth Movement (UPCYM) organized the UPCYM Playhouse to mount plays in English by foreign and Filipino playwrights (Carbayas 1999, 64-73).

Even in the regions, school-based theater groups that were established after World War II produced mostly Western plays. El Teatro, which was founded in 1959, and The Genesius, established in 1965, both based at the University of St. La Salle in Bacolod, mounted foreign plays and musicals. Portal Players, founded in 1966 as the Silliman University (SU) theater group, mounted Western classics, continuing the tradition of the earlier group, the Department of Language and Dramatic Arts of SU, established in 1961. USA Little Theater, organized in 1965 at the University of San Agustin in Iloilo, also presented mostly Western materials, and later, works by Filipino playwrights in English such as Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero.

There were school-based theater groups that stood out during the period since they focused not on foreign plays in English but developed original Filipino plays in English. Their productions may be considered important transitions from legitimate theater in English toward the development of an original Filipino theater. The Arena Theater of the Philippines was founded by Severino Montano in 1953 at the Philippine Normal College (or PNC, now Philippine Normal University). The Arena Theater of the Philippines did not limit its performances within the PNC community. It fielded teacher-actors throughout the country to bring modern drama to other schools and communities. Montano also introduced the arena style of production that enabled the group to perform in various towns and barrios all over the Philippines. The group developed 4 full-length plays and 18 one-act plays in English mostly written by Montano.

The UP Mobile Theater was established in 1962 by Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero in UP. The group performed plays by Guerrero, which while mostly written in the 1930s and 1940s, became even more popular after the war. Among these were Wanted: A Chaperone, Half an Hour in a Convent, and Three Rats. The group also aimed at bringing theater to different regions of the country. Meanwhile, another theater organization, the Chamber Theater Group, was organized in FEU in 1964 by Nick Agudo. The group developed plays based on literary works by Filipino authors in English.

Since the plays of Montano and Guerrero were staged in many communities in various regions in the Philippines and dealt with Philippine realities, a number of their plays were eventually translated or adapted to other Philippine languages. These translations and adaptations prompted the entry of the national language and other major Philippine languages into the domain of legitimate theater. Onofre Pagsanghan would transform the Ateneo Dramatics Society, which regularly produced Shakespearean plays, into Dulaang Sibol, which adapted foreign plays. While the productions still worked within the framework of the foreign plays, they nevertheless consciously explored the use of the Filipino language in legitimate theater in the case of the translations, and adjusted the foreign materials to bring them closer to the Filipino audience in the case of the adaptations. In 1967, Dulaang Sibol would initiate the Paligsahang Pandulaan. This playwriting competition encouraged the Ateneo High School students to write and direct original Filipino plays. It produced theater luminaries such as Paul Dumol and Tony Perez.

Non-School-Based Theater Groups. Aside from the school-based theater groups, there were other groups whose members came from various professions and persuasions, and catered to different communities and sectors of society. Initially, these non-school-based theater groups offered almost the same repertoire of English plays by foreign playwrights or written by Filipinos. During the period of the First Quarter Storm, however, groups that were linked with the nationalist movement emerged and developed plays that were collectively called political, activist, or revolutionary theater.

After the war, the Barangay Theater Guild, founded in 1939 by Lamberto and Daisy Avellana, continued to present classic and modern English plays. Other non-school-based theater groups were the Community Players, Tambuli Playhouse, and Penmouth Playhouse. There was also the Manila Theater Guild established in 1951, which was based at the Army-Navy Club in Manila. Its members were Filipinos, but its directors and actors often came from the American and British communities in Manila. The group had an average of six productions a year of Spanish, British, and American plays, presented mostly to the foreign community in Manila.

In 1967, even when there was a movement toward the Filipinization of theater as a response to the call of the times, Repertory Philippines (Rep) was established by Zeneida Amador. It aimed to make theater a social habit for Filipinos by presenting regular theater seasons with foreign plays, mostly from Broadway and London’s West End. Its productions were patronized primarily by the elite sector of the society.

In the mid-1960s, several theater groups were formed which faced the challenges of the times by creating original Filipino plays. The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) was founded in 1967 by Cecile Guidote to concretize her “Prospectus for the National Theater of the Philippines.” Initially, its policy was to present plays depicting Filipino culture, as well as Filipino translations of foreign plays. The group later developed the concept of “aesthetics of poverty,” and later on, its writers’ pool created committed plays—those that deal with the examination of relevant sociopolitical issues.

Another group that focused on raising the social consciousness of the Filipino audience through original Filipino theater was the UP Repertory Company, founded by Behn Cervantes in 1968. Most of its significant productions in Filipino would be staged after the declaration of martial law. The group would also develop a theater form, the tula-dula (poem-play) which is appropriate to the limitations as well as to the purpose of mounting plays in the streets.

In the regions, there was Kolambugan Dance Theater, founded in Lanao in 1970. It sought to unite Muslims and Christians through theater. All of its productions were dance dramas written and conceptualized by the group’s founder, Fr Rodulfo Galenzoga. Its most successful play is Maranatha (Make Haste, Lord), which toured all over the country and performed 135 times.

During the First Quarter Storm, theater groups that were linked with the broader nationalist movement were formed. From the productions of these theater groups, activist theater emerged. Militant student groups, such as Kabataang Makabayan and Samahan ng Demokratikong Kabataan (SDK), organized cultural groups that used theater as a political tool. Tanghalang Bayan, the cultural arm of the Katipunan ng mga Kabataang Demokratiko, sought to promote a national, mass, and scientific culture through plays like Kalbaryo ni Juan de la Cruz (The Calvary of Juan de la Cruz), Hukumang Bayan (People’s Court), Rebolusyon (Revolution), and Kamatayan ng Isang Aktibista (Death of an Activist), staged between 1969 and 1971.

The establishment of Gintong Silahis ca. 1970 was initiated by the SDK. Under the leadership of Behn Cervantes, its artistic director, the productions of the group were political in orientation. It staged Alay kay Ka Amado (In Honor of Ka Amado), 1971, and Barikada (Barricades), 1971. The group’s plays often employed a koro (chorus) since there were no microphones as they performed not only in schools and urban poor communities but also during rallies. The group also held discussions with the audience regarding the issues presented in the play.

Panday-Sining was founded by Bonifacio Ilagan in 1971. Its theater repertoire includes agitprop skits, mobile street theater, choreographed music and poetry, vignettes, and one-act plays. Some of its most known plays are Masaker sa Araw ng Paggawa (Labor Day Massacre), 1970; Hukumang Tuwad (Kangaroo Court), 1971; Welga! Welga! (Strike! Strike!), 1972; and Sinipi sa Buhay (Drawn from Life). Its artistic director Leo Rimando employed various theater forms and styles such as realism, expressionism, and absurdism, and drew inspiration from the proletarian Chinese Theater of Jiang Jing and from Bertolt Brecht.

The productions of these politically motivated theater groups represent a break from the plays produced in the 1940s up to the first half of 1960s. Theater was treated not only as a pedagogical tool for language teaching and as a form of entertainment but also as a means of raising social awareness and motivating people to transform society.

 

Education and Training

During the first decades of American colonial rule, theater was primarily used to reinforce the teaching of English through dialogues, skits, and short plays. As a result, the classroom became the default venue for theater activities, with the English teachers serving as “trainers.” After the war, theater moved out of the classrooms and into school stages and performed to larger audiences. More schools instituted drama subjects and established drama clubs or theater groups. English teachers and professors were usually assigned to teach drama, advise drama clubs, and direct plays on special occasions such as foundation days, national holidays, and feast days, thus continuing the dominance of the English language in theater.

Later, theater began to be seen not just as a complementary activity to the teaching of the English language but already as an art and a discipline in itself. Universities developed more drama subjects that later on became the foundation for a complete academic program in theater. Usually, the theater arts department emerged from the English department of colleges and universities. In 1959, the UP Department of Speech and Drama (DSD) was founded. By the 1960s, DSD included elementary stagecraft, playwriting, acting, and art history of the theater in its roster of courses. Eventually, when DSD became the Department of Speech Communication and Theater Arts in 1977, these courses were finally recognized as independent of theater courses.

Similarly, in 1965, the Department of Language and Dramatic Arts of Silliman University was established, which later gave birth to a separate Department of Speech and Drama in 1967. The latter offered majors and minors in English, and speech and drama. The Department focused on training students on the various aspects of theater production, instituting new subjects like acting, directing, and design. In 1969, it was renamed the Speech and Theater Arts Department, which offered a bachelor of arts degree in speech and theater.

Theater education and training were also obtained from the theater groups through actual productions, workshops, and apprenticeship. Training was principally conducted by theater directors who were also the groups’ founders and artistic leaders. The first group of influential theater directors were Americans or American-educated artists. Before and immediately after the war, Fr Henry Lee Irwin, SJ, was active in Ateneo de Manila, while Jean Garrott Edades was in UP. In the postwar era up to the 1970s, Severino Montano directed for the Arena Theater of the Philippine Normal University; Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero for the UP Dramatics Club and UP Mobile Theater; Fr James Reuter SJ for the Paulinian Players of St. Paul College; Lamberto V. Avellana and Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana for the Barangay Theater Guild; Sarah Joaquin, Nick Agudo, and Rustica Carpio for the FEU Theater Guild; Onofre Pagsanghan for the Ateneo Dramatics Guild and Dulaang Sibol; Frank Flores for Portal Players; Zeneida Amador for Repertory Philippines; Cecile Guidote for PETA; Behn Cervantes for the UP Repertory Company; and Rolando S.Tinio for Teatro Pilipino.

The training provided by some of these directors was not confined within the groups they established and the school communities they served. Various schools and communities all over the Philippines benefited from the performances and training programs by groups such as Montano’s Arena Theater of the Philippines and Guerrero’s UP Mobile Theater, which also conducted training-workshops to increase the number of theater directors, playwrights, actors, production staff, and even theater groups. Six years after Arena Theater was founded in 1953, the group expanded into 45 independent branches mostly in Pangasinan, Negros Occidental, and Cebu. The University of San Agustin’s USA Little Theater, formally established in 1965, traced its beginnings from a seminar Guerrero conducted among theater enthusiasts in the USA.

Most of these directors and artistic leaders introduced Western theatrical traditions, aesthetics, and practices, while also adapting them to local contexts. The history of Chamber Theater Group represents one concrete example by which foreign theater aesthetics and practices were transported to and popularized in the Philippines. The group was formed in 1964 after theater artist Nick Agudo completed his observation and work at Northwestern University with Robert Breen who developed the concept of chamber theater—a theater form where a literary work is adapted to the stage using a maximal amount of the work’s original text. Agudo experimented with short stories in his classroom laboratory productions. From his first batch of students in oral interpretation, the Chamber Theater Group was organized. In 1966, the American Embassy invited the group to popularize chamber theater in the Visayas and Mindanao using Filipino short stories as material. It also performed for public schools in Manila, and later the organization of public schools held an annual contest of chamber theater productions using the scripts developed by the Chamber Theater Group. While the experience of the Chamber Theater Group simulated the flow of foreign influences from its origin and into many parts of the Philippines, the group should also be credited for utilizing the works of Filipino authors for its theater productions.

Activist theater during the First Quarter Storm demanded a change in the training of all those involved in the production of plays. There was emphasis on politicization. Artists and staff members were expected to have knowledge of the various aspects of production but equally important was their knowledge of the prevailing political and social issues and realities. Lectures and discussions were conducted to equip theater artists and practitioners with the correct political and aesthetic orientation.

There were also changes in the practices of producing plays. Plays were written individually, but more often, collectively. The spirit of democratization was carried out even in the process of conceptualizing and deciding on the final form of the play through collective decision making by the director, playwright, performers, and production people. The collective spirit was extended even to the audience. Primarily, plays were written in the national language and other Philippine languages. Also, the barriers set down between the performers and the audience by the proscenium stage were dismantled. This was done by employing staging techniques that allowed performers to come from or move around the audience’s area or by using theater styles that required the audience not only to view the performance but also to actively participate in its completion. In a way, theater artists and audiences were being educated and trained on a new kind of theater that is democratic and participatory.

 

Venues and Spaces

Since schools and universities became the center of theater activities after World War II, most of the theater productions were mounted on large classrooms, dining halls, dormitories, assembly halls, school auditoriums, gymnasiums, and other spaces within the campuses. As many of these spaces were not really meant for staging plays, members of theater groups mustered their creativity and resourcefulness to improvise theater equipment and other staging requirements. The impressive productions of some school-based groups and the vision of school administrators to make their institution the center of theater and cultural activities in their community, city, or region eventually led to greater support from the school administration, particularly for the construction of theater venues. The FEU Auditorium was completed in 1949 primarily for the theater productions of the FEU Drama Guild. Because the Metropolitan Theater and other performing venues in Manila were damaged by the war, the 1,020-seater FEU Auditorium became the best venue for the performing arts in Manila. The auditorium is known for its centralized air-conditioning system and revolving stage, which were uncommon features in theaters during that time. The long theater tradition at St. Paul College of Manila along Herran St (now Pedro Gil), led to the construction of the Fleur-de-Lis Auditorium, which was formally inaugurated in 1957. Because of the productions of such teacher-directors as Fr James Reuter and Daisy Avellana, the Fleur-de-Lis came to be known as “the Broadway of Herran” (Dalisay 2007). These newly constructed auditoriums ensured steadier and sustained theater productions.

There was also the Pavillion of the Army Navy Club reserved for the productions of the Manila Theater Guild. Auditoriums of foreign cultural centers like Thomas Jefferson Cultural Center, Goethe Institut, the British Council, and the Centro Cultural de España, and the various open-air stages like the Luneta, Paco Park, and Puerta Real also became performance venues. In 1969, the Cultural Center of the Philippines was built. It houses three theaters with different seating capacities: Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo (formerly Main Theater), seats 1,800, built for major theater productions, operas, and symphony concerts; Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino (formerly Little Theater), seats 420, meant for more intimate plays; and Tanghalang Huseng Batute (formerly Bulwagang Gantimpala), seats 240, suited for more experimental and minimalist theater forms and types.

Despite these theater venues and spaces, there was still a lack of performance sites to accommodate the various large and small-scale productions of different theater groups. The shortage of theater structures, especially in the regions, challenged the imagination of theater artists to explore more novel spaces and develop new theater forms and types to adapt to the limited facilities and resources, as well as to the aims of their performances. Montano’s Arena Theater, for example, used the theater-in-the-round concept, wherein the audience surrounds the performance area. When the group brought its productions to various towns and barrios all over the Philippines, it explored arenas such as rice and cane fields, plazas, markets, cockpits, and other open spaces to mount its plays. A few years after, Guerrero would also develop his version of teatro rodante or portable theater through his UP Mobile Theater.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, many activist theater groups mounted their plays in various open spaces—streets, factories, plazas, basketball courts, school lobbies, facades of government buildings, marketplaces, tops of trucks, and strike areas. Since the plays were mounted wherever and whenever, there was a need for such performance to use minimal props and inexpensive and improvised sets and costumes. Theater groups used choruses to project their dialogues or to represent certain objects or images. The use of the streets and other open spaces as theater venues was not so much because of the absence of a performance space but to bring the issues and the message immediately to a wider audience and to veer away from the exclusivity that characterized much of theater after the war until the mid-1960s.

 

Scholarship

Scholarship produced during this period dealt with Philippine theater history, forms, and artists. Expectedly, colleges and universities with academic programs in literature, languages, humanities, and the arts produced a number of scholarly works on theater in the form of theses which served as final requirements to obtain graduate degrees. These research outputs included Ester Francisco Deniga’s “Ang mga Kuwento at Dula ni Severino Reyes sa Larangan ng Panitikang Pilipino” (Stories and Plays of Severino Reyes in the Field of Philippine Literature), 1948; Federico B. Sebastian’s “Pahapyaw na Kasaysayan ng Dulang Tagalog” (A Historical Survey of Tagalog Theater), 1950; Asuncion Siao’s “A Study of the Moro-Moro Plays of Catanduanes,” 1952; Leonila R. Llenos’s “A Study and Evaluation of the Works in Drama of Florentino E. Borromeo,” 1954; Iluminada Magno’s “A Critical Study of the Zarzuela in Pangasinan of Catalino Palisoc,” 1954; Irene T. Ordoña’s “An Evaluative Study of the Dramas of Piux Kabahar,” 1956; Lilia M. Cinco’s “The Significance of Buenaventura Rodriguez in the History of Sugbuanon Drama,” 1959; Maria Lilia F. Realubit’s “A Study of Popular Drama in Bikol,” 1961; and Ely Javillonar’s “The Significance of Mariano Proceso Pabalan in Capampangan Dramatic Literature,” 1961.

Published works on theater included reference books, anthologies, and scholarly works. Among these were Jean Edades’s Short Plays of the Philippines, 1950; Federico Sebastian’s Ang Dulang Tagalog (The Tagalog Theater), 1951; Jean Edades and Carolyn Fosdick’s Drama of the East and West, 1956; Juan S. Aguas’s Juan Crisostomo Soto and Pampangan Drama, 1963; Alejandrino Hufana’s Mena Pecson Crisologo and Iloko Drama, 1963; Raymundo Bañas’s Pilipino Music and Theater, 1969; Isagani Cruz’s edited work A Short History of Theater in the Philippines, 1971; and Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s The Seditious Tagalog Playwrights: Early American Occupation, 1972. Research outputs, published works, and the collections of a number of significant plays especially of the prewar American period provided a useful typology and identification of important characteristics of the various theater forms and types, gave some annotations on texts and performances, and introduced works, artists, organizations, institutions, and structures of a number of theater traditions in the country.

Seen in the light of the theater productions during this period which focused on foreign plays in English, these research outputs that collectively represent a search for Filipino roots may be taken as a counter-discourse. The scholars’ emphasis on researching the beginnings of Filipino theater may be attributed to influential academic figures such as Leopoldo Yabes, who encouraged graduate students to look for the foundations of Filipino culture. Some theater critics, however, noted the weak points of the majority of theater scholarship produced during the period. The approach was textual and formalist, and the critical framework was still Western, which at times resulted in an unenthusiastic reading of the plays written by Filipinos (Chua 2012, 92-97; Melendrez-Cruz 1994, 5-6). Despite these limitations, these research outputs and publications provided the groundwork for a more nationalist theater scholarship, in both subject matter and critical framework, starting in the 1970s and up to the present.

 

Theater Forms

Theater forms that prevailed during the period from 1946 to 1972 were (1) the traditional theater forms such as the komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and bodabil; (2) the foreign plays in English such as the Greek classics, Shakespearean plays, and modern plays; (3) translations and adaptations of foreign plays; and (4) original Filipino plays in English and in Filipino.

But the period was dominated by foreign plays in English that included the Greek classics, Shakespearean plays, and modern American and European plays. They were primarily performed in schools, universities, and other “legitimate” or formal theaters. Soon, Filipino playwrights and directors began translating and adapting foreign plays in English into Filipino and other Philippine languages to make them more accessible and meaningful to the Filipino audience. Theater artists pushed forward by creating original Filipino plays in English, and eventually in Filipino, that focused on the personal and collective experiences and realities of the Filipino people. These original Filipino plays used forms and styles of both realist and nonrealist theater.

Traditional Theater Forms. Theater forms that started and developed during the Spanish period and the first decades of the American period, such as komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and bodabil, survived even after World War II. They were still performed by theater groups, mostly in the provinces, in areas where community support continued and where people saw the performance of such traditional forms as a duty and a devotion. In many places, however, these forms disappeared. Industrialization turned farmers into workers who could no longer participate in the staging, the elite discontinued its support, education taught younger generations to look down on these traditions, and mass media lured the audience into its fold.

Significant were the first attempts to modify the form and alter the content of the komedya to make it more relevant to contemporary audiences. One of the first attempts to modernize the komedya was Principe Rodante (Prince Rodante), written by lawyer Maximino Allanigue Jr. The play still presented the conflict between the Christians and Moors. But as in Francisco Baltazar’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), it blurred the character stereotypes based on race and religion of the traditional komedya. It was first staged by the Komedya ng San Dionisio in Parañaque in May 1962 under the direction of Dr Felicidad Mendoza. Later Dr Mendoza established the Kudyapi Community Theater League, which staged her own komedya scripts, like Prinsesa Perlita (Princess Perlita), an adaptation of Jose Corazon de Jesus’s classic poem “Sa Dakong Silangan” (Toward the East). The group had a children’s arm, the Kudyapi Dulaang Munti ng Comedia, which staged Prinsesa Manok at Prinsipe Lawin (Princess Chicken and Prince Hawk) and Sa Paningin ng Puso ng mga Haring Mago (A View from the Heart of the King Magi).

The traditional sinakulo, a play that dramatizes the history of salvation, from the creation of the world to the passion, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ, mounted during Lenten season, especially during the Holy Week, continued in the provinces of Rizal, Bulacan, Pampanga, Bataan, Laguna, Pangasinan, Camarines Sur and other Bicol provinces, Iloilo, Negros Occidental, and Leyte (Tiongson 1999c, 4). However, in many other areas, starting in the 1950s, with the gradual decline of the rural economy as a result of urbanization and industrialization, the traditional sinukulo began to decline. In some urban areas, it survived because of the introduction of modern techniques of staging without changing its traditional message (Tiongson 1999c, 3). For example, in Kapitangan, Paombong, Bulacan, the full seven-night sinakulo in the 1950s was shortened. When the play was reworked in 1972, only selected scenes were staged—from the agony in the garden to the crucifixion—from 10:00 am to 12:00 noon on Good Friday (Tiongson as cited in Modelo 1984, 1-2). In some provinces, an element of sensationalism was added, such as the actual crucifixion of penitents in Cutud, San Pedro, San Fernando, Pampanga, since 1963 (Tiongson 1999c, 21). This attracted more local and foreign audiences to watch the play. Since the 1970s, politicized theater artists developed a new type of sinakulo. They appropriated the narrative of Christ, removing its conservative values and fusing it with sectoral concerns or by drawing parallelisms between the life and sufferings of Christ and the majority of the Filipino people (Tiongson 1999c, 3).

There were still playwrights who created original sarsuwela during this period. One was Iluminado Lucente, a well-known Waray poet and playwright, who wrote about 30 plays, most of which were sarsuwela or melodramas interspersed with songs. These included Abugho (Jealousy), 1949; Mga Retrato han Akon Bungto (Pictures of My Hometown) and Usa nga Pinit han Aton Kinabuhi (A Slice of Life), 1952. Another playwright from the region who wrote Pampango sarsuwela even after the war was Jose Gallardo. His best-known play, Crucifijong Pilak (Silver Crucifix), a three-act sarsuwela first staged in 1956, had almost a hundred performances. In Davao, Karl Gaspar wrote a sarsuwela in 1971 titled Ang Ngot-ngot nga Kangit-ngit (The Pain of Darkness). In 1971, PETA staged Halimaw (Monster), libretto by Isagani Cruz, music by Lutgardo Labad Jr, and direction by Felix Padilla Jr, which is considered to be the first modern sarsuwela. Here, elements of folk literature are fused with various theater forms and styles, such as Brechtian theater, theater of the absurd, Broadway musical comedy, and Chinese revolutionary theater, to dramatize metaphorically the state of affairs in the country.

Bodabil or stage show experienced a period of popularity after the war. Several troupes produced bodabil shows at the Clover Theater and Manila Grand Opera House, among others. Famous was Lou Salvador Sr who assembled several bodabil troupes and discovered new bodabil talents such as comedians Chiquito, Cachupoy, and German Moreno, and singers Pepe Pimentel, Diomedes Maturan, and Eddie Peregrina. Famous singers such as Eddie Mesa, Sylvia La Torre, Elizabeth Ramsey, and Pilita Corrales also appeared in stage shows. However, by the late 1960s, the stage show had to compete not only with movies but also with television. To keep up with the competition, the stage show presented burlesque shows, but even these were no match to the bomba films which rose in the 1970s.

Foreign Plays in English. Foreign plays in English that were mounted during this period were Greek classics, Shakespearean plays, and modern American and European plays. These plays primarily entered the Philippine stage through the educational system and, later, through professional and semiprofessional theater initiatives. Foreign professors and theater practitioners who settled in the Philippines, as well as Filipino theater practitioners who studied abroad, were instrumental in popularizing these plays.

Among the Greek classics and other Western classics that were performed were Sophocles’s Oedipus Rex, Moliere’s The Imaginary Invalid and The Physician in Spite of Himself, Henrik Ibsen’s Ghosts, Oscar Wilde’s The Importance of Being Earnest, Anton Chekhov’s The Boor, Luigi Pirandello’s Six Characters in Search of an Author, and Edmond Rostand’s Cyrano de Bergerac and L’Aiglon. Many theater groups mounted plays by William Shakespeare such as Hamlet, Macbeth, The Merchant of Venice, Hamlet, and Julius Caesar. Among the modern American plays that were produced by Filipino theater groups were Daniel Lord’s Everyman, Louisa May Alcott’s Little Women, Eugene O’Neill’s Mourning Becomes Electra and Long Day’s Journey into Night, T.S. Eliot’s Murder in the Cathedral, Maxwell Anderson’s The Bad Seed, Ali Samson Raphaelson’s Accent on Youth, Thornton Wilder’s Our Town and The Happy Journey to the Treton and Camden, Arthur Miller’s All My Sons, Tennessee Williams’s Suddenly Last Summer and Something Unspoken, George Axelrod’s Seven Year Itch, Sydney Kingsley’s Darkness at Noon, and Oscar Hammerstein II and Joshua Logan’s South Pacific. Some of the modern European plays that were mounted on Philippine stage were Maurice Baring’s The Drawback, Bertolt Brecht’s Mother Courage and Her Children, Federico Lorca’s The House of Bernarda Alba and The Blood Wedding, Eugene Ionesco’s The Bald Soprano, Samuel Beckett’s Waiting for Godot, and Joaquin Calvo Sotelo’s The Wall.

Translations and Adaptations. Rolando Tinio introduced major works of Western theater to a wider Filipino audience with his translations such as Laruang Kristal, 1966, a translation of Tennessee Williams’ The Glass Menagerie; Pahimakas sa Isang Ahente, 1966, a translation of Arthur Miller’s Death of a Salesman; Paghihintay kay Godot, 1967, a translation of Samuel Beckett’s Waiting for Godot; and Miss Julie, 1967, a translation of August Strindberg’s work with the same title. Brecht’s plays were presented in their English translations such as Mother Courage and Her Children, 1968, by Repertory Philippines, and The Good Woman of Setzuan, 1970, and in Filipino, 1971, by PETA. Eugene Ionesco’s The Bald Soprano, staged in the early 1960s by the UP Dramatic Club, was adapted and performed by PETA as Ang Tatay Mong Kalbo in 1967.

Most of the foreign plays were not only translated but adapted to bring them closer to the Filipino audience. Onofre Pagsanghan would transform the Ateneo Dramatics Society, which regularly produced Shakespearean plays, into Dulaang Sibol which adapted foreign plays. It produced Wala sa Ating mga Bituin (Not in Our Stars), 1966, an adaptation of J.M. Barrie’s Dear Brutus, and Doon Po sa Amin, 1968, Pagsanghan’s local adaptation of Thornton Wilder’s Our Town.

Some foreign plays were even translated into other Philippine languages. For example, when Reuter established Cathedral Players in 1949 based in Ateneo de Naga, he produced Western plays and also translated and adapted English plays into Bikol such as Everyman, Do Not Lie, Wherever David Goes, All Brides Are Beautiful, and Petty Juan .

Original Filipino Plays in English. After World War II, directors and playwrights who were products of the American educational system and educational exchange programs produced original plays in English. Their plays may be considered the results of their education in language or literature, their studies in the graduate programs in creative writing in the United States, the workshops and conferences they participated in abroad, and the theater experience they acquired from the theater groups they engaged with.

Original Filipino plays in English during this period was dominated by two theater giants: Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero and Severino Montano. They established theater groups that presented mostly their own plays. Guerrero wrote and directed about 100 plays in English. Some of his most popular plays were Wow These Americans, 1946; Perhaps, 1947; Condemned, 1947; Three Rats, 1948; Deep in My Heart, 1951; In Unity, 1953; and Our Strange Ways, 1953. The UP Mobile Theater, which he established in 1962, had more than 2,500 performances in English and in regional language translations, including his earlier plays such as Women Are Extraordinary, 1937; Hate Begins , 1938; Romance in B Minor, 1939; Movie Artists, 1940; Wanted: A Chaperon, 1940; The Forsaken House, 1940; Forever, 1941; Condemned, 1944; and Frustrations, 1944. Severino Montano wrote three one-act plays—namely, Sabina; The Ladies and the Senator, and Parting at Calamba, all first staged in 1953; a full-length play, The Love of Leonor Rivera, 1954; The Foolish Virgins, 1959; and The Naked Woman, 1959. The 200 performances of Arena Theater, which Montano established in 1953, revolved almost entirely on the first four plays.

After Guerrero and Montano, other Filipino playwrights who wrote in English were Jose Flores who penned Flowers for the Dead; C. V. Pedroche, Little Corner of the City; Antonio Bayot, The Finishing Touch, Among the Faithless , Malakas and Maganda, Rigodon, and Rejection ; Estrella Alfon, The Stranger; Nick Joaquin, A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino; Celso Carunungan, Like a Big Brave Man; Alejandro Roces, Of Cocks and Kites; Virginia Moreno, Mariang Makiling, Glass Altars, Straw Patriot, The Onyx Wolf, and Indio Spoliarium; Alberto Florentino, The World Is an Apple, Cavort with Angels, The Dancers, Oli Impan (Holy Infant), and Cadaver; Jesus Peralta, Play the Judas, Scent of Fear, Longer Than Mourning, The Mouth Is an Open Wound, The Sign of the Seagulls, Voices of Laughter, Days of the Clock, Age of Prometheus, and Grave for Blue Flower; Wilfrido Nolledo, Goodbye My Gentle; and Mar Puatu’s Reunion. Works of the following playwrights were also staged: Fidel Sicam’s Seven Years, Julian Dacanay’s Something Filipino, Paulina Bautista’s Quiet Evening, Agustin Ancheta’s A Wife Goes to Politics, Mercedes Marquez’s Tomorrow May Be Kind, Nicolas Nuñez’s The Stepson, Nemia Arroyo’s The Expulsion, Marcelino Agana’s New Yorker in Tondo, and Carlos Sison’s The Affair.

Original Filipino Plays in Filipino and Other Philippine Languages. Original Filipino plays in Filipino and other Philippine languages during this period first emerged in the form of translations and adaptations. The plays in English of Guerrero, Montano, and Florentino were translated to Philippine languages. When Guerrero organized the UP Mobile Theater, his plays were staged in English. But later, as these plays were mounted in different regions in the country, they were translated to various regional languages. Six years after the establishment of Arena Theater in 1953, the group brought Montano’s plays to the provinces, such as Pangasinan, Negros Occidental, and Cebu. In these regional performances, the group’s repertoires were translated into Pangasinan, Ilocano, Hiligaynon, and Cebuano. Florentino’s plays, which depicted the lives of the urban poor, were translated to Filipino and performed by the UP Mobile Theater, PETA, and UP Repertory Company. Moreno’s Straw Patriot, first written in 1967, was translated into Filipino by Wilfredo Pascua Sanchez as Bayaning Huwad. It was the first play staged by PETA at the new theater in Fort Santiago, also in 1967. Moreno’s The Onyx Wolf was staged as part of the inaugural presentations at the CPP Little Theater in 1971.

Not content with translation and adaptation, Filipino theater artists wrote and staged plays originally written in Filipino. Some of the earliest examples during this period are Tirso Antiporda’s Hindi Ko Akalain (I Never Imagined), Florentino Ballecer’s Sundalong Mantika (Sluggard Soldier), Alberto Florentino’s Sayaw ng Bayan (Dance of the People), Julian Balmaseda’s Dahil sa Anak (Because of the Child), Gloria de Guzman’s Sisa, Bonifacio Ilagan’s Ang Buhay Nga Naman (That’s Life, Indeed), and Francisco Rodrigo’s Sa Pula, sa Puti (Bet for the Red, for the White) (Legasto 2008, 105-6).

Original Filipino plays in the national language also emerged from Paligsahang Pandulaan, a playwriting and staging competition for high school students sponsored by Dulaang Sibol and the Kagawaran ng Pilipino of Ateneo de Manila University in 1967. It produced Paul Dumol’s Ang Puting Timamanukin (The White Timamanukin Bird), Tony Perez’s Hoy, Boyet, Tinatawag Ka Na, Hatinggabi Na’y Gising Ka Pa Pala (Hey, Boyet, They’re Calling You, It’s Midnight and You’re Still Awake), Dindo Angeles’s Kandilang Naaagnas (Melting Candle), Guillermo Catindig’s Huling Pagsisisi (Final Regret), and Jose Gadi’s Ang Tinig ng Langit (The Voice of Heaven).

One of the most significant examples of realism in Philippine theater is Rogelio Sicat’s Moses, Moses, 1968, first mounted by Paul Dumol at the college cafeteria of Ateneo de Manila University in 1971. Another example is Malou Jacob’s first play, Timbangan Ay Tagilid (The Weighing Scale Is Aslant), staged by PETA in 1971. In 1972, before the declaration of martial law, PETA again mounted another one of her plays, Aidao, which focuses on the conflict between Christians and Muslims. Other realist plays written in other Philippine languages are Karl Gaspar’s works such as Kinabuhi ug Kamatayon sa Barrio Sudionan (Life and Death in Barrio Sudlonan), 1962, and Ang Kalayo sa Luha (Fire of Tears), 1972.

Realism gave way to various theater forms and styles such as street theater, theater of the absurd, and Chinese proletarian theater that use a lot of allegories and symbolisms. Several reasons demanded this transition such as the need for the stylization of representing reality to make up for the minimalist staging, and the desire to create a sense of alienation in order to cultivate among the audience a critical perspective and to ensure that the political message is transmitted.

A theater form that thrived during the period of activism, specifically from 1970 to 1972, was street theater or dulansangan. This new kind of theater focused on national, local, and sectoral issues, and employed a variety of theater styles. Costumes were very simple but representative, and at times, symbolic; props were minimalist and improvised. Plays were mounted during rallies, demonstrations, and marches in Plaza Miranda, Mendiola, Liwasang Bonifacio, as well as in churches, school grounds, bulding lobbies, marketplaces, plazas, and streets.

The political or activist theater groups of this period developed the dulansangan. Masaker sa Araw ng Paggawa (Massacre on Labor Day), 1970, penned by Bonifacio Ilagan and directed by Leo Rimando, was mounted by Panday Sining and presented at Plaza Miranda. Ang Kalbaryo ni Juan de la Cruz (The Calvary of Juan de la Cruz), 1970, was staged by Tanghalang Bayan during the Holy Week in the streets of Manila and at Plaza Moriones. Other examples of these types of plays are Pakikibaka (The Struggle) by Kamanyang; Barikada (Barricades) and Tanging Paraan (The Only Way) by Gintong Silahis; Tunggalian (Rivalry) by Panday Sining; and Hukumang Bayan (People’s Court) by Tanghalang Bayan.

Politicized theater groups and playwrights employed elements of the theater of the absurd in creating plays that incorporated absurd images and situations to highlight political and social disorder and upheaval in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), 1968, presented beggars prosecuting one of their peers for the crime of caring for a child which was prohibited by the beggars’ organization. The court ordered Mang Serapio’s blinding to make him a better beggar. Panday Sining’s Hukumang Tuwad (Kangaroo Court), 1971, focused on the trial of the progresibong uri (progressive class) composed of the proletariat, farmers, workers, national minority, student, teacher, and prostitute who were charged for society’s problems by the reaksiyonaryong uri (reactionary class) composed of the imperialist American, landlord-comprador, and bureaucrat-capitalist. Rey de la Cruz’s Kumbensiyon ng Mga Halimaw (A Convention of Monsters), 1971, satirized the 1971 Constitutional Convention by bringing together creatures from Philippine folklore to tackle the Philippine Constitution. Kabaong ng Kalokohan (A Coffin of Nonsense), 1972, presented two cross-dressers in a nonsensical discussion of ways to face death.

 

Conclusion

English theater dominated the period from 1946 to 1972. Foreign theater repertoire, aesthetics, and practices circulated through the productions of numerous school-based and several non-school-based theater groups especially in Manila. However, Filipino theater artists later saw the incongruity of the plays they presented with the Filipino audiences they wanted to reach. With this realization, theater artists soon found ways to bring theater closer to the people. First was through the translation or adaptation of foreign plays to Filipino and other Philippine languages; second, through the creation of original Filipino plays in English which, although still written in a foreign language, depicted Philippine social realities; and third, through the translations into Filipino of original Filipino plays in English, and later through the creation of original plays in Filipino.

But it was the political and social events of the mid-1960s up to 1972 that pushed theater groups and artists to reevaluate their productions. The period witnessed a radical transformation of Philippine theater that paralleled the upheaval happening in society. Filipino playwrights, directors, and artists wrote plays that analyzed the problems of society and formulated courses of action so that audiences could contribute to social transformation. These artists explored different theater traditions—from the East to the West, from foreign and local, from traditional to modern—and experimented with various forms and techniques to make sure that the message contained in their plays were communicated to the audience effectively. Furthermore, they used languages that were most persuasive and powerful to their audience—namely, Filipino and other Philippine languages. These transformations become more significant as they influenced future theater productions in Philippine theater history.   Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article.value: Historical Background

On 4 Jul 1946, the Philippines declared its independence from the Americans. Despite the formal declaration, however, foreign control persisted. From being a colony, the Philippines became a neocolony.

The Philippines’s status as a neocolony was primarily defined by the economic and military treaties it was forced to forge with the United States (US). The Philippine Trade Act of 1946, also known as the Bell Trade Act, reflected the lopsided tariff agreements in favor of the United States. When the Bell Trade Act was severely criticized by Filipino nationalists, the Laurel-Langley Agreement of 1955 was passed. This new agreement removed some of the provisions that give preferentiality for the former colonizer, but it still guaranteed equal opportunities for US and Filipino business interests in all areas of the Philippine economy (Schirmer and Shalom 1987, 87-88, 95). Moreover, the Military Bases Agreement of 1947 provided the United States with extensive military facilities in many parts of the Philippines for a period of 99 years. Unlike similar agreements for US military bases in other countries, the treaty placed no restrictions on the use of the bases, including the types of weapons that could be stored in these facilities (Ibid., 96-97).

The Philippines became a neocolony of the United States not only politically and economically but ideologically as well. The American educational system continued to function as the most important bearer of American ideology. The public educational system under American colonial rule taught Filipinos to accept the Americans as benefactors, to forget their struggles for freedom, and to help pacify domestic opposition to US policy in the Philippines (Schirmer and Shalom 1987, 45). The curriculum taught Filipinos to trust in its relations with foreigners and to be uncritical about foreign economic control. After the war, the educational system, which remained Western and pro-American, produced a generation of young educated Filipinos who were even more receptive to the American way of life and its accompanying individualistic, competitive, and consumerist attitudes. Much of the success of the educational system in carrying out its function as a strategy of colonization is rooted in the use of English as the medium of instruction and learning. The use of English to teach and to learn “became the wedge that separated the Filipinos from their past and later was to separate educated Filipinos from the masses of their countrymen” (Constantino 1966, 45).

The educational system implemented in the country was supplemented by educational exchange programs supported by Fulbright, Rockefeller, and Ford. These programs were supposed to provide venues for the exchange of cultural influences. However, the one-way cultural transmission that actually happened only intensified the Americanization of Filipinos, especially of the educated class. Recipients of these programs, mostly artists, writers, and academicians, were given grants to stay in the United States to study, lecture, observe, and immerse themselves in the American culture. Upon their return to the Philippines, they became effective carriers of foreign ideas that spread throughout Philippine academic institutions and other domains of Philippine society (Lumbera 1997, 180). Also important were the visits to the Philippines of American professors and artists who would influence the direction of Philippine arts and culture (Legasto 2008, 76).

Developments in radio, television, and film would have a great impact on theater since these forms of mass media were some of the primary channels through which Western culture entered the Philippines. Radio stations aired the latest American pop songs, while television showed canned shows from the United States, including comedies, dramas, horror shows, action dramas, and variety shows. While the film industry tried to come up with original Filipino cinema, it was inundated by well-funded commercial films from Hollywood, including American melodramas, comedies, actions films (cowboy, secret agent, martial arts), and horror thrillers as well as European soft-core sex films and Italian cowboy movies. In order to compete with these imported films, some local movies produced local versions of these foreign genres.

The political, economic, educational, and cultural opportunities benefited only a small sector of Philippine society. As a result, the economic gap between the rich and the poor widened. Toward the mid-1960s, the living conditions of the great majority of Filipinos were getting worse. The US influence on Philippine politics and economy continued, its military privileges protected and strengthened. Opposition against the government and the status quo grew louder and stronger. Because of worsening poverty, workers in the urban areas and peasants in the regions became more radical. In various schools and universities, militant student movement emerged. Mass rallies and demonstrations were met with violence. The so-called First Quarter Storm took place, marked by the following historic events: the Battle of Mendiola in Jan 1970; the people’s congresses at Plaza Miranda, Congress, and the US Embassy, Feb-Mar 1971; and the Diliman Commune and University of the Philippines (UP) Barricades in Feb 1971 (Legasto 2004, 172-73). These changing conditions were reflected in the changes that happened in Philippine theater.
Theater Groups

School-Based Theater Groups. One of the main channels through which American ideology and way of life continued to be passed on to generations of young Filipino was the staging of foreign plays in English. Plays written by American or European playwrights that have so-called “artistic merits” based on Western standards dominated the theater scene after World War II. The school setting remained to be the center of legitimate theater productions in English. After the war, other school-based theater groups followed the lead of the Ateneo Players Guild established in 1921: the UP Dramatic Club, 1930, and the Far Eastern University (FEU) Theater Guild, 1934. Some of the theater figures who established theater groups after the war were part of these earlier groups. For example, Onofre Pagsanghan, who established Dulaang Sibol was part of the Ateneo Players’ Guild, while Severino Montano, who organized the Arena Theater, was a member of the UP Dramatic Club. Just like their predecessors, most of the postwar theater groups mounted original foreign plays in English or English translations of foreign plays.

The Paulinian Players Guild was founded in the early 1950s at the St. Paul College in Manila. Some of the plays it mounted were Edmond Rostand’s L’Aiglon, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II’s The Sound of Music and Carousel, and Alan Jay Lerner’s Brigadoon. The Aquinas Dramatic Guild also started in the early 1950s at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) and was an offshoot of a series of radio plays in 1952. It was initially called the Aquinas Radio Dramatic Guild, which later became the Aquinas Dramatic Guild when it staged Antonio Molina’s His Eminence, an English translation of Jose Maria Peman’s El Gran Cardenal. The group founded by Onofre Pagsanghan at the Ateneo de Manila High School was first organized in 1956 as the Ateneo de Manila High School’s Dramatic Society. In 1966, it became the Dulaang Sibol. The earlier group regularly produced Shakespearean plays such as Macbeth and Hamlet, and even Rostand’s Cyrano de Bergerac. Other school-based theater groups that mounted similar repertoire included the Arellano University Dramatic Club, FEU’s Drama Department, the Philippine Women’s University Experimental Theater, the Manuel L. Quezon Dramatic Club, and the University of the East Dramatic Guild.

Aside from these theater groups, school-based organizations such as fraternities and sororities, as well as student religious groups, would often stage plays in English to celebrate important occasions, to raise funds for the organization, or to use theater to project an image for the organization. In UP, fraternities and sororities that ventured into theater production were the Tau Alpha, Upsilon Sigma Phi, Sigma Rho, Aztecs Confraternity, Phi Kappa Mu, Upsilon Sigma Phi, Alpha Phi Omega, Beta Sigma, Alpha Phi Beta, Sigma Alpha Sorority, Delta Lambda Sigma Sorority, Sigma Delta Phi Sorority, Sigma Beta Sorority, Phi Delta Alpha Sorority, Kappa Phi Omega Sorority, and Sigma Delta Phi. The University of the Philippines Student Catholic Action established Dramatic Guild, which later became Dulaang Delaney, and the University of the Philippines Christian Youth Movement (UPCYM) organized the UPCYM Playhouse to mount plays in English by foreign and Filipino playwrights (Carbayas 1999, 64-73).

Even in the regions, school-based theater groups that were established after World War II produced mostly Western plays. El Teatro, which was founded in 1959, and The Genesius, established in 1965, both based at the University of St. La Salle in Bacolod, mounted foreign plays and musicals. Portal Players, founded in 1966 as the Silliman University (SU) theater group, mounted Western classics, continuing the tradition of the earlier group, the Department of Language and Dramatic Arts of SU, established in 1961. USA Little Theater, organized in 1965 at the University of San Agustin in Iloilo, also presented mostly Western materials, and later, works by Filipino playwrights in English such as Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero.

There were school-based theater groups that stood out during the period since they focused not on foreign plays in English but developed original Filipino plays in English. Their productions may be considered important transitions from legitimate theater in English toward the development of an original Filipino theater. The Arena Theater of the Philippines was founded by Severino Montano in 1953 at the Philippine Normal College (or PNC, now Philippine Normal University). The Arena Theater of the Philippines did not limit its performances within the PNC community. It fielded teacher-actors throughout the country to bring modern drama to other schools and communities. Montano also introduced the arena style of production that enabled the group to perform in various towns and barrios all over the Philippines. The group developed 4 full-length plays and 18 one-act plays in English mostly written by Montano.

The UP Mobile Theater was established in 1962 by Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero in UP. The group performed plays by Guerrero, which while mostly written in the 1930s and 1940s, became even more popular after the war. Among these were Wanted: A Chaperone, Half an Hour in a Convent, and Three Rats. The group also aimed at bringing theater to different regions of the country. Meanwhile, another theater organization, the Chamber Theater Group, was organized in FEU in 1964 by Nick Agudo. The group developed plays based on literary works by Filipino authors in English.

Since the plays of Montano and Guerrero were staged in many communities in various regions in the Philippines and dealt with Philippine realities, a number of their plays were eventually translated or adapted to other Philippine languages. These translations and adaptations prompted the entry of the national language and other major Philippine languages into the domain of legitimate theater. Onofre Pagsanghan would transform the Ateneo Dramatics Society, which regularly produced Shakespearean plays, into Dulaang Sibol, which adapted foreign plays. While the productions still worked within the framework of the foreign plays, they nevertheless consciously explored the use of the Filipino language in legitimate theater in the case of the translations, and adjusted the foreign materials to bring them closer to the Filipino audience in the case of the adaptations. In 1967, Dulaang Sibol would initiate the Paligsahang Pandulaan. This playwriting competition encouraged the Ateneo High School students to write and direct original Filipino plays. It produced theater luminaries such as Paul Dumol and Tony Perez.

Non-School-Based Theater Groups. Aside from the school-based theater groups, there were other groups whose members came from various professions and persuasions, and catered to different communities and sectors of society. Initially, these non-school-based theater groups offered almost the same repertoire of English plays by foreign playwrights or written by Filipinos. During the period of the First Quarter Storm, however, groups that were linked with the nationalist movement emerged and developed plays that were collectively called political, activist, or revolutionary theater.

After the war, the Barangay Theater Guild, founded in 1939 by Lamberto and Daisy Avellana, continued to present classic and modern English plays. Other non-school-based theater groups were the Community Players, Tambuli Playhouse, and Penmouth Playhouse. There was also the Manila Theater Guild established in 1951, which was based at the Army-Navy Club in Manila. Its members were Filipinos, but its directors and actors often came from the American and British communities in Manila. The group had an average of six productions a year of Spanish, British, and American plays, presented mostly to the foreign community in Manila.

In 1967, even when there was a movement toward the Filipinization of theater as a response to the call of the times, Repertory Philippines (Rep) was established by Zeneida Amador. It aimed to make theater a social habit for Filipinos by presenting regular theater seasons with foreign plays, mostly from Broadway and London’s West End. Its productions were patronized primarily by the elite sector of the society.

In the mid-1960s, several theater groups were formed which faced the challenges of the times by creating original Filipino plays. The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) was founded in 1967 by Cecile Guidote to concretize her “Prospectus for the National Theater of the Philippines.” Initially, its policy was to present plays depicting Filipino culture, as well as Filipino translations of foreign plays. The group later developed the concept of “aesthetics of poverty,” and later on, its writers’ pool created committed plays—those that deal with the examination of relevant sociopolitical issues.

Another group that focused on raising the social consciousness of the Filipino audience through original Filipino theater was the UP Repertory Company, founded by Behn Cervantes in 1968. Most of its significant productions in Filipino would be staged after the declaration of martial law. The group would also develop a theater form, the tula-dula (poem-play) which is appropriate to the limitations as well as to the purpose of mounting plays in the streets.

In the regions, there was Kolambugan Dance Theater, founded in Lanao in 1970. It sought to unite Muslims and Christians through theater. All of its productions were dance dramas written and conceptualized by the group’s founder, Fr Rodulfo Galenzoga. Its most successful play is Maranatha (Make Haste, Lord), which toured all over the country and performed 135 times.

During the First Quarter Storm, theater groups that were linked with the broader nationalist movement were formed. From the productions of these theater groups, activist theater emerged. Militant student groups, such as Kabataang Makabayan and Samahan ng Demokratikong Kabataan (SDK), organized cultural groups that used theater as a political tool. Tanghalang Bayan, the cultural arm of the Katipunan ng mga Kabataang Demokratiko, sought to promote a national, mass, and scientific culture through plays like Kalbaryo ni Juan de la Cruz (The Calvary of Juan de la Cruz), Hukumang Bayan (People’s Court), Rebolusyon (Revolution), and Kamatayan ng Isang Aktibista (Death of an Activist), staged between 1969 and 1971.

The establishment of Gintong Silahis ca. 1970 was initiated by the SDK. Under the leadership of Behn Cervantes, its artistic director, the productions of the group were political in orientation. It staged Alay kay Ka Amado (In Honor of Ka Amado), 1971, and Barikada (Barricades), 1971. The group’s plays often employed a koro (chorus) since there were no microphones as they performed not only in schools and urban poor communities but also during rallies. The group also held discussions with the audience regarding the issues presented in the play.

Panday-Sining was founded by Bonifacio Ilagan in 1971. Its theater repertoire includes agitprop skits, mobile street theater, choreographed music and poetry, vignettes, and one-act plays. Some of its most known plays are Masaker sa Araw ng Paggawa (Labor Day Massacre), 1970; Hukumang Tuwad (Kangaroo Court), 1971; Welga! Welga! (Strike! Strike!), 1972; and Sinipi sa Buhay (Drawn from Life). Its artistic director Leo Rimando employed various theater forms and styles such as realism, expressionism, and absurdism, and drew inspiration from the proletarian Chinese Theater of Jiang Jing and from Bertolt Brecht.

The productions of these politically motivated theater groups represent a break from the plays produced in the 1940s up to the first half of 1960s. Theater was treated not only as a pedagogical tool for language teaching and as a form of entertainment but also as a means of raising social awareness and motivating people to transform society.

article.value: Education and Training

During the first decades of American colonial rule, theater was primarily used to reinforce the teaching of English through dialogues, skits, and short plays. As a result, the classroom became the default venue for theater activities, with the English teachers serving as “trainers.” After the war, theater moved out of the classrooms and into school stages and performed to larger audiences. More schools instituted drama subjects and established drama clubs or theater groups. English teachers and professors were usually assigned to teach drama, advise drama clubs, and direct plays on special occasions such as foundation days, national holidays, and feast days, thus continuing the dominance of the English language in theater.

Later, theater began to be seen not just as a complementary activity to the teaching of the English language but already as an art and a discipline in itself. Universities developed more drama subjects that later on became the foundation for a complete academic program in theater. Usually, the theater arts department emerged from the English department of colleges and universities. In 1959, the UP Department of Speech and Drama (DSD) was founded. By the 1960s, DSD included elementary stagecraft, playwriting, acting, and art history of the theater in its roster of courses. Eventually, when DSD became the Department of Speech Communication and Theater Arts in 1977, these courses were finally recognized as independent of theater courses.

Similarly, in 1965, the Department of Language and Dramatic Arts of Silliman University was established, which later gave birth to a separate Department of Speech and Drama in 1967. The latter offered majors and minors in English, and speech and drama. The Department focused on training students on the various aspects of theater production, instituting new subjects like acting, directing, and design. In 1969, it was renamed the Speech and Theater Arts Department, which offered a bachelor of arts degree in speech and theater.

Theater education and training were also obtained from the theater groups through actual productions, workshops, and apprenticeship. Training was principally conducted by theater directors who were also the groups’ founders and artistic leaders. The first group of influential theater directors were Americans or American-educated artists. Before and immediately after the war, Fr Henry Lee Irwin, SJ, was active in Ateneo de Manila, while Jean Garrott Edades was in UP. In the postwar era up to the 1970s, Severino Montano directed for the Arena Theater of the Philippine Normal University; Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero for the UP Dramatics Club and UP Mobile Theater; Fr James Reuter SJ for the Paulinian Players of St. Paul College; Lamberto V. Avellana and Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana for the Barangay Theater Guild; Sarah Joaquin, Nick Agudo, and Rustica Carpio for the FEU Theater Guild; Onofre Pagsanghan for the Ateneo Dramatics Guild and Dulaang Sibol; Frank Flores for Portal Players; Zeneida Amador for Repertory Philippines; Cecile Guidote for PETA; Behn Cervantes for the UP Repertory Company; and Rolando S.Tinio for Teatro Pilipino.

The training provided by some of these directors was not confined within the groups they established and the school communities they served. Various schools and communities all over the Philippines benefited from the performances and training programs by groups such as Montano’s Arena Theater of the Philippines and Guerrero’s UP Mobile Theater, which also conducted training-workshops to increase the number of theater directors, playwrights, actors, production staff, and even theater groups. Six years after Arena Theater was founded in 1953, the group expanded into 45 independent branches mostly in Pangasinan, Negros Occidental, and Cebu. The University of San Agustin’s USA Little Theater, formally established in 1965, traced its beginnings from a seminar Guerrero conducted among theater enthusiasts in the USA.

Most of these directors and artistic leaders introduced Western theatrical traditions, aesthetics, and practices, while also adapting them to local contexts. The history of Chamber Theater Group represents one concrete example by which foreign theater aesthetics and practices were transported to and popularized in the Philippines. The group was formed in 1964 after theater artist Nick Agudo completed his observation and work at Northwestern University with Robert Breen who developed the concept of chamber theater—a theater form where a literary work is adapted to the stage using a maximal amount of the work’s original text. Agudo experimented with short stories in his classroom laboratory productions. From his first batch of students in oral interpretation, the Chamber Theater Group was organized. In 1966, the American Embassy invited the group to popularize chamber theater in the Visayas and Mindanao using Filipino short stories as material. It also performed for public schools in Manila, and later the organization of public schools held an annual contest of chamber theater productions using the scripts developed by the Chamber Theater Group. While the experience of the Chamber Theater Group simulated the flow of foreign influences from its origin and into many parts of the Philippines, the group should also be credited for utilizing the works of Filipino authors for its theater productions.

Activist theater during the First Quarter Storm demanded a change in the training of all those involved in the production of plays. There was emphasis on politicization. Artists and staff members were expected to have knowledge of the various aspects of production but equally important was their knowledge of the prevailing political and social issues and realities. Lectures and discussions were conducted to equip theater artists and practitioners with the correct political and aesthetic orientation.

There were also changes in the practices of producing plays. Plays were written individually, but more often, collectively. The spirit of democratization was carried out even in the process of conceptualizing and deciding on the final form of the play through collective decision making by the director, playwright, performers, and production people. The collective spirit was extended even to the audience. Primarily, plays were written in the national language and other Philippine languages. Also, the barriers set down between the performers and the audience by the proscenium stage were dismantled. This was done by employing staging techniques that allowed performers to come from or move around the audience’s area or by using theater styles that required the audience not only to view the performance but also to actively participate in its completion. In a way, theater artists and audiences were being educated and trained on a new kind of theater that is democratic and participatory.
