article.value: The vibrant theater scene, especially among the ranks of activist youths and students of the 1970s, was one of the first to be affected by the declaration of martial law. The groups could not continue the brand of militancy developed and sustained in the late 1960s and especially during the first two years of the 1970s. The streets and universities of Metro Manila and select regions stormed by such groups as Samahang Kamanyang, Gintong Silahis, Tanghalang Bayan, and Panday Sining quieted down—at least for several months.

Theater artists were the first to regroup, reorganize, and pursue an organized program. By Jan 1973, three months after the declaration, a group led by Nicanor Tiongson which included B. Basilidez Bautista, Anton Juan Jr, Jonas Sebastian, Manuel Pichel, and Doreen Fernandez established Dulaang Babaylan. In the open and official documents, Dulaang Babaylan aimed at staging professional productions and authentic revivals of traditional Philippine drama, but covertly, it provided a venue for nationalist artistic activities and some degree of protection or shelter to the endangered activists-artists of pre-martial law theater. Fons Deza of Panday Sining typified this endangered species. In Apr 1973, during Holy Week, he gamely played Christ in Babaylan’s modern nationalist sinakulo at the Luneta—among the first breakthroughs for theater artists amid martial law terror (Deza 1998, 10, 68-70; Tiongson 2013).

Similar moves would be observed in other groups already existing before the declaration, especially those that had espoused anti-Marcos sentiments or pursued radical and revolutionary goals. In the case of the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) founded in 1967, the founder Cecile Guidote-Alvarez, who was critical of the Marcoses, had to leave the country. But martial law could not dampen the group’s vision and programs. There were resignations and leadership shuffles, but with talents like CB Garrucho, Joy Soler de Castro, Pio de Castro, Felix Padilla Jr, Frank G. Rivera, Len Santos, Jojo Purisima, and Maryo de los Reyes in its ranks, theater activities continued. Though they were not necessarily productions that directly alluded to the rapacity of the Marcoses, they presented original Filipino theater just the same. Lino Brocka eventually emerged as leader, aided by Soxie Topacio and Lutgardo Labad. Even Teodoro Valencia did not give up on a theater space in the ruins, the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman. PETA’s next generation of leaders—CB Garrucho, Manny Pambid, Brenda Fajardo, and Remmy Rikken—ensured Philippine theater’s continuity. There was no break in the productions, even in 1972 and 1973 (Samson et al. 2008).

Lino Brocka pursued realist productions; Orlando Nadres and Frank G. Rivera wrote scripts, and their works saw the light of day; Felix Padilla Jr showcased innovations in directing on colleague Paul Dumol’s material; and by 1977, Fritz Bennewitz, a German national from Europe’s socialist world, began working on Brecht for the company. The magic of Dulaang Rajah Sulayman continued to work. To a good extent, PETA had reclaimed radical and revolutionary trajectories that were becoming dominant voices before the declaration. While there was real shock, fear, and anxiety accompanying the imposition of martial law, the period was just ripe for the continuation and enrichment of theater trends and productions that had been going on for several decades in the Philippine theater communities before martial law. The repressive period proved both immensely challenging and productive. It gave space eventually and pushed boundaries to many trends and directions, and evolved additional refinements. An initial overview attests to continuities and proliferations but also dissonances and counter-discourses. Established groups like Repertory Philippines and PETA, both founded in 1967, persisted. University theater groups like Dulaang Sibol, Tanghalang Ateneo, and De La Salle Dramatics Guild (later becoming DLSU Harlequin Theatre Guild in 1987), all established before martial law, weathered the difficult times and survived. Some school-based groups may possibly have been dormant in this period, but they did not exactly close shop. To be fair, martial law was not anti-theater. The military did close Abelardo Hall at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1972 after the first performance of Marat/Sade and harassed Teatro Pangkatilingban in Negros, both for their organizing and their theater activities. But military agents were also part of the audience of the Dulaang Babaylan’s Sinakulo at the Luneta, laughing at the scenes, while inquiring who the director was. It was only after some time that PETA realized there may have been spies in their membership (Cristobal 2011; Juan 2015; Lucero 2016).

Quite impressive new theater groups and formations actually sprouted during this period. In the National Capital, Dulaang Babaylan’s quick response in 1973 was followed in the same year by a reorganization of the UP Repertory Company by Behn Cervantes, which was based in the UP Diliman campus. Even the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) had established Samahan sa Dulo by Dindo Angeles and Paul Dumol in the same year. By 1974, UP Anak-Tibawan was established in UP Manila. With the arrival of PETA facilitators and artist-organizer Frank Rivera, Sining Kambayoka was formed in Marawi State University in the same year. In 1976, UP Diliman became home to Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP), and CCP to Teatro Pilipino (TP), led by Tony Mabesa and Rolando Tinio, respectively. The following year, Gantimpala Theater Foundation Inc (formerly known as Bulwagang Gantimpala Theater Foundation Inc), was established at the CCP and was dedicated to mounting the winning entries to the CCP Playwriting Contest. In the same year also, Teatro Mulat ng Pilipinas at UP Diliman and Teatro Umalohokan at UP Los Baños were established, along with Teatro Tomasino at the University of Santo Tomas (UST). And from 1978 to 1981, the regions were able to produce the Integrated Performing Arts Guild (IPAG) in Iligan, 1978; Teatro Amakan in Iloilo City, 1979; Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna (PASILAG) in Laguna, 1979; Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc in Malolos, Bulacan, 1980; and Kulturang Atin Foundation Inc (KAFI) in Davao, 1981. Despite the tight control of the dictator, theater gained more shape and cohesion not only in Manila but in the provinces as well. Even the ruling establishment had its own theater formation—the Dulaang Kabataang Barangay—although this initiative hardly left an impression and is now generally forgotten.

Martial law heightened contradictions and conflicting trajectories in contemporary Philippine theater history observed after World War II. The short period of about 14 years, from the declaration to the ouster of Marcos, saw the ascendancy and eventual triumph of a sizable group of Filipino playwrights writing in the vernacular and able to feed the production needs of the contemporary theater movement, especially those artists hungry for originality and discourse rooted in the nation’s experience. Except for Repertory Philippines that produced more current successes from Broadway and London’s West End, the theater scene was very much enlivened by the arrival of these contemporary Filipino playwrights, whose efforts started much earlier, but their definitive corpus of works was perhaps really felt only during this period.

This triumph could perhaps be credited to the Palihang Aurelio V. Tolentino (PAVT) and parallel efforts and initiatives in PETA that had an active writers’s pool from its very inception in the late 1960s. Although the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature already had a category for playwriting in both English and Filipino, the winning entries were not systematically staged, if at all. Before PAVT, Onofre Pagsanghan had silently worked to develop expressions and vernacular texts for the performing arts for the very young and talented in Ateneo in the mid- and late 1960s. But perhaps PAVT had a good strategy and a more integrated, pluralistic program, less tied down to specific resident writers’ programs for generating texts for Philippine theater. PAVT was led again by Nicanor G. Tiongson, Jonas Sebastian, Doreen Fernandez—about the same group from Dulaang Babaylan. With the institutional support from UP Repertory, the Department of Filipino and Philippine Literature of UP Diliman, the UP Writers Club, and the Cultural Research Association of the Philippines, the generous financial assistance from Vic Puyat, and the cooperation of other theater groups that eventually participated (e.g., UP Anak-Tibawan, PETA), PAVT founded a network larger than one production or theater group—something unprecedented at that time—and evolved and gave sustenance to local playwrights of the generation (Tope 2014). What made this project exemplary for the period was that it involved a workshop phase, a writing phase, a contest, and a production phase for winning entries.

With the four successive sets of the Palihan workshops (1974, 1976, 1978, 1979), new playwrights like Reuel Aguila, Mauro Avena, Rosauro de la Cruz, Manuel Pambid, Angelito Tiongson, Nonilon Queaño, Bonifacio Ilagan, Reynaldo Duque, Jose Papa, Al Santos, Richie Valencia-Buenaventura, Rene O. Villanueva, Bienvenido Noriega, and Edgardo Maranan emerged, arrived, and were greatly encouraged. Their works were staged. Generally young and inexperienced, bold, vibrant, and enchanting productions came from the winning batches. To some theater scholars and the culturati, the productions may have overused the episodic structure or were written like movie scripts (Tope 2014, 53), but their texts generated meaning, worth, and relevance for audiences that watched them. The PAVT approach was so successful that the CCP would later adopt this model for its playwriting contest whose winning entries were staged by Bulwagang Gantimpala at the CCP’s experimental space starting in 1997.

Considering national contexts and international standards of that time, and looking at how the theater community reacted in the early days of martial law as seen in the works of the Babaylan theater group and the PAVT and the parallel efforts made by PETA, the CCP, Ateneo, and UP Repertory Company, and at how regional theater groups like Sining Kambayoka, Teatro Umalohokan, IPAG, Teatro Amakan, PASILAG, Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation, KAFI, and Sorsogon’s Community Based Theater Group (established in 1984) developed their own formations and expressions, it was quite clear that Philippine theater stood for the development of the Filipino playwright and his corpus of works was in the right path. The standard and ideal trajectory for Philippine theater at this juncture was the delivery of original and current works whose discourses were rooted in ethnic and national contexts. It had to stand with the rest of the world with a unique voice, with text, lore, themes, and issues in its own narratives and indigenous languages. Collectively, the theater community not only fought the dictatorship but also continued to shape the cultural component of the nation through a body of original plays written in the vernaculars, mounted by Filipino theater groups, and shared to a cross section of Philippine publics.

Complementing the creation of a corpus of contemporary plays in the vernaculars was the revalidation and reintegration of traditional Philippine theater into the national scene. Again, Dulaang Babaylan was in the ideal trajectory here, although there had been earlier efforts from Felicidad Mendoza through the Kudyapi Community Theater League and Rolando Tinio in Ateneo de Manila University. The theater community rediscovered the earlier mandudula (playwrights)—Francisco Baltazar, Tomas Remigio, Aurelio Tolentino, Juan Abad, Julian Cruz Balmaseda—and gave a salute to the sinakulo. After the initial success of the Babaylan sinakulo at the Luneta in 1973, other groups mounted similar productions to popularize traditional plays. Kalinangan ng Lahi, for example, performed in the asphalt jungle of Cubao, while Tanghalang Kabataan staged its plays ca. 1975 in the Pantranco vicinity. In the case of UP Anak-Tibawan, both traditional and contemporary plays were nurtured. These two complementary directions—the production of original contemporary plays and the staging of Filipino classics—intertwined to define the text for Philippine theater.

By having plays from the earlier periods of Philippine history vis-à-vis the growing corpus of contemporary works, originality and heritage coalesced to project a confident theater community continuously defining national theater and culture (Chua 2014). Liberated and liberative, ascendant, daring, Philippine theater from 1972 to 1986 contributed in solidifying and defining the nation, in the midst of the realities of martial law and a hierarchical society dominated by political dynasties and corrupt politicians.

The phenomenon of theater at that time could also be viewed in the broader context of the larger organization occurring during this period. The theater community mirrored the larger national struggle to dismantle the Marcos dictatorship. In the 1970s, the youth and the studentry were once more at the forefront. The reorganization of the PETA-Metropolitan Teen Theater League (PETA-MTTL) in 1975 under Rosalie Matilac exemplified how youthful energy could be harnessed for theater creation. As eloquently perceived by Tony Mabesa, Philippine theater is youthful energy, with mostly students in their teens to their 20s as its base. At the height of its expansion just before the 1986 EDSA Revolt, PETA-MTTL had members and affiliates in approximately 20 high schools in Metropolitan Manila doing theater work for themselves and their communities as young citizens of the land.

Other sectors soon followed. In 1976, fishport workers in urban poor areas captured the attention of playwrights like Manny Pambid. Eventually, the Alyansa ng Maralita sa Sining (ALMASIN), an alliance of cultural groups in the urban poor sector, materialized, tapping resources from Bagong Barrio, Caloocan, and areas in Tondo. It was also in 1976 that the workers announced their renewed participation in the La Tondeña strike to clamor for the humane treatment of workers and the abolition of antilabor policies of the state. Other cultural groups would eventually be formed: Tanghalang Silangan, 1981, its unionists working in the Novaliches factory of Rubberworld Adidas, and Tambisan sa Sining Inc, whose base was the labor formation Kilusang Mayo Uno–Nasyunal. By 1985, another factory-based group, Artex Cultural Group, would become active (Barrios 1994, 129). While it is true that the religious did not seem to have created a specific theater group or even just a singing group with themselves as actors and performers, their presence during mobilizations and mass actions during the period certainly exposed their anti-dictatorship stance. Working with the religious were theater artists Rodulfo Galenzoga and Karl Gaspar in Mindanao, and Alan Abadesco in Negros. By 1976, the theater community and its allied sectors had made clear their anti-dictatorial sentiments.

The regions were soon busy doing committed theater. PETA, through the Central Institute for Theater Arts in Southeast Asia (CITASA) program, had over the years fielded out regional coordinators and teachers to monitor and push regional development in the field of theater and culture all over the Philippines. After all, the vision of its founder was a prospectus for a national theater movement, which meant geographical cover of Philippine regions. The famous workshop in Tagum, Davao, in 1969, supposedly the first rural workshop by the company, linked Mindanao to the national network formation. Sining Kambayoka became possible only after a PETA workshop in Mindanao State University, Marawi City, in 1974. In 1976, PETA trainers hooked up with KAFI, and eventually a stronger KAFI spilled over to the Mindanao Community Theater Network. By 1984, Visayas had Gigi Carunungan as PETA regional coordinator, Southern Tagalog and Bicol had Weni Gamboa, and Northern and Central Luzon had Marichu Belarmino. Local initiatives complemented by the CITASA training programs generated alliances, formations, and groups active in using theater and culture for social empowerment. For example, Teatro Umalohokan led the formation of Makabayang Alyansa sa Sining Anakpawis–Timog Katagalugan (MASA-TK), mandated to coordinate theater groups in Laguna, Cavite, Quezon, and Batangas (Samson et al. 2008, 100, 190-238). Certainly, Joonee Gamboa, Leo Rimando, and Behn Cervantes, each in their own ways worked to popularize theater or to establish a national network of cultural and theater groups. But more likely, it was PETA’s summer workshops and the innumerable CITASA outreach work that really achieved the formation of a theater network. The culmination of all of PETA and CITASA’s efforts were MAKIISA I in 1983 and MAKIISA II in 1984, directly coordinated by the premier theater company.

But even as many groups, institutions, and formations were doing theater rooted in ethnic, regional, and national contexts, generally progressive and social in discourse, other discourses were being generated by other initiatives. For Teatro Pilipino which he founded in 1976, Rolando Tinio insisted on a repertoire of translations—mainly his—of Western classics, which led to the marginalization of original Filipino plays. The DUP would strike very interesting variations. Its inaugural at the Abelardo Hall Auditorium in 1976 was a Filipino translation of Shakespeare’s Much Ado about Nothing, with its founding chair and artistic director Tony Mabesa directing. Both Tinio and Mabesa had a very strong passion for Western classics, and these were the kind of materials they wanted to stage in their respective companies after they returned from their studies in the United States. And they had the influence, the support of colleagues and friends, and the structures to do this. But Mabesa did not monopolize DUP for himself—he shared it with several other directors, including the activist-theater director Behn Cervantes, whose agitprop productions for his UP Repertory Company were included in the seasons of DUP from the very first. Although Western theater in English or English translations nearly dominated the premier state university’s offerings through DUP’s Theater Arts Company, it could not be sustained. It only lasted from the 8th to the 12th theater season (Cortez 2006, 100). At Ateneo de Manila University, Enterteynment para sa Tao, Bayan, Lansangan, at Diyos or ENTABLADO aimed to create socially conscious theater. The theater group did exposure trips and apostolic work in depressed areas and eventually took part in the EDSA Revolt (Casumpang 2015). Since its founding year in 1985, its repertoire has consisted of original Filipino plays in the vernacular. Tanghalang Ateneo, established earlier in the 1970s, already incorporated original Filipino plays in its repertoire as early as 1979 and became a venue for playwrights like Bienvenido Noriega, Paul Dumol, and Tony Perez. At the University of Santo Tomas (UST), Artistang Artlets was established in 1980. Together with Teatro Tomasino, which was formed in 1977, this new theater group championed local plays and playwrights, mostly contemporary. After 1986, new texts from Jun Lana, Vim Nadera, and Jose Victor Torres emerged from these groups. Meanwhile, De La Salle Dramatics Guild, already mounting Pilipino translations, adaptations of Western classics, and even original works, managed to survive until 1987 when it officially became DLSU Harlequin Theatre Guild. Both the FEU Drama Guild and the UE Theater Company took a little longer to rebuild and regain active status.

But the majority of theater artists, whether inside or outside the National Capital Region, were in full battle gear by 1983, the year Senator Benigno Aquino was assassinated. By then, a younger generation of theater artists had joined the community. UP Peryante led by Chris Millado mounted productions in campuses and on the streets which directly attacked the Marcoses. Pete Lacaba, Lino Brocka, and Behn Cervantes formed the Concerned Artists of the Philippines. A massive show of art and protest, with Philippine theater groups leading, was organized, with MAKIISA I staged in Dec 1983 at the Tanghalang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago (Tiongson 1984), and MAKIISA II in Dec 1984 at Christ the King Seminary, Quezon City. Theater communities united to define trajectories for finer approaches to people’s theater aesthetics, which supplanted its agitprop and allegorical roots during the pre-martial law years, as well as to clarify positions vis-à-vis the currents of national and radical social movements (Tiongson 1984; Samson et al. 2008, 265-75). People’s theater would continue until the 1986 EDSA Revolt.

By then, an impressive national network of theater groups had emerged. This network covered all the regions. From the National Capital Region came Alyansa para sa Makabayang Teatro ng Kabataan or ALAMAT, ALMASIN, Anak Ko Cultural, Artex Cultural Group, BAHAGHARI, BALIK-DULA, Dulaang Habagat, Dulaang Katig, Dulaang Palanyag, DULAMPASIGAN, HAYUMA, HONRADES, KANTA (based in Valenzuela), KISSA, LFS Cultural, Likas-Likas (based in Montalban), Lingkod-Sining, MASA, MASKARA, Muog ng Lahi, PATATAG, PETA, PETA Kalinangan Ensemble, PETA-MTTL, Pintig Kayumanggi, SAKDAL, SAMBIGKIS, SAMBISIG, SAPAGKAT, Sining, Sining Pangharing, SINTUNADO, TAHAK, TAMANABA, Tambisan, Tanghalang Silangan (predecessor of Teatro Pabrika), TANGLAW (MYF), Tanglaw ng Kabataan (Malabon), Teatro Bedista, TUKLAS, Ugnayang Pasig, UP Peryante, UP Repertory Company, and cultural formations from Carlos Albert High School, Manila Science High School, Philippine Science High School, Ramon Magsaysay High School, St. Joseph’s College, St. Scholastica’s Academy, and St. Theresa’s College.

From Luzon, there were Baguio Urban Poor People’s Alliance Cultural Arm, Barasoain Kalinangan, Bataan Workers Cultural Group, Cagayan Youth Theater League, Cordillera Youth Cultural Action Program, Dulaaang Malolos, Dulaang Angeles University Foundation, KALATAS, NOBELA (Diocesan Youth), Samahan ng Kabataang Agraryo (based in Bicol), Sentro ng Kalinangang Bayan, Silang Parish Dramatic Guild, Sining Bayan, Sorsogon Community Based Theater Group, Tanghalang Dalawa Singko (based in Batangas), Teatro Umalohokan, and Ugnay-Sining (based in Angeles).

From the Visayas rose ACT-Cebu, Alyansa Pangkultura Sang-Iloilo, Bulalakaw Samar, Cebu Repertory Company, Dulaang Katilingban Redemptorista, Dungog Alliance of Cebu Cultural Groups, Kataluasan Calbayog, Leyte Cultural Group, NAMSU, Negros Theater Leaque, Northern Samar Theater Arts Organization, and Silaw-Gabayan.

And from Mindanao came Agusan-Surigao Community Theaters, Apo ni Juan, Atong Teatro, Ipil Diocese Community Theater, Kambayoka Center, Kampilan Mindanao, KAFI, Lanao Educational Arts for Development, Mindanao Development Center, SCRIPT, and Sining Malay Ensemble-KAFI.

Looking back at the theater curriculum that propelled this movement, several features may be ascertained, particularly that which propelled people’s theater, the particular trademark and flag bearer for theater during the period of martial law up to the EDSA Revolt. The most crucial was the formulation of the orientation for Philippine theater, embodied in the acronym RPN, which stands for repleksiyon ng pangangailangan ng nakararami (reflecting the needs of the people), formulated in Nicanor Tiongson’s “What Is Philippine Drama?” (1983). As far back as 1971, RPN was lectured in drama classes in the universities, and afterward in theater groups like Babaylan, PETA, in the Mindanao theater networks, and in the CITASA summer workshops where it served as the opening plenary orientation lecture. Later, when the Orientation-Artistic-Organizational (OAO) framework was incorporated in the PETA theater syllabus in 1978 (Samson et al. 2008, 210-14), RPN fit perfectly in the first frame. The OAO framework was not imposed, but evolved with theater artists. Generally, a Marxist view of reality dominated.

Certainly, the entire Philippine dynamics at this time was layered, with issues that come with a society divided into social classes and oppressor-oppressed dynamics. Oppressor-oppressed theater exercises, merged with Viola Spolin’s release exercises, which were done in as playful a manner as possible, already propagated by PETA workshops even before the more sophisticated theater of the oppressed variant came. Boal’s theater of the oppressed, with touches of Paulo Freire, also made it into the 1982-83 PETA syllabi (Samson et al. 2008, 232), and was incorporated into the Basic Integrated Theater Arts Workshop (BITAW). BITAW seemed to have had a life of its own, as workshop participants echoed what they learned in multiple communities.

All these various strands came together to define the orientation and political stand of the people’s theater of the period. Karl Marx, Mao Tse-tung, Amado Guerrero, and Bertolt Brecht became major influences. The bottom line was that all sought change. Quite obviously, there was already a theater community that was gaining national configuration during martial law, through the remaining Marcos years, and until the 1986 EDSA Revolt. A foreign observer labeled the movement as a “playful revolution,” affirming the presence and force of the national theater community not only in toppling the dictatorship but also in building and shaping a society (Erven 1992). There was never a final victory for the nationalist, radical, and revolutionary agenda, which marked theater before and during martial law. The war against the dictator succeeded, but not the radical and revolutionary goals. But neither was it a total defeat.
Types of Plays

One of the most exciting periods in the history of Philippine theater production was the period from 1972 to 1986, which generated a variety of trends, forms, techniques, styles, directions, and processes.

Plays in English. Repertory Philippines, with cosmopolitan and corporate Makati as its base and both the Spanish and American expatriate communities as its supporters, did English language theater during the Marcos years. Even with English language theater generally declining in the schools and cultural centers during this period, Repertory Philippines proudly showcased renditions—some almost copies—of the original of Broadway and West End hits. It also successfully professionalized human resources for these productions (Ang 2015).

Many theater companies based in universities and colleges continued to mount English language plays, concentrating on the classics of Western theater, Shakespeare, Chekhov, Ibsen, and contemporary Western playwrights.

Translations and Adaptations. From 1975 to 1992, Teatro Pilipino led in this trend, and some of its Pilipino translations of Western classics, notably Hamlet, have been published. Almost all the other theater groups were doing translations as well. UP Repertory Company staged translations of English plays by Filipinos such as Alberto Florentino’s Sa Bawat Sandali ng Buhay, from the original In Life’s Every Second, 1973, and Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Pagbibinyag sa Apoy at Dugo, from the original Walking Canes and Fans, 1975. DUP’s inaugural was Lilia Antonio’s Pagkahaba-haba Man ng Prusisyon, 1976, a translation of Shakespeare’s Much Ado about Nothing. PETA did Ang Hatol ng Guhit na Bilog, 1977, Franklin Osorio and Lito Tiongson’s translation of Bertolt Brecht’s The Caucasian Chalk Circle; and Ang Buhay ni Galileo, 1981, Alan Glinoga’s translation of The Life of Galileo. Tanghalang Ateneo mounted Ricardo Saludo’s Taga sa Panahon, 1984, a translation of Robert Bolt’s A Man for All Seasons.

Local adaptations included Doon Po sa Amin, 1965, Onofre Pagsanghan’s adaptation of Thornton Wilder’s Our Town, and Sinta, 1973, his adaptation of The Fantasticks. Paul Dumol adapted the story of one of Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion) characters and came out with Kabesang Tales (Cabeza Tales), 1975, while Bienvenido Lumbera worked on Nasa Puso ang Amerika, 1984, an adaptation of Carlos Bulosan’s novel America Is in the Heart. In the regions, Theater Arts Guild of the University of the Philippines College of Iloilo adapted foreign works into Hiligaynon such as Donya Clara, from Friedrich Durrenmatt’s The Visit, and Hacienda Roces, from Anton Chekhov’s The Cherry Orchard.

In the case of Japanese theater, Japanese theater forms, not plays, were adapted to Filipino narratives and materials. Tony Mabesa and Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio were the pioneers in exploring the possibilities of applying Japanese theater forms to Philippine materials. In 1977, the noh and kyogen were used in Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa (Sisa’s Quest) and Ang Madyik na Sombrero (The Magic Hat) respectively.

Adaptations of Traditional Plays. Martial law, to an extent, provided not only a good backdrop and context for productions of traditional Philippine plays plucked from their traditional communities and the historical past. Dulaang Babaylan’s breakthrough production of a modernized sinakulo at the Luneta a few months after the declaration of martial law succeeded in utilizing the traditional form to assert the right of the theater artist to continue to create and participate in the national discourse amid an authoritarian regime. Since censorship was enforced, the production was itself a commentary and testament to survival and creativity. Discourse-wise, the production could only openly attack commercialism, but implied was a critique of US multinationals in the Philippines.
Since not even martial law could overpower Holy Week rituals, theater artists in the urban setting maximized the political potential of this tradition.

Even as Dulaang Babaylan’s last sinakulo, Kristo, Anak ng Tao (Christ, Son of Man), played in Isabela, Cagayan, in 1981 (Cristobal 2011; Alfon 2015), the sinakulo had, by 1983, become a favored vehicle of protest among other artists. Virgilio Vitug’s Sinakulo ning Balen (Passion Play of the Country) was staged in Lubao, Pampanga, with a Jesus Makabalen as the central figure (Tiongson 1994b, 30), echoing Aurelio Tolentino’s Bagong Cristo (New Christ), 1907, which had Christ as a labor leader. Bagong Cristo was remounted by Anton Juan for Babaylan in 1977. Rene O. Villanueva, with Dulaang Malaya, also had a version of Sinakulo, 1981, deriving inspiration not only from Tolentino but from the dynamics of the workers’ theater group that mounted the production and the allegorical conventions of pre-martial law activist theater (Tiongson 1999c, 15-43).

Aside from the sinakulo, the panunuluyan also saw a stage version. Ang Panunuluyan ng Birhen Maria at San Jose sa Cubao, Ayala, Plaza Miranda, Atbp. Lugar sa Loob at Labas ng Metro Manila (Virgin Mary and Saint Joseph’s Search for an Inn in Cubao, Ayala, Plaza Miranda, and Other Places Inside and Outside Metro Manila) was performed in Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in 1979. It showed Mary and Joseph visiting various communities of the urban poor in Metro Manila and understanding the plight of the Filipino majority.

Eventually, Aurelio Tolentino’s drama simboliko Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow), 1976-77, produced by Babaylan and directed by Anton Juan, would make it to a theater space at the CCP and even in France. Somehow, the allegorical and historical frames of the narrative reverberated with similar formulations from the agitprop allegories of pre-martial law activist theater. Tomas Remigio’s Mga Santong Tao (People Saints), with its biting commentary on a stratified society and the ruling classes’ corruption at the very core, was staged by Tanghalang Kabataan in 1975, and by UP Manila’s Anak-Tibawan in 1983. At the CCP, Rolando Tinio directed Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1974, and Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), 1977, the latter a rare exception to the Western-text preference of TP. UP Anak-Tibawan also staged Severino Reyes’s R.I.P. and Ang Kalupi (The Wallet), 1981.

UP Repertory Company, under the artistic direction of Behn Cervantes, worked on Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Bundok (The Mountain), 1976, merging agitprop style with sarsuwela conventions. In this play, mountain people had to unite to fight foreign speculators digging for gold in the Cordilleras. By 1982, Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907) by PETA, under Soxie Topacio’s direction, would showcase artistic excellence in dramaturgy and the handling of the traditional form on stage, and provide validation for continuing the tradition for the contemporary audiences.

Indigenous Forms. The period after World War II, extending up to martial law, heightened other concerns by theater artists, such as the use of local languages and indigenous theater forms. Frank Rivera’s Mga Kuwentong Maranaw (Maranao Tales), 1974, as well as Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss on the Sword), 1978, use the indigenous bayok (debate in chant) as structural pegs for the plays and the accompanying poetic or chanted renditions. Rodulfo Galenzoga’s Maranatha (Make Haste, Lord), 1974, and Fe Remotigue and Don Pagusara’s Sinalimba (Magic Boat), 1986, used the dance drama genre for their plays.

In these productions, the lumad and Muslim traditions were creatively used by Mindanao theater artists and their audiences. The kapamalong-malong (a dance that uses the tubular skirt called malong), the various non-Christian Mindanao lore, and their costumes, textile, and dances were maximized to give productions coming from Mindanao local color and an authentic Mindanao feel. Even Fritz Bennewitz’s Ang Hatol ng Guhit na Bilog (The Caucasian Chalk Circle), staged in Manila, carried a similar preference. CB Garrucho’s portrayal of the queen even showcased her janggay (metal claws) and pangalay dance skills.

Historical Plays. Activism during the 1960s and the 1970s placed premium on knowledge of Philippine history. Teodoro Agoncillo and Renato Constantino were required and prized readings, before Amado Guerrero and Mao Tse-tung. In the case of playwrights of the period, historical materials became subjects of their texts for the stage. The pivotal historical epochs would be the revolution in the late 19th century; the various rebellions that preceded the revolution; the Filipino-American War, specially the events clustering on the drama simboliko and playwright Aurelio Tolentino; and to a lesser extent, the Japanese period.

Interest in Rizal’s fiction as history led Paul Dumol to write his powerful Kabesang Tales (Cabeza Tales), 1975, which showed the peasant as revolutionary. Domingo Landicho’s Unang Alay (First Offering), 1975, had one of the first takes on Andres Bonifacio. Fernando Josef’s Ang Tao … Hayop o Tao (Man … Animal or Man), 1975, was on the Dagohoy revolt. Lito Tiongson’s Ang Walang Kamatayang Buhay ni Juan de la Cruz, Alyas … (Isang Kronika ng Digmaang Pilipino-Amerikano 1900-1902) (The Deathless Life of Juan de la Cruz, Alias … A Chronicle of the Filipino-American War 1900-1902), 1976, was on the Philippine American War.

In Walang Kamatayang Buhay ni Juan de la Cruz, it became very clear that these excursions into past epochs were representations of contemporary events such as hamletting and heightened militarization. Eventually, critics and scholars would refer to this technique as the theater of circumvention (Lumbera 1987), similar to the allegorical drama simboliko at the turn of the 20th century. In these plays, lines alluded to events in distant or fictive settings, but audiences and the actors cross-referenced these to current events.

Other historical plays were Bonifacio Ilagan’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Sons of the People), 1978, staged by Bulwagang Gantimpala and also mounted as Sigaw ng Bayan (People’s Cry) by Behn Cervantes for UP Repertory Company in the same year. This was followed by Estados Unidos bersus Cruz, Abad at Tolentino (United States versus Cruz, Abad and Tolentino), 1981, also by Ilagan and Cervantes and the UP Repertory Company.

Anton Juan’s mounting of Aurelio Tolentino’s Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas, 1976, earlier made famous by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s The “Seditious” Tagalog Playwrights: Early American Occupation published 1972, must have made a deep impression on playwrights and other theater artists. They took bits of seditious plays and the theater artist-heroes’ lives as core or takeoff materials for contemporary playwriting as seen in two 1983 productions: Tolentino! by Edgar Maranan, staged by Bulwagang Gantimpala, and Isang Rihersal (A Rehearsal) by Rody Vera for PETA. Joel Lamangan did it with Isang Rehersal, and Chris Millado would bring Tolentino closer to the NPA period and the national democratic movement in his Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas, PETA, 1991.

By 1983, UP Peryante would cover the more recent historical material of the peasant movement just before World War II, with Marina Feleo-Gonzalez’s Dahong Palay, direction and adaptation by Chris Millado. Eventually, the Japanese occupation would be reflected in Jose Dalisay’s Sugatang Lawin (Wounded Eagle), 1978, and Pagsabog ng Liwanag (Burst of Light), 1980.

Realism. An early example of a realist style for this period, both in the mounting and the script, is Orlando Nadres’s Paraisong Parisukat (Square Eden), 1974, which had one setting for all scenes, capturing the specific ambience of a cramped stockroom above a shoe store space in real life. As conceived in the play’s script, the set, the costumes, and the acting would be realistic. Nadres, though, never seemed to have fully incorporated in his fictive creations the social complexities of the period, but this would turn out to become the paramount preoccupation of the younger generation of writers composed of Nonilon Queaño, Bonifacio Ilagan, and Rene O. Villanueva. While maintaining the verisimilitude of settings and accompanying action on stages, their brand of realism underlined concerns for social analysis and the depiction of social realities. More than a mounting style in theater as seen in the sets, costumes, and the execution, realism became an obligation for writers to analyze their society and depict them on stage. Class issues and antagonisms were among the first to surface. Workers’ issues, along with the conflict between capitalist and labor, had earlier been confronted in Bonifacio Ilagan and Panday Sining’s Welga! Welga! (Strike! Strike!), staged first on 25 Jan 1972 and remounted in 1986.

Sans obvious class delineation, other playwrights produced plays that evoked social analysis and a critique of the oppressor-oppressed relationships. Tony Perez’s Biyaheng Timog (Trip to the South), 1984, explored feudalism, patriarchy, and family history, while Reuel Aguila’s In Dis Korner (In This Corner), 1978, exposed the system of game fixing in the boxing world.

Eventually, martial law itself and its effects on individuals, communities, and sectors became the subject matter of plays. Rene O. Villanueva’s May Isang Sundalo (There Was a Soldier), 1982, was among the earliest to tackle and analyze the martial law setup. It problematized a soldier’s involvement in the oppressive military operations of the regime. Three years after, Chris Millado’s Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major), 1985, took the analysis to a more summative and national scale, representing the experiences and points of views on martial law of peasants, workers, the religious, the studentry, the affluent class, the ethnic minority, and even the police force, with all equally condemning the oppressive regime. In 1983, Bienvenido Noriega’s Batang Pro (Child Prostitutes) appeared, showing how even children suffer mercilessly as sex tourism proliferated during the period.

Eventually, gender issues began to fascinate playwrights, both on the personal and social levels. The gay community probably had their first manifesto on stage with Orlando Nadres’s Hanggang Dito na Lamang at Maraming Salamat (This Is as Far as I Go, and Many Thanks), 1974. Issues on the Filipino diaspora and the travails of the overseas Filipino were tackled in Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), 1975, while the elderly became the focus in Hiblang Abo (Strands of Grey), 1980.

Epic Theater. The reaction to authoritarian rule broadened the existing vocabulary of theater. Politicized Filipino artists and critics continuously seeking alternative ways to wrestle with artistic creations in settings that had grown far more complex and demanding, rediscovered Brecht and his practice. Challenged by the art and theoretical formulations of the master, certain features of playwriting and productions were identified as Brechtian or epic theater or theater of instruction, such as the nonconventional presentational style employing mime, song, and dance. The use of slides and other technical innovations, and the stylization of costumes and sets were also explored. Folklore and history were tapped as sources for characters and narratives (Torres-Reyes 1994, 71). Al Santos’s use of life-size dummies as substitute for real actors for the torture scenes in his Mene, Mene Tekel Upharsin (Your Days Are Numbered), 1982, and Chris Millado’s use of mask in his Ilokula productions, 1983, would fit the category, as would some Bonifacio Ilagan and Behn Cervantes collaborations.

Epic theater also covered techniques and methods learned from Peking Opera productions popular to theater artists–activists at that time. To a certain degree during this period, Brechtian theater, people’s theater, and activists’ theater overlapped. Brechtian also generally connoted a nonrealist style of theater mounting. Some critics and commentators saw in Rolando Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason) and Paul Dumol’s Kabesang Tales and Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio) techniques and devices learned from Brecht.

The documentary style, a trend in productions in this period first noticed by Tiongson (1994), may also exemplify the meaning of Brechtian or epic. The use of slides in theater productions to project photos taken from real events, approximating news coverage or newspaper accounts, is one innovation characteristic of the documentary theater or style. Al Santos’s Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata (May 21 and Other Chapters), 1977, added to this technology the use of narrators for an overall narrative effect, projecting what was happening on stage as historically accurate or nonfiction. The play covered historical vignettes from the Spanish period to the American, the Japanese, and then the present. Joel Lamangan’s direction of Mayo A-Beinte Uno used recycled newspaper and magazine photos of thekapatiranLapiang Malaya and its leader Valentin de los Santos, particularly the massacre that transpired on that date. Lamangan would reprise this style in his Bien Aligtad, 1983.

PETA’s Mariang Aliw (Maria the Woman of Pleasure), 1983, a play on prostitutes, followed this trend. It also used slides of actual establishments and places where the trade flourished. The whole cast and crew actually developed the play. About 15 PETA actors conducted visits to these establishments, and observed and interviewed prostitutes. In the actual production, an offstage voice throwing questions to the characters onstage served as narrative frame and sequence guide, and the whole production appeared like an interview session with prostitutes, serving as a documentation of their lives and trade.

Tula-Dula (Poem-Play). Theater during martial law contributed one original genre to the rich tapestry of modern Philippine theater forms—the tula-dula. This is credited to the UP Repertory Company. A performance designed for mass actions and rallies, it features a narrator, who delivers the lines of the poem, and one or two movers miming the action of characters in the poem. The narrator generally uses a microphone or a megaphone for the huge audience to hear the play. The first tula-dula used a previously written poem, Jose Lacaba’s “Ang mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz” (The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz) for the performance. Eventually other poems were seen as good material for tula-dula mountings like Richie Valencia and Ed Vencio’s Mga Unang Araw sa Buhay ng Iskolar ng Bayan (First Few Days in the Life of a New Scholar of the People), 1976, which gave birth to the character Isko, the student in the state university. After its initial employment in 1975, the form developed and had many variations, and poems would be specifically written for stage mounting (Dacanay 2009) such as Titser ng Bayan (People’s Teacher), which was performed from the late 1970s to the early 1980s.

Dula-Awit-Sayaw (Dance Musicals). The 1983 PETA production Nukleyar! (Nuclear!) embodied a loosely strung rock band concert, with the singing accompanied by dancing and dramatic improvisations. Without a definite narrative spine, it projected a more issue-oriented production that highlighted the dangers confronting the Philippines with the Bataan nuclear power plant project. Similarly incorporating music, choreography, and dramatic scenes together, but with clearer and more solid narratives were Gines Tan’s Magsimula Ka (Make a Start), 1983, which was about fresh graduates pursuing dreams in spite of parental control, and Dong de los Reyes’s Bien Aligtad, 1985, which focused on the effects of militarization on slum dwellers. Theater artists from Mindanao explored this form as well. Tapping into the region’s rich culture, they came up with Maranatha, 1974, Halik sa Kampilan, 1978, Ranaw: Isang Alamat (Ranaw: A Legend), 1985, and Sinalimba, 1986, which all incorporated local music, costume, and dances into the narrative (Tiongson 1994b, 29).
Conclusion

Martial law was a historical condition imposed on the theater community in 1972. Before its imposition, a relatively good segment of that community had already become radicalized and had already succeeded in forming influential theater groups and networks, particularly in the National Capital Region, but eventually also in the regions. The vanguards and trainees of this advance force eventually reestablished their links and influence in the community when the imposition happened and remarkably led the community to a good fight and a good harvest. Some groups had more participation than others in this undertaking, some individuals were more prominent in battle, but the theater community was generally against martial rule.

The period from 1972 to 1986 may be seen as both protest and procreation. There was the very real battle against the dictatorship. The regions too fought, with very strong currents in Mindanao, Negros, and Bicol generally following Manila’s compass and trends. But it was also during this period that playwrights developed original works using indigenous languages, lore, narratives, themes, and issues. Viewed as solidifying and enriching the cultural component of nation building, these works could be seen as the period’s gain. The harvest to date still needs thorough documentation and publication. But enough material exists, already seen in subsequent productions or publications, even if so much data and artifacts, including texts, still have to be retrieved.

A vast, varied repertoire and vocabulary emerged during this period. Immersion in social and political realities, including the reality that was the dictatorship and its oppressive character, unleashed the talent and resources of theater artists, individually and collectively. It certainly broadened the vocabulary of styles, trends, and forms of theater in the country. And with the success of the people’s theater, the MAKIISA events, as well as earlier achievements that reached national proportions, Philippine theater rooted in indigenous culture, enriched by outside influences, and conscious of the Filipino people it serves, prevailed.

article_title: Philippine Theater during the Fifth Republic (1986 Onward)
