Introduction

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, theater became less obviously political since the main target of artists in the 1970s, the deposed Ferdinand Marcos, was no longer a motivating factor. This did not mean, however, that artists stopped creating or staging works about current events. Theater artists continued to revive old works and create new plays or musicals that criticized, satirized, or shed new light on societal ills.

In fact, in the months following the EDSA Revolt, theater artists promptly mounted productions in response to this new chapter in the country’s history. The Philippine Educational Theater Association’s (PETA) Panata sa Kalayaan (Oath to Freedom), a compendium of stories about the Filipino people during the Marcos regime, was staged at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The fact that a group like PETA was able to perform at the CCP was a symbolic “takeover” of the center in that the latter had previously shut out local groups and critical works in favor of foreign acts and what were perceived to be “high art” productions. Panata was one of the first productions to be staged after martial law and went on to tour in North America, Europe, and Asia, thereby introducing contemporary Philippine theater to international audiences.

Later that year, Bulwagang Gantimpala staged Bienvenido Noriega’s Bongbong at Kris (Bongbong and Kris) also at the CCP. The third prize winner of that year’s CCP Playwriting Contest, the satire is an imagined romance between deposed Marcos’s son Bongbong and the new president Corazon Aquino’s daughter Kris, signaling in a way that it was all right to start laughing again. Repertory Philippines (Rep) staged Evita, the musical based on the life of Eva Peron, previously banned in the country as its story line had uncanny parallelisms with Imelda Marcos. In the regions, Negros Theatre League started staging productions that aimed to show that nothing had changed despite having a new government.

In 1989, Lea Salonga and several other Filipino theater actors were cast in the mega-musical Miss Saigon at London’s West End. Salonga was later cast in the Broadway staging as well. Publicity for the show highlighted Filipino talent: there were anecdotes of how the producers searched all over the world to find the perfect actors for the roles only to find what they needed in the Philippines. This resulted in increased media exposure for Philippine theater, creating more awareness of Filipino talent among international audiences as well as among the Filipino public.

The restoration of democracy eventually led to social and economic development—factors that helped spur growth for the country and, as a result, in the theater scene as well. In the decades following 1986, new Filipino plays and musicals in Filipino and other Philippine languages, as well as in English, were created and staged. Theater programs in the academe and theater companies, professional and otherwise, provided more and more opportunities for artists to perform a variety of genres and materials. New companies and groups were formed, new performance spaces were built, audience numbers grew, and interest in the theater arts was nurtured.

 

Institutions and Groups

Government Organizations. After 1986, public and private institutions and organizations went through reorganization or were established, reflecting a renewed and growing interest in Philippine arts. These groups have helped steer the direction of Philippine theater these past few decades.

The Cultural Center of the Philippines reevaluated its mandate under Ma. Teresa Escoda-Roxas and Nicanor G. Tiongson, whose leadership from 1986 to 1994 envisioned the creation of a national culture, focusing on four main points: Filipinization—that is, prioritizing Filipino works over foreign acts and emphasizing the staging of new Filipino works; democratization or reaching out to all socioeconomic strata and sectors and not just the elite audiences of the martial law years, and allowing more groups and artists to use CCP venues and resources; decentralization, which means rallying all regions and sectors to showcase their own cultures and contribute to the creation of a national Filipino culture; and reorientation of international exchanges to showcase Filipino artists abroad.

From simply being a venue for performances, CCP transformed into the national coordinating center for the arts. To foster pride in the rich heritage of Filipino artistry, CCP renamed its venues and surrounding streets after Filipino artists. The Main Theater was named Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo in honor of the composer; the Little Theater, Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino after the playwright and director; and the Bulwagang Gantimpala, Tanghalang Huseng Batute, the pen name of poet Jose Corazon de Jesus. A street was named after Cebuano playwright Vicente Sotto. CCP also revived the National Artist awards. Theater artists who have received this honor since then include Atang dela Rama, 1987; Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero (posthumous), 1997; Rolando Tinio (posthumous), 1997; Daisy Avellana, 1999; Severino Montano (posthumous), 2001; and Salvador Bernal, 2003.

As part of the center’s decentralization efforts, the CCP established arts councils in the regions, developed satellite venues in select cities all over the country, created nationwide events and festivals, and through its Outreach and Exchange Department, organized nationwide tours of performances from Manila to the regions and vice versa. Plays such as Tanghalang Pilipino’s (TP) Mac Malicsi and Tonyo, Pepe at Pule (Tonyo, Pepe, and Pule) were toured in the regions while shows like Marawi-based Sining Kambayoka’s Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss on the Sword) was brought to Manila, Vigan, Laoag, Baguio, Pampanga, Batangas, and Sorsogon. TP was also sent to Paris in 1994 to perform the komedya Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira).

CCP created the National Theater Festival, gathering theater practitioners from across the country to showcase their best works and network with each other. The first festival, titled “Unang Tagpo” (First Scene), was held in 1992. This was followed by “Ikalawang Tagpo” (Second Scene), 1996, and “Ikatlong Tagpo” (Third Scene), 2004. The festival held in 2012, billed “Ikaapat na Tagpo: Ang Bagong Yugto” (Fourth Scene: The New Act), included groups from the regions such as the Integrated Performing Arts Guild of Mindanano State University–Iligan Institute of Technology, Uwahig (Mindanao Flood Story); Kabpapagariya Ensemble of Mindanao State University–General Santos City, Dula Ta (Let’s Play); The Xavier Stage of Cagayan de Oro, Isa Pang Kawing (One More Link); Bohol Antequera, Maribojoc Cultural Collective, Teatro Bol-Anon from Bohol, Duha Ka Alimpo sa Habagat (Two Eyes of the Monsoon Storm); Kanlaon Theater Guild of Colegio San Agustin–Bacolod, Circulo; Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation from Bulacan, which staged Kakarong: The Musical; as well as National Capital Region-based groups Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (DUP) of the University of the Philippines (UP), Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira); Tanghalang Ateneo of Ateneo de Manila University, Sintang Dalisay (Pure Love); PETA, William; Gantimpala Theater Foundation, Sayaw ng mga Senyorita (Dance of the Maidens); Tanghalang Pilipino, Stageshow; Triumphant People’s Evangelistic Theater Society (Trumpets), Mind’s Eye; Sipat Lawin Ensemble, Battalia Royale (Battle Royale) and Haring Tubul, an adaptation of Ubu Roi; Silly People’s Improv Theater, D4: The Next Generation; and ventriloquists Ony Carcamo and Wanlu, Bata Batute (Child Batute).

Using an earlier proposal from the Concerned Artists of the Philippines, CCP helped prepare the proposal for a ministry of culture, which became the basis for the Presidential Commission on Culture and Arts (PCCA) created by Executive Order 118 in 1987, and later, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), created via Republic Act 7356, which replaced the PCCA in 1992.

The NCCA makes cultural policies, coordinates and gives grants for the preservation, development, and promotion of Philippine arts and culture, and administers the National Endowment Fund for Culture and the Arts. Through its National Committee on Dramatic Arts, it has given grants to theater productions, conferences, and workshops, and established Tanghal: The National University and College Theater Festival in 2007. Tanghal has since been a gathering of youth theater groups based in colleges and universities who interact with each other, exchange ideas and processes, and showcase outstanding works. It was held at the University of San Agustin, Iloilo, in 2007; West Mindanao State University, Zamboanga, 2008; Colegio de San Juan de Letran, Laguna, 2009; in various venues in Manila, 2010; and University of St. La Salle, Bacolod, 2011. In 2012, the festival was held in four sites: Benguet State University for Luzon; Siliman University, Dumaguete, for the Visayas; Mindanao State University, General Santos City, for Mindanao; and Polytechnic University of the Philippines for the National Capital Region.

Artist Networks and Alliances. In 1989, under the guidance of Rene O. Villanueva and coordinator Charley de la Paz, Writer’s Bloc was formed to provide PETA’s in-house writers support for their playwriting, through feedback sessions and workshops to rehearsals and marketing assistance. Rody Vera became executive director after De la Paz’s death in 1995. The group organized and hosted the first National Playwrights Conference in 1997 and held the annual Dulaang Laboratoryo Festival with PETA from 1998 to 2007. In 2004, Writer’s Bloc became an independent group.

In 1994, Salvador Bernal formed the Philippine Association of Theatre Designers and Technicians (PATDAT), the Philippine chapter of the International Organisation of Scenographers, Theatre Architects and Technicians, more popularly known by its French name’s acronym OISTAT (Organisation Internationale des Scénographes, Techniciens et Architectes de Théatre). Bernal served as PATDAT president until his death in 2011, and Leo Rialp succeeded him. PATDAT has sent representatives to international production design exhibitions such as the World Stage Design 2005 in Toronto, Canada, featuring Joaquin Jose Aranda’s 2001 lighting design for Turn Up the Quiet, Just Dance, which was a jury selection for exhibition, and Gino Gonzales’s set design for Spolarium, 2003, which won the silver prize; and the World Stage Design 2009 in Seoul, Korea, featuring the winning sound designs of Jed Balsamo for Amihan, 2008, and Jethro Joaquin’s for Hamlet, 2008.

In 1997, Alyansa ng mga Manggagawang Pangkultura sa Kamaynilaan at mga Karatig-Pook Inc was formed. This group is a network of individual artists and groups, high school and college students, out-of-school youth, church workers, teachers, industrial workers, and freelance artists from Metro Manila.

In the same year, heads of different theater groups in Metro Manila came together to form Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group (Philstage), the country’s only organization of professional performing arts companies. Founding member companies include PETA, Rep, Ballet Philippines, Gantimpala Theater Foundation, Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit, TP, Trumpets, Actor’s Actors Inc, and Ballet Manila. Zeneida Amador served as founding chairperson until her death in 2004. Celeste Legaspi served as president until 2006; Dennis Marasigan, 2007-8; Fernando Josef, 2009-10; and Audie Gemora, 2011-16. In the 2010s, new members included 9 Works Theatrical, Philippine Ballet Theater, Philippine Opera Company, Red Turnip Theater, Resorts World Manila’s Full House Theater Company, and Stages Production Specialists.

Philstage has organized arts festivals in various venues in Metro Manila and at the Subic Bay Arts Center. To celebrate the 1998 Philippine Centennial, it produced Buhay! (Live!), a theater festival of 100 performances in Shangri-La Plaza Mall. Together with the NCCA, it created a theater appreciation program that ran from 2000 to 2004, which offered free viewing of plays, musicals, and dance performances to public school students and teachers. In 2008, it formed Gawad Buhay! to celebrate excellence in productions staged by its member companies. The first awarding ceremony was held in 2009, honoring productions done in 2008.

Networks in the regions were also formed. In 1987, the Philippine Coordinating Council for People’s Cultures (Bugkos) was established. A network of some 200 cultural groups involved in theater, literature, dance, music, and visual arts nationwide, Bugkos has its national secretariat in Metro Manila and has networks in different regions: TADEC in the Cordillera, BUSLO in Central Luzon, SINING in Metro Manila, Makabayang Alyansa sa Sining Anakpawis–Timog Katagalugan in Southern Tagalog, Kaborongan in Bicol, and Mindanao Community Theatre Network and Mindanao Center for People’s Culture in Mindanao.

In Luzon, Arts Research and Training Institute in Southern Tagalog Inc (ARTIST Inc) was established in Laguna in 1987 by sectoral groups and community-based organizations in Southern Tagalog. The network aims to provide opportunities to conduct arts trainings and cultural research for their productions. In the Visayas, Dungog Alliance of Cultural Organizations was established in 1986, and it includes groups from Samar, Leyte, Cebu, Negros, Bohol, and Panay. In 1997, Teatrokon Western Visayas Theater Network was also established.

In 1994, Mindanao Community Theatre Network, which was founded in 1984, changed its name to Mindulani. Member groups include school-based theater groups such as Sining Kambayoka, Integrated Performing Arts Guild, Kabpapagariya Ensemble, and Sining Theresian; and other groups such as Kariala Music Traditions, Iligan City; Kalambagohan Repertory, Cagayan de Oro City; Sinag, Butuan City; and Kaliwat Theatre Collective, Davao City. Mindulani has organized the Angat Mindulani Project. Its first phase in 2011 had arts management and improvisational theater workshops at La Salle University, Ozamis City. Its second phase in 2012 was a directing workshop at Mindanao State University (MSU)–Iligan Institute of Technology. And its third phase in 2013 at MSU-General Santos City included a forum that featured speakers Steven Patrick Fernandez, Sunnie Noel, Fr Rudolfo Galenzoga, and Nestor Horfilla.

In 1995, the Luzon Theater Network held the first Lusong Theater Festival. It included Dap-ayan ti Kultura iti Kordilyera from the Cordillera region; Teatro Amamugis from Central Luzon; Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation from Malolos, Bulacan; and ARTIST Inc, Kaboronyogan Bicol Cultural Alliance, and Community Based Theater Group from Bicol.

School Theater Groups. School theater groups continue to provide students with opportunities to explore and train in theater arts. In Metro Manila, the University of the Philippines has DUP. It handles the UP Playwrights Theater, which showcases new works, and Dulaang Laboratoryo, which stages student thesis productions. UP also has UP Repertory Company and UP Theater Council. Other groups in Metro Manila include Ateneo de Manila University’s Tanghalang Ateneo, Blue Repertory, and Enterteynment para sa Tao, Bayan, Lansangan, at Diyos (ENTABLADO); University of Santo Tomas’s Teatro Tomasino and Artisang Artlets; De La Salle University’s Harlequin Theater Guild; Polytechnic University of the Philippines’s Molave and Sining Lahi Polyrepertory; Philippine Normal University’s The Thespian Society; De La Salle–College of Saint Benilde’s Dulaang Filipino; and University of Makati’s Collective Arts of Students and Thespians.

Regional school theater groups continue to flourish. In Luzon, there are Tanghalang Saint Louis University in Baguio City and Tambayo Cultural Group in Pangasinan State University. In the Visayas, University of San Agustin Little Theater, Iloilo City; Performance Laboratory and Maskara Theater Ensemble, University of St. La Salle Bacolod; Kalingaw Ang Teatro Hiligaynon, West Negros University, Bacolod, Negros Occidental; Portal Players, Silliman University, Dumaguete, Negros Oriental; Antequera, Punta Cruz, Cortes, and Lincod Cultural Collectives and Teatro Bol-Anon, Bohol.

In Mindanao, there are Sining Theresian Ensemble of St. Theresa College, Tandag City, Surigao del Sur; and Ateneo de Cagayan in Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental. MSU has Sining Kambayoka (MSU-Marawi City), Integrated Performing Arts Guild (MSU-Iligan Institute of Technology), Kabpapagariya Ensemble (MSU-General Santos City), and Sining Kandidilimudan (MSU-Maguindanao).

Private Groups. In 1987, CCP’s resident theater groups Teatro Pilipino and Bulwagang Gantimpala left the auspices of the center. Tanghalang Pilipino was formed with Nonon Padilla as founding artistic director and served as the resident theater group for the CCP. Teatro Pilipino was active until 1992. Bulwagang Gantimpala was renamed Gantimpala Theater Foundation and changed its repertoire: instead of staging new plays, it now stages plays based on the high school curriculum such as Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), El Filibusterismo (Subversion), Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird).

In 1988, Lito Casaje and Boy Noriega founded Dramatis Personae while Celeste Legaspi and Girlie Rodis founded Musical Theater Philippines (Musicat). New companies formed in the following decades include Trumpets, founded by Audie Gemora, 1990; Actor’s Actors Inc by Bart Guingona, 1992; New Voice Company by Monique Wilson, 1994; Atlantis Productions by Bobby Garcia, 1999, renamed Atlantis Theatricals Entertainment Group, 2015; 9 Works Theatrical by Robbie Guevara, 2009; and Sipat Lawin Ensemble (SLE) by JK Anicoche, 2009. Resorts World Manila started producing musicals in 2011 and went on to establish Full House Theater Company in 2014, naming Michael Williams and Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo as co-artistic directors. Red Turnip Theater Company was founded by Ana Abad Santos, Topper Fabregas, Jenny Jamora, Cris Villonco, and Rem Zamora in 2013.

SLE became part of the pool of companies that stage productions in Filipino such as PETA, Gantimpala, and TP. The rest of the new companies stage productions in English, usually licensed plays and musicals from the United States and the United Kingdom. Trumpets stages original English productions, usually musicals, albeit adapted from foreign materials. Notably, a majority of the theater artists who have formed these companies are alumni of Repertory Philippines.

Community theater groups in Metro Manila include Tanghalang Santa Ana and Teatro Sambisig in Manila; Samahan ng Sinakulista ng Pio del Pilar in Makati; Samahang Nazareno Inc in Cainta, Rizal; and Komedya ng Don Galo, Komedya ng San Dionisio, and Kudyapi Community Theater League in Parañaque.

Activist theater group Peryante, established in 1983, disbanded in 1987. Interest and sociopolitical groups include Dukha-Dulaang Habagat, composed of urban poor and fishport workers; Tanghalan ng Maralitang Tagalunsod, urban poor; Teatro Akebono of the Development Action for Women Network, and Gabriela Cultural Group, women; Tanghalang Silangan and Teatro Pabrika, factory workers. Teatro Pabrika, founded in 1990, integrates songs in union meetings and picket lines or mounts productions advocating better working conditions for workers.

Private theater groups in Luzon include Obon Di Malayad based in Lubon, Mountain Province; Tropang Komedya ng Baler in Aurora; and Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna and Komedya ng Pakil, both in Laguna. The Community Based Theater Group is an alliance of theater groups from Sorsogon. In the Visayas, there are San Antonio Cultural Group in Antique; and Dagway Sigmahanon in Capiz, founded 2000. In Mindanao are Kaliwat Theater Collective in Davao City, founded 1987; Kulturang Atin Foundation in Davao City; Kariala Music Traditions in Iligan City; Kalambagohan Repertory in Cagayan de Oro City; Educational Discipline in Culture and Arts for Development and Services in the Agusan-Surigao provinces; Sinag, Maskara Theater Guild, and Artists Quarter, all in Butuan City.

Theater Groups Abroad. Filipino theater groups have been established abroad. Notably, the theater artists involved in the founding of three Filipino-American theater groups are Filipino immigrants who mostly have had training with PETA or the University of the Philippines.

Ma-Yi Theater Company was formed in New York in 1989, with Chito Jao Garces as founding artistic director, followed by Ralph Peña in 1995. The group expanded into an Asian-American theater group in 1998. It has staged Ralph Peña’s Flipzoids and Lonnie Carter’s The Romance of Magno Rubio. The company won the 2010 Drama Desk Award for Theater Excellence.

In San Francisco, Teatro ng Tanan (TnT) was established in 1988 by a group of immigrant theater artists, with the help of Chris Millado. It produced original plays focusing on immigrant experiences and had outreach performances for low-income audiences such as Filipino World War II veterans. The group was active until 2001.

In 1993, stand-up comic Al Manalo, with other Filipino-American comedians, created the sketch comedy group Tongue in a Mood. In 1997, Manalo included actors from TnT for its first major production at Bindlestiff Studio, a black box arts space and theater venue he discovered when he watched a one-woman play by Lorna Aquino Chui-Velasco, an actress who had trained at Bindlestiff as a teenager. Manalo and his wife Joyce Juan took over the management of the studio in 1998, developing its programming to nurture and celebrate Filipino-American performing artists. Since then, Bindlestiff Studio has produced original plays, music festivals, stand-up and sketch comedy shows, dance, visual and video arts all created by Filipino Americans. Their productions include the PiNoise Pop Music Festival, the FOB Show, the Bakla Show (Gay Show), the Love Edition, and Stories High, a culmination of acting, writing, and directing workshops offered each season.

In Chicago, CIRCA Pintig theater group was founded in 1991. Initially as Pintig Cultural Group, it mounted America Is in the Heart for its inaugural production. The Center for Immigrant Resources and Community Arts (CIRCA) joined forces with Pintig in 2006, and the group has staged Bells of Balangiga, Nanay Isog and Her Children, Sky Legends, Dreamweavers, and Allos: The Story of Carlos Bulosan.

Meanwhile, in Toronto, Canada, the Carlos Bulosan Cultural Workshop was formed by Martha Ocampo and Fely Villasin in 1982. It became a theater group—the Carlos Bulosan Theater—in 1984. It has staged productions such as Cardin, If My Mother Could See Me Now/Inay Kung Alam Mo Lang, Home Sweet Home, Images of 1896, and The Romance of Magno Rubio.

 

Education and Training

Theater as a college degree has been offered by UP’s Department of Speech Communication and Theater Arts since the mid-1970s. In the 1990s, it started offering a certificate program in theater. Schools that began to offer theater-related courses after 1986 include Polytechnic University of the Philippines, with its bachelor of arts in theater arts; De La Salle–College of Saint Benilde, with its technical theater and production design courses; Ateneo de Manila University, with its bachelor of fine arts, major in theater arts, with concentrations in acting, directing, technical theater, drama text and performance, and theater history and criticism; and Meridian International College (Mint College), with its bachelor of arts in theater arts. The Philippine High School for the Arts, established in 1978 via Presidential Decree 1287, continues to offer arts-focused secondary education.

Theater artists and scholars continue to travel to other countries to study directing, acting, playwriting, and other disciplines, some taking short courses or workshops and some obtaining college, masteral, or doctoral degrees. Some of these artists do so under scholarships or grants from organizations such as the Philippine-American Educational Foundation, the Fulbright Program, Japan Foundation, and the Asian Cultural Council.

Some of the artists who have studied abroad after 1986 include Mio Infante, Wimbledon School of Art for set design/production design/scenography; Clint Ramos, New York University (NYU); Gino Gonzales, NYU; Josefina Estrella for directing, Columbia University; Chris Millado for performance studies, NYU; Glenn Sevilla Mas for playwriting, Catholic University of America; Barbara Tan-Tiongco for technical theater, Yale University; Ana Valdez Lim for acting, Juilliard School; and Missy Maramara for performance, University of Arkansas. Scholars who have focused on theater studies and related subject matter include Vanessa Banta, master of arts in theatre studies, Florida State University and Performance Studies, NYU; and Sir Anril Tiatco, master of arts in theater studies, National University of Singapore.

 

Venues and Spaces

Except for theater companies based in institutions like the CCP or UP that would have easy access to performance spaces in and around their respective buildings, theater companies in general need to rent spaces such as proscenium theaters or art gallery spaces. PETA is distinct in that it is the only company, thus far, that has been able to own its land and building in Quezon City starting 2005, after it moved out of its original venue, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, a former Spanish garrison in Intramuros, Manila.

There are many venues commonly used by theater companies in Metro Manila. In Manila, there are the Philamlife Auditorium, and Manila Metropolitan Theater or Tanghalang Pangkalakhan ng Maynila until it closed in 1996; in Pasay, Aliw Theater and Star Theater; Rizal Theater at the Makati Commercial Center until it was demolished in 1991, Onstage Theater at the Greenbelt 1 Mall, and Carlos P. Romulo Auditorium at the RCBC Plaza Building; in Quezon City, PETA-PHINMA Theater (a black-box theater) at the PETA Theater Center, the Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio Papet Teatro-Museo, and the Armed Forces of the Philippines Theater in Camp Aguinaldo; in San Juan, Music Museum and Teatrino; in Pasig, Meralco Theater and William J. Shaw Theater in Shangri-La Plaza Mall from 1992 until it closed in 2002. In the 2010s, new venues were established such as Whitespace (a multipurpose warehouse) and PowerMac Center Spotlight Theater at Circuit Makati Mall, both in Makati; Newport Performing Arts Theater at Resorts World Manila and the Theater at Solaire at Solaire Resort and Casino, both in Parañaque; and Kia Theater, formerly the movie theater New Frontier Theater, in Quezon City.

 

Research, Publications, Conferences

Filipino scholars continue to write books and papers that have been published in academic journals, included in anthologies, or presented in conferences or symposia. Some of the published works in the late 1980s are Jean G. Edades’s Onstage and Offstage, 1983; Wilhelmina Ramas et al.’s Philippine Drama: Twelve Plays in Six Languages, 1987; and Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Fist: Literature of Protest 1970-1986), 1987, edited by Alfredo Navarro Salanga et al.

From 1986 to 1994, under the editorship of its artistic director Nicanor G. Tiongson, CCP published the 28-part Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art) series, 1989-94, consisting of 30 monographs and video-documentaries on the Philippine arts; the 10-volume CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994; anthologies like Kamao (Fist), 1987, Himalay: Kalipunan ng mga Pag-aaral kay Balagtas (Gleanings: Anthology of Studies on Balagtas), 1988, and Unang Tagpo (First Scene), 1992; and the journal Ani (Harvest).

In the 1990s, Tiongson conceived the Panitikan series of books on theater from different regions, with editorial supervision for translation by Bienvenido Lumbera: Zarzuelang Iloko (Iloko Zarzuela), 1993; Dulaang Hiligaynon (Hiligaynon Theater), 1996; Sarswelang Pangasinan (Pangasinan Sarsuwela), 1996; and Dulaang Cebuano (Cebuano Theater), 1997. Other research and publications in the 1990s include Clarita Filipinas’s Lineyte-Samarnon Zarzuela (1899-1977): History and Aesthetics, 1991; Doreen Fernandez’s Palabas: Essays on Philippine Theater History, 1996; and Tiongson’s Philippine Theater: History and Anthology, 1999, with volumes on the komedya and the sinakulo.

The following were published in the 2000s: Wilhelmina Ramas’s Studies in Pre-War: Sugbuanon Theatre (The First Series), 2001, and Apolonio Chua’s Simulain: Dulambayan ng Manggagawa sa Konteksto ng Militanteng Kilusang Unyonismo (1980-1994) (Beginnings: People’s Theater of Workers in the Context of the Militant Labor Unions [1980-1994]), 2009. In the 2010s, A Reader in Philippine Theater: History and Criticism, edited by Jonathan Chua and Rosario Cruz-Lucero, 2014, and Sir Anril Tiatco’s Entablado: Theaters and Performances in the Philippines, 2015, were released.

There have also been a number of unpublished studies—theses and dissertations—especially on the folk forms using various approaches. Some of the topics include traditional theater forms like the moryonan, the reenactment of Longhino’s role in the Passion of the Christ, and balagtasan, a debate done in verse; rituals such as maytinis, a dramatic retelling of Saint Joseph and Virgin Mary’s search in Bethlehem for a place to stay, and the Turumba Festival, a singing and dancing procession in honor of the Blessed Mary of Sorrows; theater history such as theater during the martial law period; and regional theater such as theater in Negros.

In 2008, UP hosted Komedya Fiesta, which included a conference that featured speakers such as Nicanor G. Tiongson, Resil Mojares, and Gabino Ponce Herrero. Then in 2009, the university organized the National Sarsuwela Festival, which also included a conference that had speakers such as Tiongson, Javier Suarez-Pajares, Cecilia Locsin-Nava, and Ramon Santos. In 2011, NCCA and Teatro Sambisig organized Tanghalin ang Tanghalan: National Conference on Theater Aesthetics at the CCP. The conference had speakers such as Tiongson, Jerry Respeto, Bienvenido Lumbera, Leoncio Deriada, Prospero Covar, Priscelina Legasto, Lulu Torres-Reyes, Orlando Magno, Nestor Horfilla, Lutgardo Labad, Roberto Mendoza, and Manny Pambid.

 

Theater Forms

Traditional and Classic Forms. Traditional and classic theater forms, such as the komedya, sinakulo, and sarsuwela, continue to be staged in the regions and in urban settings such as Metro Manila. New groups that stage these classic forms continue to be established as new works continue to be created as well.

The komedya continues to find new incarnations. In 1992, Komedya ng San Dionisio was invited to attend workshops at the CCP to update this traditional form by writing new works using the community’s aesthetic standards; using relevant themes to replace the theme of Muslim conversion to Christianity; modernizing the form by tightening plots; and preserving characteristic features such as verse, choreography, and conventional romantic, spectacular, and epic elements (Fernandez 2004, 71-73). The workshop resulted in the staging of Ang Bagong Prinsipe Rodante (The New Prince Rodante) in San Dionisio, Parañaque, and at the CCP.

In 1994, Jonas Sebastian directed Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura) as a komedya in the playground of Dongalo Elementary School. Students from the school were cast, Sebastian wrote the script, and Salvador Bernal designed the sets and costumes. Ballet Philippines’s Nonoy Froilan and Komedya ng San Dionisio’s Rodante Hernandez choreographed the marchas (marches) and batallas (battles) using props and movements from indigenous dances such as sakuting, maglalatik, and singkil while incorporating modern dances such as cha-cha and boogie and music such as rap.

In 2005, Gantimpala Theater began staging its annual production of Florante at Laura as a komedya, with Tony Espejo directing, using Virgilio Almario’s script, and with movements researched by choreographer Ramon A. Obusan from different locales such as San Dionisio, Parañaque; Nabuan, Isabela; and Batanes. Later Gantimpala productions of Florante at Laura retained the komedya format while using a new libretto by Boni Ilagan, with music by Toni Muñoz. In 2007, Jerry Respeto directed Rene Villanueva’s modern komedya Sandaang Panaginip (A Hundred Dreams), an allegory of the Marcos family first staged in 1981 for ENTABLADO.

In 2008, at the Komedya Fiesta, Komedya ng San Dionisio and Komedya ng Don Galo, both from Parañaque City, staged Max Allanigue’s Prinsipe Rodante (Prince Rodante); Comedia de Baler from Baler, Aurora, in Northern Luzon performed Isabelita Mejia’s Sakim na Pagmamahal (Greedy Love); Komedya San Miguel from Iligan City, Lanao del Norte, staged Ramon and Damaso Padilla’s Kinabuhi ni Senyor San Miguel (Life of Saint Michael); and DUP staged Sir Anril Tiatco’s adaptation of Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira).

In Los Angeles, USA, San Dionisio sa America was established in the late 1990s by families originally from San Dionisio, Parañaque City. It staged Ang Kambal ng Valencia (The Twins of Valencia), 2002; Hermano de la Paz, 2004; Nerissa at Bolivar (Nerrisa and Bolivar), 2006; and Mike Llamas’s Esperanza at Caridad (Esperanza and Caridad), 2008, and Mga Prinsesa ng Cordova (The Princesses of Cordova), 2010.

Regional sinakulo performances are still seen annually during Holy Week. The Sariaya Dramatic Guild in Sariaya, Quezon, has performed Santo Kristo: Isang Senakulo (Holy Christ: A Passion Play) since 1904. Sinakulo have been held in several barrios in Malolos, Bulacan, since the 1910s and in San Pedro Cutud, San Fernando, Pampanga, since the 1950s. Ang Pagtaltal sa Balaan Bukid (The Passion of Christ at the Holy Mountain) has been staged in Jordan, Guimaras, since 1975. In Metro Manila, sinakulo have been performed since 1902 in different barangays such as in Malibay, Pasay; in Cainta, Rizal, by Krus sa Nayon Incorporated since 1904 and by Samahang Nazareno since 1960; and in Mandaluyong by Samahang Kabataan ng San Roque Senakulista ng Barangka since 1965. Newer stagings of the sinakulo include Martir sa Golgota (Martyr at Golgotha) in Santa Ana by Tanghalang Santa Ana since 1989; and Ang Tagapagligtas (The Savior) in Morong, Rizal, by Pangkalinangang Kilusan ng mga Taga-Morong since 1993. In Quezon City, Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas has staged Papet Pasyon (The Passion of Jesus Christ in Puppetry), the only children’s puppet sinakulo in the country, since 1985.

Sarsuwela, the indigenized Spanish zarzuela (play with music), continues to be staged in Ilocos by Paat Dramatic Guild in Bantay and St. Catherine Zarzuela Group in Santa Catalina; in Pangasinan by Tamayo Stage Troupe in Santa Barbara and by Baay Dramatic Association in Lingayen; and in Iloilo by UP Visayas Alumni Theatre Company in Miag-ao. From 1986 to the mid-1990s, the local government of Silay and the Silay City Arts Foundation sponsored an annual sarsuwela competition. In 1994, Tambayo Cultural Group staged a Pangasinan sarsuwela titled Sirena: Pangasinan Myths and Legends in Lingayen.

Starting 1987, Tanghalang Pilipino, following the CCP’s directive of revitalizing traditional forms, has revived and staged existing sarsuwela such as Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1987; Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1989; Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1994; and Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1995. It also staged new sarsuwela like Pilipinas circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907) by Nicanor Tiongson, music by Lutgardo Labad, Lucien Letaba, and Louie Pascasio in 1992, 1993, and 2007. This last play was premiered by PETA in 1982.

In 1998, the National Centennial Commission hosted the Centennial Literary Prize. First prize winner for the sarsuwela category was Mario O’Hara’s Palasyo ni Valentin (Palace of Valentin), music by Minda Azarcon, staged by PETA that same year. There was a three-way tie for second prize: George de Jesus’s Paglayang Minamahal (Beloved Freedom), music by Jesse Lucas, staged by Tanghalang Pilipino in 2000; Bienvenido Lumbera’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), music by Lucien Letaba, staged by DUP in 2002; and Melba Padilla Maggay’s Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (Nation: Just One Foot Left), music by Lucio San Pedro, staged by Institute for Studies in Asian Church and Culture in 2002.

Other new sarsuwela include Alejandro Roces’s Something to Crow About, 2006, based on his short story “My Brother’s Peculiar Chicken,” staged in Manila, 2006, and in New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco, 2007; Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), music by Joy Marfil, staged by DUP, 2007; Bonifacio Ilagan’s Ang Señorita at ang Hukbo (The Lady and the Soldier), music by Lucien Letaba, 2008.

At the National Sarsuwela Festival in 2009, the University of the East Drama Company staged Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation performed Walang Sugat, Far Eastern University’s Art Theatre Clinique performed Sa Bunganga ng Pating, UP in the Visayas Alumni Theatre Company presented Iloilo Sarswela: Padayon ang Istorya (Iloilo Sarsuwela: The Story Continues), and DUP staged Ang Kiri (The Flirt). In 2010, the University of the East Drama Company staged Miss Philippines for Tanghal, the NCCA-organized National University and College Theater Festival.

Western-Type Musicals. Filipino theater groups continue to stage classics and produce new works in the musical genre, combining influences from the traditional musical forms of sarsuwela, bodabil (indigenized vaudeville), and kundiman (classic love songs) even as they adopt and adapt new and developing forms, devices, and trends from around the world such as musicals, sung-through musicals, rock operas, and mega-musicals. PETA and Tanghalang Pilipino stage original musicals as part of their season.

History and its heroes always serve as inspirational subject matter for musicals. PETA staged 1896: The Musicale, 1995, a narrative about Emilio Jacinto, to commemorate the centennial of the Filipino’s revolt against colonial Spain. Musicat staged Alikabok (Dust), 1995, a play about the Katipunera Bising Vallejo. DUP staged Gabriela, 2005, which is about Gabriela Silang. TP staged Aguinaldo 1899: Ang Pagpatay kay Luna (Aguinaldo 1899: The Murder of Luna), 1998, which is about Emilio Aguinaldo; EJ: Ang Pinagdaanang Buhay nina Evelio Javier at Edgar Jopson (EJ: The Lives of Evelio Javier and Edgar Jopson), 2008, a jukebox musical about martial law activists Javier and Jopson that uses songs by the rock band The Dawn; San Andres B, 2013, which is about Andres Bonifacio; and Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior), 2015, which centers on Apolinario Mabini.

Jose Rizal and his novels also provide inspiration for theatrical works. DUP, for instance, staged Elias at Salome (Elias and Salome), 1996, while TP staged Noli Me Tangere, El Filibusterismo, and Ilustrado: Ang Buhay ni Rizal (Educated Native: The Life of Rizal). Musicat produced Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal? (Who Are You, Jose Rizal?), 1996.

Philippine literature originally written in English has inspired adaptations such as TP’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1988, and Banaag at Sikat (Glimmer and Light), 2010, a rock musical based on the novel by Lope K. Santos; Musicat’s Larawan (Portrait), 1997, based on Nick Joaquin’s play A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, and Fire Water Woman, 2000, based on Joaquin’s play Tatarin: A Witches’ Sabbath in Three Acts and on his short story “The Summer Solstice.”

Pop culture reflected in film andkomikshave also provided inspiration for musical adaptations. TP staged Himala: The Musical, 2000, based on the film of the same title, and Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal, 2006, based on the graphic novel, also of the same title. Musicat staged Kenkoy Loves Rosing, 1992, based on the komiks version. Bit by Bit Productions staged Maxie: The Musical, 2005, based on the film Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros). Viva Productions and Full House Theater Company has staged Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2015, based on the film and komiks version of the same title.

Musicals range from revivals of older musical genres to new and emerging forms. Bodabil tunes have been revisited in such musicals as Musicat’s Katy!, 1988, and TP’s Stageshow, 2012. But rap has also been used to comment on corruption as in TP’s Kleptomaniacs, 2014. PETA has staged musicals that talk about current events and issues, like Skin Deep, 2008, a dark comedy on the cosmetic surgery industry, and Care Divas, 2010, a play about a group of overseas Filipino workers who moonlight as cross-dressing performers. It has also staged Rak of Aegis, 2014, a jukebox musical using songs by rock band Aegis that touches on the hopes and frustrations of families in a fictitious barangay dealing with constant flooding.

Musicals with religious themes have also been staged. Magnificat, about the life of Jesus Christ as seen through the eyes of his mother, the Blessed Virgin Mary, written by Nestor Torre with music by Ryan Cayabyab, was staged from 1996 to 2012. Trumpets has produced evangelical musicals in English such as The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, 1997; The Little Mermaid, 2000; N.O.A.H. (No Ordinary Aquatic Habitat), 2009; and Bluebird of Happiness, 2013.

The pulse, emotions, and music of the streets also provide inspiration for performances. Teatro Pabrika, for instance, integrates songs in union meetings and picket lines or mounts productions advocating better working conditions for workers such as Haranang Bayan I (Serenade for the Nation I), 1991, Haranang Bayan II (Serenade for the Nation II), 1992, Kuwatro Kantos (Four Corners), 1995, and Ultimatum, 1998.

Rep and Atlantis are the most consistent in staging foreign musicals, usually from the United States and the United Kingdom. In the late 1980s, Repertory Philippines (Rep) did Evita, Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat, Little Shop of Horrors, Man of La Mancha, Nunsense, La Cage Aux Folles, and Kismet; in the1990s, Scrooge, The King and I, Grease, Fiddler on the Roof, Into the Woods, Les Miserables, The Wiz, My Fair Lady, Camelot, Once on This Island, Jesus Christ Superstar, Carousel, South Pacific, Annie, and Oliver!; in the 2000s, The Secret Garden, The Sound of Music, Altar Boyz, Disney’s Mulan, A Christmas Carol, and Sweeney Todd; and in the 2010s, Little Women, Jekyll & Hyde, The Wizard of Oz, Disney’s Camp Rock: The Musical, and Alice in Wonderland. Atlantis’s inaugural production was Rent in 1999. Since then it has staged, in the 2000s, Hedwig and the Angry Inch, The Rocky Horror Show, Dreamgirls, Urinetown, Disney’s Beauty and the Beast, Avenue Q, Hairspray, Spring Awakening, and Legally Blonde; in the 2010s, Disney’s Little Mermaid, Next to Normal, In the Heights, Rock of Ages, Disney’s Aladdin, Piaf, Carrie, The Addams Family, Ghost: The Musical, and Shrek. Rep and Atlantis have also toured their productions in other Asian cities such as Hong Kong, Singapore, and Jakarta.

In 1999, SK Productions staged Rama at Sita (Rama and Sita) at the UP Theater. It was a large-scale musical based on the Indian epic Ramayana and was reported to have cost 40 million pesos to produce. From 2000 to 2001, Miss Saigon was staged in Manila, with Lea Salonga and Isay Alvarez reprising their roles as Kim and Gigi, respectively, in the musical’s 1989 world premiere at the West End. This production took over the usual theater and rehearsal venues of CCP resident companies Tanghalang Pilipino and Ballet Philippines, prompting strong reactions from the local theater community about how a foreign production was displacing local artists. A decade later, production company Concertus Manila produced the Manila run of the international production Cats, 2010, with Salonga as Grizabella, also at the CCP. This began what has become a consistent stream of international productions such as Phantom of the Opera, 2013, Wicked, 2014, and Chicago, 2015, proving that now there is a big enough audience in the Philippines and an economy strong enough to bring in touring productions in Manila, which provide stiff competition for local theater companies.

Straight Plays. Original plays continue to be created after 1986. In the 1990s, social and psychological realism in theater became more dominant as audiences became more interested in the characterizations and internal conflicts of characters than in political motifs that dominated the theater scene from 1972 to 1986. Tony Perez wrote plays that touch on middle-class characters dealing with the psychological underpinnings of love and loss such as Saan Ba Tayo Ihahatid ng Disyembre? (Where Will December Bring Us?), staged by PETA, and Oktubre, Noong Tayo’y Nagmamahalan Pa (October, When We Were Still in Love) and Nobyembre, Noong Akala Ko’y Mahal Kita (November, When I Thought I Love You), staged by TP.

Nonetheless, plays about the martial law years and its aftereffects, political activism, and human rights violations such as forced disappearances continued to be staged such as DUP’s Desaparecidos (Forced Disappearances); TP’s Maliw (Fade), Isang Araw sa Karnabal (A Day in the Carnival), and Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major); and Atlantis Productions’ Dogeaters.

Plays continued to find inspiration in history such as PETA’s Lakangbini (Las Viajeras/Oryang) and Ang Dalawang Buhay ni Plaridel (Almanac for Revolution), which were about Gregoria de Jesus and Marcelo del Pilar, respectively; TP’s Ang Paglilitis at Pagkamatay ni Jose Rizal: Mga Teksto at Mga Komentaryo (The Trial and Death of Jose Rizal: Texts and Commentaries), a play about Rizal, Kagila-gilalas na Kasinungalingan Tungkol sa Isang Kayumangging Bayan (Amazing Lies about a Brown Race), later retitled Kalantiaw, about Jose Marco’s Code of Kalantiaw hoax, and Isandaang Awit ni Mary Helen Fee (One Hundred Songs of Mary Helen Fee), about the Thomasite teacher; and DUP’s … And St. Louis Loves dem Filipinos, which was about how Filipinos were paraded at the 1904 World’s Fair, USA, Isang Panaginip na Fili (A Dreamed Subversion), which was inspired by Rizal’s novel, Teatro Porvenir (Theater of Tomorrow), about Andres Bonifacio, and Atang, about Atang de la Rama.

Playwrights continue to touch on a myriad of subject matters: Bayan-bayanan (Little Country) on Filipino diaspora abroad, Anatomiya ng Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption) on corruption, Ang Buhay Ay Pelikula (Life Is a Movie) on the movie industry, Kung Paano Ko Pinatay si Diana Ross (How I Killed Diana Ross) and Gee-Gee at Waterina (Gee-Gee and Waterina) on homosexuality, Welcome to Intelstar on the call center industry, Walang Kukurap (Let No One Blink) on government and politics, and Melanie on HIV.

In the regions, Community Based Theater Group based in Sorsogon staged productions such as An Tunay na Istorya san Sorsogon (The Real Story of Sorsogon), 1988; Si Bulusan nan si Agingay (Bulusan and Agingay), 1994; An Gugurang (Divine Being) and Kahadean ni Reyna Gayon (The Kingdom of Queen Gayon), 1996; and Ribonsinay (Mythical Bird), 2002. Kaliwat Theater Collective, Davao City, staged Nag-alintabong Kabilin (Burning Legacy), 1988; Sketches of Mindanao Experience, 1991; and Lem-a-feu sa Habagatan (Spirit of Paradise) and Siak sa Duha ka Damgo (Crack between Two Dreams), both in 1992.

In the late 1980s, other plays that have been staged or restaged by PETA throughout the years after 1986 include Sigwa (Storm), June Bride, Aray Ko! (Ouch!), Ang Monopolyo ni Su (The Monopoly of Su), Juan Tamban: Sion, Sion, Tama na, Sion (Sion, Sion, Stop It, Sion), Macli-ing, Ang Pagguho ng Troya (The Destruction of Troy), and Pangako ng Binhi (The Promise of Seed); in the 1990s, Bombita, Si Bodyok at si Ningning (Bodyok and Ningning), Misere Nobis (Have Mercy on Us), DH: Domestic Helper, Ang Alamat ni Limbaswang: Ang Batang Ampon ng mga Aswang (The Legend of Limbaswang: The Adopted Child of Shapeshifters), Ambon ng Kristal (The Crystal’s Drizzle), June at Johnny (June and Johnny), Mga Pusang Gala (Stray Cats), Tumawag kay Libby Manaoag (Call Libby Manaoag), Watawat (Flag), and Despedida de Soltera (Send-off Party for the Bride). In the 2000s, Dreamweavers, Strongboy, Deaf Boy and Girl in Abaya, Isang Libong Tula para sa Dibdib ni Dulce (One Thousand Poems for Dulce’s Bossom), Hans Christian Andersen Must Be Pinoy, and Don Q; in the 2010s, Belong Puti (White Veil), Si Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), and Ang Post Office (The Post Office).

DUP staged Engkantado (Fairy), Sakurahime, Drunkenness of Noah, Shadows of the Reef, Shock Value, Hinabing Pakpak ng Ating mga Anak (Woven Wings of Our Children), and Collection. TP staged plays such as Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), Wanted: Isang Tsaperon (Wanted: A Chaperone), Pugad (Nest), Besame Mucho (Kiss Me a Lot), White Love, Balota Queen (Ballot Queen), Sierra Lakes, and Bakit Wala Nang Nagtatagpo sa Philcoa Oberpas (Why Nobody Meets Anymore at the Philcoa Overpass).

In the 1990s to early 2000s, New Voice Company staged foreign English plays and musicals that highlighted women’s issues and gender issues such as Oleanna, Top Girls, The Blue Room, Falsettos, Stop Kiss, My Sister in this House, and Vagina Monologues. In 2000, writer, artist, and publisher Gilda Cordero-Fernando produced Luna: An Aswang Romance, having different visual artists design the costumes and casting actors from Filipino and English theater groups, a bold move at the time as actors of different companies did not usually cross over to other companies back then.

In 2005, Writer’s Bloc, in partnership with Tanghalang Pilipino, established the Virgin Labfest, a showcase of new plays developed by its members. What started as a festival of one-act plays has grown to include full-length plays and even musicals from both the group’s members and from submissions from the public. Some of the plays showcased in the festival would later on be produced by school-based groups or professional groups like TP. Members include award-winners Layeta Bucoy, Allan Lopez, Liza Magtoto, Nicolas Pichay, Dennis Teodosio, and Jose Victor Torres. Some of the prizewinning plays that underwent a Bloc reading and have been subsequently staged include Rene Villanueva’s Watawat (Flag), 2003; Rody Vera’s Mga Aswang sa Pahanon ng Digmaan (Shapeshifters in the Time of War), 2004; Magtoto’s Agnoia, 2004, and Paigan, 2009; Pichay’s Psychedelia Apokalipsis, 2004, and Tres Ataques de Corazon (Three Heart Attacks), 2006; Lopez’s Anatomiya ng Pag-ibig (Anatomy of Love), 2005, Masaganang Ekonomiya (Flourishing Economy), 2008, and Higit Pa Dito (More Than This), 2010; Teodosio’s Baka Sakali (Maybe), 2006; and Layeta Bucoy’s Ellas Inocentes (Innocent Girls), 2007, and Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan (Doc Resureccion: Will Heal the Nation), 2009.

Audiences are able to watch American and British plays in English as these are usually staged by Repertory Philippines, Actor’s Actors Inc, and Red Turnip Theater, with the latter two groups leaning more toward newer works.

Translations and Adaptations. Teatro Pilipino continued to stage Filipino translations of Western classics until it was dissolved in the early 1990s. PETA, TP, DUP, and Tanghalang Ateneo usually stage translations or adaptations of both Filipino works—either those originally written in English or in different media or formats such as novels or short stories, komiks, or film—and foreign plays from the ancient Greek dramatists to Shakespeare, and other playwrights from Asia, Europe, and the Americas.

The country’s vast and colorful legacy of epics, myths, and legends has given rise to adaptations such as PETA’s Ang Paglalakbay ni Radiya Mangandiri: Isang Pilipinong Ramayana (The Journey of Radiya Mangandiri: A Filipino Ramayana), 1993, partly based on the Maranao Darangen; TP’s Hudhud: The Slanting Dance of the Buliklik Hawks, 2004, based on the Ifugao epic; Tanghalang Ateneo’s Lam Ang, 2004, based on Biag ni Lam Ang (Life of Lam Ang); University of San Agustin Little Theater’s Tarangban (Cave), 2004, and ENTABLADO’s Labaw Donggon: Ang Banog ng Sanlibutan (Labaw Donggon: The Eagle of the World), both based on fragments of the 28,000-verse epic Hinilawod (Tales from the Mouth of the Halawod River) from Panay province; and TP’s Ibalong, 2013, Rody Vera’s adaptation of the extant 60 stanzas of the Ibalong origin myth of Bicol.

For translations or adaptations of Filipino literature, PETA staged productions such as Balete, based on F. Sionil Jose’s novel Tree; and Noli at Fili Dekada 2000 (Noli and Fili in the Decade of the 2000s) from the two Rizal novels. TP staged Sa Kuko ng Liwanag (In the Claws of Light), based on Edgardo Reyes’s book; Mga Ama, Mga Anak (Fathers and Sons), from Joaquin’s English play based on his short story “Three Generations”; Mass and Ang mga Huwad (The Pretenders), based on F. Sionil Jose’s novels; and Mga Gerilya sa Powell Street (Guerrillas on Powell Street), based on Benjamin Pimentel’s book. Film has also inspired adaptations such as PETA’s Minsa’y Isang Gamugamo (Once a Moth) and Bona, and TP’s Insiang.

Translations or Adaptations of Foreign Materials. From the ancient Greek and Roman dramas, TP staged Aristophanes’s Lysistrata and Euripides’s Troyanas (Trojan Women), while DUP staged Euripides’s Bacchae and Titus Maccius Plautus’s Ang Sundalong Hambog (The Braggart Soldier).

From Asian and Australian playwrights, TP staged Ang Taong Yungib ng Peking, based on Cao Yu’s Peking Man; Ang Ginintuang Bayan, based on Shusako Endo’s Golden Country; Speaking in Tongues/Salitang Dila, based on Andrew Bovell’s Speaking in Tongues; Bakeretta, based on Chong Wishing’s Ghost Operetta; and Rhythm Method (Kung Kailan Ka Pwede), based on Iijima Sanae and Suzuki Yumi’s Rhythm Method. DUP staged Laruang Kariton, based on Shudraka’s A Little Toy Cart, and Kanjincho, from Namiki Gohei’s kabuki play.

From European playwrights, PETA staged Ang Napigil Sanang Paghahari ni Arturo Ui, based on Bertolt Brecht’s The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui; Romulus D’Grayt, based on Friedrich Durrenmatt’s Romulus the Great; and Arbol de Fuego, based on Chekhov’s Cherry Orchard. In the 1980s, TP staged Super Pulis, based on Slawomir Mrozek’s Super Police; and Taga sa Panahon, based on Robert Bolt’s A Man for All Seasons. In the 1990s, TP had Ang Memorandum, based on Vaclav Havel’s The Memorandum; Lusak, based on Maxim Gorky’s The Lower Depths; Ang Balkonahe, based on Jean Genet’s The Balcony; Hedda Gabler, based on Henrik Ibsen’s work; Ripit Perpromans, based on Slawomir Mrozek’s Repeat Performance; Ang Kuripot, based on Moliere’s The Miser; and Scapino, based on Moliere’s Les Fourberries de Scaph. In the 2000s, TP produced Dakilang Hokus-Pokus, based on Eduardo de Filippo’s La Grande Magia; Ang Buhay at Trahedya ni Carmen, based on George Bizet’s Carmen; Drakula, based on Liz Lochhead’s Dracula; ’Yun Na Nga! (Kung ’Yun Na Nga), based on Luigi Pirandello’s Right You Are If You Think You Are; Ang Pokpok ng Ohio, based on Hanoch Levin’s The Whore from Ohio; Kudeta, based on Mustapha Matura’s The Coup; and Mansanas ng Disyerto, based on Savyon Liebrecht’s Apples from the Desert. In the 2010s, TP had Tatlong Mariya, based on Chekhov’s Three Sisters; and Juego de Peligro, based on Pierre Choderlos de Laclos’s Dangerous Liaisons.

DUP staged Lulu, based on Frank Wedekind’s Earth Spirit/Pandora’s Box; Amphitryon, based on Heinrich von Kleist’s work; Maria Stuarda, based on Friendrich von Schiller’s Maria Stuart; Ang Muntik Nang Di Mapigilang Paghahari ni Arturo Ui, based on Bertolt Brecht’s The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui; Tres Hermanas, based on Chekhov’s Three Sisters; and Alkalde ng Zalamea, based on Calderon de la Barca’s The Mayor of Zalamea. ENTABLADO staged Birheng Matimtiman (Steadfast Virgin), based on Niccolo Machiavelli’s La Mandragola.

From North and South American works, TP staged La Chunga, based on Mario Vargas Llosa’s work of the same title; Ang Ulo ni Pancho Villa, based on Luis Valdez’s The Shrunken Head of Panco Villa; Ang Romansa ni Magno Rubio, based on Lonnie Carter’s Romance of Magno Rubio, based on the short story of the same title by Carlos Bulosan; and Pahimakas sa Isang Ahente, based on Arthur Miller’s Death of a Salesman. DUP staged Misteryo ng Pumpon ng Rosas, based on Manuel Puig’s Mystery of the Rose Bouquet; Kamatayan at ang Binibini, based on Ariel Dorfman’s Death and the Maiden; Pagdating ng Daluyong, based on Eugene O’Neill’s The Iceman Cometh; and Sa Ngalan ng Anak, based on Arthur Miller’s All My Sons.

Translations and Adaptations of Shakespeare. Shakespeare’s works continue to be translated and adapted by playwrights and directors. These include Rolando Tinio’s Makbet (Macbeth), 1989; Bienvenido Lumbera’s Julio Cesar (Julius Caesar), 1991; Rody Vera and Joey Baquiran’s Antony at Cleopatra (Anthony and Cleopatra), 1996; Jun Lana’s Summer Dreamin’ (Midsummer Night’s Dream), 1998; Rogelio Sicat’s Otelo (Othello), 2000; Paul Dumol’s Hamlet, 2001; Joi Barrios’s Kwento ng Pag-ibig at Pagtataksil (meaning Tale of Love and Betrayal, based on The Winter’s Tale), 2001; Vim Nadera’s Ang Ligawang Ligaw (Love’s Labours’ Lost), 2002; Ron Capinding’s Pagpapaamo sa Maldita (Taming of the Shrew), 2002; Vera’s Ang Unos ( The Tempest ), 2003; Guelan Varela Luarca’s Komedya ng mga Napagkamalan (Comedy of Errors), 2009; Luarca and BJ Crisostomo’s Prospero (The Tempest), 2010; Luarca’s Trobol sa Troya (Troilus and Cressida), 2012; Lumbera’s Haring Lear (King Lear), 2012; Capinding’s Hakbang sa Hakbang (Measure for Measure), 2014; Nicolas Pichay’s Haring Lear (King Lear), 2015; and Om Velasco’s Troilus + Cressida (Troilus and Cressida), 2015.

Directorial adaptations include Jose Estrella’s staging of Tinio’s Makbet for DUP, 1995, with the narrative set in the Cordillera region; PETA’s Romeo at Julieta: Isang Komedi (Romeo and Julieta: A Comedy), 1998, a trilingual (English, Filipino, and Japanese) coproduction with Japan’s Black Tent Theater, with a Filipina Julieta and a Japanese Romeo; Chris Millado’s staging of Tinio’s Makbet for TP, 2000, with a pan-Asian production design by Salvador Bernal; Ricky Abad’s staging of Tinio’s Twelfth Night: Kung Ano’ng Ibigin (Twelfth Night: What You Will) for Tanghalang Ateneo, 2000, set in a fictitious Southeast Asian locale designed by Salvador Bernal; and Abad’s adaptation of Pagpapaamo sa Maldita (Taming of the Shrew) for TA, 2002, which he set in Bicol during the early US colonial period, with Petruchio as an American military officer and Katherina as the daughter of a Filipino merchant; and Herbert Go and Dulaang Sipat Lawin’s batch 2004’s R’meo Luvs Dew’lhiett, 2004, an adaptation of Tinio’s Romeo at Julieta, which was set in a local barangay and had an updated text using contemporary slang. Go restaged it in 2005 for TP, with additional text revisions done by J. Victor Villareal and Chynna Roxas.

Ana Abad Santos also staged Hamlet for Rep, 2008, and set it in a dystopian world where the characters held oversized weapons. Playwright Layeta Bucoy collaborated with director Tuxqs Rutaquio to adapt Titus Andronicus into Tinarantadong Asintado for DUP, setting it in the milieu of barangay politics, 2011. Abad and playwright Luarca adapted Romeo and Juliet into Sintang Dalisay, 2011, using the Tinio translation and the awit (metrical romance) “Ang Sintang Dalisay ni Julieta at Romeo” (The Pure Love of Julieta and Romeo) written in 1901 by G. D. Roke. They set the action in a fictional Muslim community and had the actors perform igal, a traditional dance of the Sama people from Tawi-Tawi Province. Guelan Varela Luarca and Brian Sy staged Trobol sa Troya (Troilus and Cressida) for Ateneo de Manila University, 2012, and set in modern times using a hip-hop delivery of the lines. Nonon Padilla directed Lumbera’s Haring Lear (King Lear) for PETA, 2012, with an all-male cast in a Japanese-inspired dystopian setting designed by Gino Gonzalez. Vera translated and adapted Twelfth Night to D’ Wonder Twins of Boac for PETA, 2013, setting it during the decline of the 1960s Philippine film industry, with Viola and Sebastian as a singing-sibling act and Duke Orsino and Countess Olivia as film studio owners. He also adapted Tinio’s Ang Negosyante ng Venecia to Der Kaufmann: Ang Negosyante ng Venetia for TP, 2013, creating a “play within a play” set in Germany during the Nazi occupation.

Children’s Theater. Companies continue to stage plays and musicals geared for children. PETA’s original children’s productions include Batang Rizal (Young Rizal), Ismail at Isabel (Ismail and Isabel), and William. Adapted from the short stories of Severino Reyes is Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang).

TP produced original works such as Prinsipe ng Buwan (Prince of the Moon). It staged an adaptation of Virgilio Almario’s retelling of an Asian folktale Dugtong-Dugtong na Sumbong: Ang Hukuman ni Sinukuan (Series of Complaints: The Court of Sinukuan) and an adaptation of Luis Gatmaitan’s children’s book Sandosenang Sapatos (A Dozen Pair of Shoes). Adaptations from foreign stories include Pinocchio, Mulan, and Prinsipe Munti (Little Prince). Other TP productions are Tiktipaklong, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, and Ang Pagong at ang Matsing (The Turtle and the Monkey).

Rep licenses children’s plays or musicals from abroad and presents these productions under its Repertory Children’s Theater. Usually, the stories are based on classic Western fairy tales such as Sleeping Beauty, Pinocchio, and Jack and the Beanstalk.

Experimental Theater. Productions occasionally use experimental scripts, which either have nonlinear story lines or are directed or staged in a nontraditional or unusual manner. Some productions are even staged in nontheater venues. Theater groups based in UP are known for their forays into experimental territory. UP Tropa’s Manhid (Numb), 1991, was staged along the corridors of Palma Hall instead of a theater. Anton Juan directed his own play Death in a Form of a Rose, 1991, combining several texts to devise the script and staging it with poetry reading and movement pieces. In 2010, he directed Information for Foreigners, where audiences were led by “tour guides” in groups, going up and down different floors and in and out of different rooms in the College of Arts and Letters Building in UP, where different scenes were played out by actors. In the early 2000s, Josefina Estrella staged what may be deemed as the first nondramatic theater piece in the metropolis (or maybe in the entire country). Her Recoged Esta Voz (Gather This Voice) was a montage of visual spectacles: actors dancing and reciting poetry, with video projections on a bare stage with only white drapes.

Sipat Lawin Ensemble staged Haring Tubul, 2010, in art galleries, prodding audiences to “eat” one of the character’s “feces,” a concoction that was actually peanut butter. It staged Batallia Royale (Battle Royale), 2012, on the CCP driveway ramp and later in an abandoned school, with audience participation. It also staged Love: This Is Not Yet a Musical (Love: Not), 2014, a “crowd-sourced” musical that aimed to document present-day thoughts on love from social media based on more than 300 contributions.

In 2013, Transitopia Contemporary Dance Commune artistic director Jose Jay Cruz met with other independent or nonmainstream theater companies such as SLE, Kolab Company, and Destiyero Theatre Commune. The meeting gave birth to MNL X: Festival of New Performances, 2014, a theater event held at the CCP, organized by independent artists and groups.

 

Conclusion

As the 2010s reaches its midpoint, judging by the number of companies that are currently active as well as the number of works being staged in Metro Manila and other regions, it is neither a boast nor an overestimation to say that Philippine theater is enjoying a new golden era. Filipino artists continue to use theater to contemplate, criticize, commemorate, and celebrate their people’s varied travails, truths, and triumphs by preserving, reviving, or evolving traditional genres and works for contemporary audiences; creating new works that Filipinos can enjoy and proudly share with global audiences; translating and adapting foreign materials to expose audiences to international works; and experimenting with new forms that push the envelope. Economics fluctuate, nature sometimes does not cooperate, social norms and trends change faster than the blink of an eye, but the Philippine theater industry not only keeps up and thrives but also forges new colorful and exciting paths for artists, practitioners, scholars and, most importantly, for Filipino audiences.
