Early Diaspora Theater
Theater Companies
Community Theater Groups
Individual Artists

 

Philippine diaspora theater consists of performances mounted by Filipino artists who reconstruct the Philippines, participate in discourses of the homeland, and articulate contemporary issues in sites of migration—notably in the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, Japan, Hong Kong, Taiwan, France, the Netherlands, and Australia—through the restaging of plays first performed in the Philippines, the staging of original works, the rewriting of epics, and the revival of traditional forms. Their works are informed not only by their memory of the homeland but also by the Philippines’s colonial history, its politics and economic conditions, and the desire to link migrant narratives to that of the narrative of home. In their plays are discourses on exile, labor, colonialism, gender, geopolitics, and class.

 

Early Diaspora Theater

The roots of diaspora theater can be traced to touring performances, early collaborations with Asian artists, actors who become professional workers abroad, and foreign exchanges. Among the Philippine theater groups that have performed in tours of Asia, Europe, and the United States were the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) with Panata sa Kalayaan (Oath to Freedom), 1986, and the Kaliwat Theater Collective with Lem a Feu sa Habagatan (Spirit of Paradise) in the United Kingdom and Ireland, 1992, and Korea, 1998; Dis Place (This Place) in Australia, 1996; and Oya! Arakan (Oh! Arakan) in Singapore in 1999.

Of collaborations, one of the earliest was Cry of Asia, 1989, through the Asian Council for People’s Culture, with concept and direction by Al Santos. The performance incorporated 10 languages and included participants from India, Pakistan, Korea, New Zealand, Thailand, and Japan. In a 90-minute performance that incorporated traditional and contemporary forms to tell a tale of spectacle and deceit, power dynamics, and the triumph of collective action, Kaliwat Theater Collective, led by its artistic director Nestor Horfilla, also engaged in collaborations through its Dancing Land collaborative performance with Assignment Theater in Taiwan, 1989.

Among the earliest theater artists who became migrant workers were the actors who performed in the West End production of Miss Saigon in London in 1989. They were Lea Salonga who played the role of Kim, Monique Wilson (her alternate), Isay Alvarez, Junix Inocian, Robert Seña, Cocoy Laurel, and Pinky Amador. Salonga won the Olivier in 1990, and in 1991 performed the same role on Broadway, winning the Tony and the Drama Desk Awards of that year. Other Filipina actors who became migrant professionals to play Kim were Joanna Ampil, Jamie Rivera, and Jenine Desiderio in London; Caselyn Francisco and Lani Sumalinog in Germany; and Ima Castro in Asia.

Artists who have participated in exchanges were Lutgardo Labad, who gave workshops in several Asian countries; PETA artists who collaborated with the Black Tent theater group of Japan; Chris Millado and Dessa Quesada, who gave workshops to Maori communities in 1987; Bugkos theater artists who worked with the Hagurumaza theater group in Japan in the late 1980s; and women playwrights led by Malou Jacob, who engaged in conferences through Women Playwrights International.

Contemporary Philippine diaspora theater can be divided into three main types: sustained production through a professional or community theater company or a performing space; random productions or single performances mounted by organizations, communities, or groups for a specific purpose or as a response to a particular issue; and the works of individual artists in university, community, or professional theater.

 

Theater Companies

In the United States, among the most successful Asian American theater groups is Ma-Yi Theatre Company. Founded in 1989 by Chito Jao Garces (who was its founding artistic director), Ralph Peña (the current artistic director), Margot Lloren, Anne Frilles, Luz de Leon, Isolda Oca, Arianne Recto, Cristina Sison, and Bernie Villanueva, its first productions were Filipino plays and adaptations. Key Ma-yi artists include executive director Jorge Ortoll, associate director Suzette Porte, director and designer Loy Arcenas, composer Fabian Obispo, actors Ching Valdez and Mia Katigbak, literary manager Joi Barrios-Leblanc, and guest artist Chris Millado. While Ma-yi’s early plays such as Linda Faigao Hall’s Woman from the Other End of the World and Ralph Peña’s Flipzoids, both in 1996, and Han Ong’s Middle Finger, 2000, countered negative portrayals and stereotypes of Asian Americans by focusing on the characters’ contradictions, negotiations of identity, and intergenerational conflicts, its later productions interrogated history as in Chris Millado’s PeregriNasyon, 1998, and Ralph Peña and Sung Rno’s Project Balangiga, 2002; examined popular culture as in Sung Rno’s wAve, 2004; reframed memory as in Qui Nguyen’s Trial by Water, 2006; and indicted neocolonial globalization, as exemplified by Lonnie Carter’s The Romance of Magno Rubio, with Tagalog text by Peña, 2002, and Kia Cothron, Sung Rno, and Jorge Cortiñas’s Savage Acts, 2004. These plays have been anthologized in Savage Stage, 2007, which argues that by creating a theater of disturbance, employing elements of the “savage” as weapons of dissent, and performing that which is empowering, the company is able to redefine the “savage stage” of Asian American theater. Ma-yi’s works have won 10 OBIE Awards, a Drama Desk nomination for Best Play, Henry Hewes Design Award nominations, and in May 2010, a special Drama Desk award for “more than two decades of excellence and for nurturing Asian American voices in stylistically varied and engaging theatre.”

Two other groups that have sustained productions in the United States are Bindlestiff Studio in San Francisco and CIRCA Pintig in Chicago. Bindlestiff Studio started as an experimental theater space when it was founded in 1989 by Canadian artists Chrystene Ells, Chris Brophy, and a group of local theater artists. However, when Allan S. Manalo became the studio’s artistic and managing director in 1997, the studio set out to become a center for Filipino-American performing arts in the Bay Area. Manalo’s theater group Tongue in a Mood staged Kevin Camia, Patty Cachapero, and Manalo’s Tsismis (Gossip) in 1997 and Damo (Grass/Weed) in 1999. Another theater group, Teatro ng Tanan, active in the Bay area in the 1990s, has had an enduring influence on the studio, through its workshop series culminating in an annual production titled Stories High. Although Bindlestiff lost its theater to the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency (SFRA) in 2003, SFRA subsequently built a 99-seat, black box theater for them in the rebuilt housing complex, and this opened in 2011. Among Bindlestiff’s productions are Lorna Velasco’s A Pinoy Midsummer, 2013; a series of works called The Bakla Show (The Gay Show); and Rody Vera’s adaptation of the novel The Guerillas of Powell Street by Benjamin Pimentel, 2014.

CIRCA Pintig, based in Chicago is composed of two groups: Pintig, founded in 1991 by a group of artists, activists, professionals, and community organizers, and the Center for Immigrant Resources and Community Arts (CIRCA), founded in 2001. The two groups came together in 2006 to form a community theater company and a community education and outreach organization. Among the group’s leaders are artistic director Angela Mascarenas, composer Louie Pascasio, Levi and Christy Aliposa, Daisy Castro, Ginger and Larry Leopoldo, and Divina Calo. The group’s body of work interrogates Philippine American colonial relations and articulates the migrant experience through Chris Millado’s adaptation of America Is in the Heart, 1992, a novel by Carlos Bulosan; Rody Vera and Louie Pascasio’s Bells of Balangiga, 1997, remounted in 2007; Larry Leopoldo’s Scent of Home , 2006 and 2014, an adaptation of Bienvenido Santos’s short stories; Lani Montreal Bermudez’s Dama, 2002 and 2014; and Noel Alumit’s Mr. and Mrs. LaQuesta Go Dancing, 2009 and 2013.

Similarly, Carlos Bulosan Theater (formerly the Carlos Bulosan Cultural Workshop) based in Ontario, Canada, has been staging plays since 1982, with the aim of producing “theatre that reflects social and political issues affecting the Filipino and the broader community.” Founded in 1982 by Fely Villasin and Martha Ocampo, it has produced works such as Fely Villasin’s If My Mother Could See Me Now/Inay Kung Alam Mo Lang, 1989 and 1990, a play on domestic workers; Nina Lee Aquino and Nadine Villasin’s Miss (Oriented), 2003, which examines the politics of culture identity through the eyes of three contestants in the beauty pageant “Miss Pearl of the Orient”; People Power, 2006, restaged in 2008 and 2010, a play on the 1986 EDSA Revolt that ended the Marcos dictatorship; In the Shadow of Elephants, 2013, which was on the Philippines’s history of resistance against colonial rule; and the annual Tales from the Flipside. Key members of the group include Leon Aureus (the artistic director), Rose Cortez, Nicco Lorenzo, Christine Mangosing, and N. Villasin, all collaborators in the staging of both People Power and In the Shadow of Elephants, as well as Board President Rina Espiritu. The theater company partners with the Kapisanan Philippine Centre for Arts and Culture for community events and facilitates education workshops on Philippine history.

In the United Kingdom, Philippine Theatre UK, led by its artistic director Ramon Castillanes Teñoso and managing director Maurice Newberry, has produced around 15 original plays since it was founded in 2002. A graduate of the University of the Philippines (UP) with a master’s degree in psychology, Teñoso had worked for the CEO of the Society of London Theatres/Theatrical Management. He also wrote a stage adaptation of Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1998, and Debt (Death) Trap , 1998. Teñoso has served as the company’s playwright, director, and trainer. The company has trained more than 100 Filipino and British actors. Among the pioneering works of Philippine Theatre UK are Birthmark, 2004, a play about a gay man, a lesbian, and a straight man living together; Pater Noster (Our Father), 2006, which focuses on the life of Filipino seafarers; Four Ladies, 2007, which is about four famous Filipinas—namely, Imelda Marcos, Corazon Aquino, Susan Roces, and Gloria Arroyo; Migrants, 2012; and The Enchanted Bird, a retelling of the metrical romance Ibong Adarna, 2014.

 

Community Theater Groups

The production of plays, however, is not limited to theater companies. In some cases, organizations or community groups stage their plays through a cultural section or teams of artists. In others, individual Filipino playwrights/performers stage their own works or have them produced by other companies.

An example is the Filipina Women’s Network, which staged Eve Ensler’s Vagina Monologues, with performances either in both Filipino and English or English only, in San Francisco and New York in 2004-13. First directed by Elena Buensalido and Bernardo Bernardo and later by Bettina Santos Yap, the production integrated songs such as “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” (In the Cradle’s Rocking), “Ili-ili,” and “Babae” (Woman). In its 9th and 10th years, the former all-Filipina cast members were joined by other Asia-Pacific women to reflect both the diversity of the city and the collaborative work of Asia-Pacific women.

One of the earliest groups to have performed in the United States was Sining Bayan, which was active from 1973 to 1981, and which defined itself as the cultural arm of the national democratic organization Katipunan ng mga Demokratikong Pilipino. In the book Puro Arte: Filipinos on the Stages of Empire (2013), Lucy Mae San Pablo Burns studied the plays performed by the group, and noted that “Sining Bayan rendered their work as a vehicle to popularize their political agenda, and as an organizing tool” (86). Burns also explained that although Ermena Vinluan was the driving force, crucial to the creative process of the group was collective work, thereby challenging mainstream theater processes. Among the group’s works cited by Burns are Isuda ti Imunal/They Who Were First, which focused on Filipino migrant workers; Warbrides, on Filipina war brides; Mindanao, on Southern Philippines; Sakada, on peasant workers; Narciso and Perez, on two Filipina nurses who were victims of racism; Tagatupad/Those Who Carry On, on the eviction of International Hotel residents in San Francisco; and Ti Manyuna/Those Who Led the Way, on the Filipino labor community in Hawaii. Burns underlines the following strategies employed by the group: narratives that show the triumph of collective struggle against oppressive forces, as informed by Augusto Boal’s theater of the oppressed; shifts in action when actors address audience members, making them central to the play; defamiliarization of popular culture; and negotiations of space (75-94).

Similarly influenced by the framework that theater plays a role in the Filipino people’s struggles, Teatro ng Tanan was formed in San Francisco in 1989. With the leadership of key artists Chris Millado, Julia Camagong, Mara Torres, Marlette and Bingo Marasigan, guest director Edgardo de la Cruz, and later, Allan Manalo, the group produced the collectively written Kin/Kamag-anak, 1989, on identity, immigration, and activism; Rene Villanueva’s Botong, 1991, on the life of National Artist Carlos V. Francisco; and Chris Millado’s PeregriNasyon , 1993, on the parallel lives of farmers and farmworkers in the Philippines and the United States during the American colonial period. The company disbanded in the mid-1990s.

The influence of the national democratic movement endures, however, as seen not only in professional groups such as Ma-yi Theatre Company but also in loosely organized cultural groups and networks affiliated with larger political organizations. Two examples are Linangan Cultural Network in the Netherlands and LIKHA Filipino Migrants Organization in Hong Kong. Linangan Cultural Network, formerly People’s Artist Network, was formed in 2006 by former PETA artists Jun Saturay and Mitchy Mallorca Saturay, and Netherlands-based Irish artist Martin Travers. Many of its members are Netherlands residents with different ethnic backgrounds: Poojah Pant (Nepali), Guney Brusk (Kurdish), Denise Yildirim (Dutch-Kurdish), and the Saturay children Nwel, Hiyasmin, Ilena, and Marikit (Filipino). Informed by strategies of street theater such as the use of giant puppets, clowning and mimicry, and reenactments, the network has articulated issues such as human rights, immigrant rights, and geopolitics through Checkpoint 101, 2007, a presentation on the Apartheid Wall in Palestine; A Sad State of Freedom, 2007, a street dramatization of Nazim Hikmet’s poem, focusing on human rights in the Philippines, the Abu Gharaib prison, and Palestine; Grieving Mothers, 2010, a mask/movement theater piece on poverty, injustice, and human rights during the term of President Benigno Aquino III, performed in Amsterdam; an untitled giant puppet play performed on International Workers’ Day, 1 May 2011, in Rotterdam; and Kapi’s Magic Trick, 2014, a clown act on workers’ struggles.

LIKHA Filipino Migrants Cultural Organization, an affiliate of United Filipinos in Hong Kong, Migrante–HK, and BAYAN (Bagong Alyansang Makabayan)–Hong Kong and Macao, was established in 1992 but became inactive for many years until it was reactivated in 2006. Since most of its members are domestic workers and migrant organizers like Aaron Ceradoy, Shiela Tebia, Aurelia Gatchalian, Maricel Redita, Karen Garcia, Lalyn Lopez, and Jezelle Mendez, its performances tackle issues on the intersections of labor, migration, and gender: Binibining OWW A(Miss OWWA), 2003; Si Maria sa Mga Kuko ng Ahensiya (Maria in the Claws of the Agency), 2014; and Balagtasan: Lagay ng Mamamayan (Verbal Joust: the Conditions of Citizens), 2014; and several dance movement interpretations of songs such as “Babae Ka” (You Are a Woman) and “Manggagawa” (Worker).

Labor and women’s issues are also presented in the United States through occasional and annual productions by groups such as the Committee for the Protection of Workers’ Rights (CPWR), a support group of Kilusang Mayo Uno in the Philippines, and General Assembly Binding Women for Reforms, Integrity, Equality, Leadership, and Action (GABRIELA) USA, the US chapter of GABRIELA Philippines. In 2011, CPWR’s artists Pendong and Cynthia Aban of the musical group Ang Grupong Pendong composed and performed Piketlayn Cantata (Picket Line Cantata) on the parallel struggles of caregivers and DOLE pineapple plantation workers. The play was restaged by Pintig in 2015. Annually since 2002, GABRIELA’s chapters in the United States, such as FIRE in New York and Babae in San Francisco, have mounted Diwang Pinay (Spirit of the Filipina), which consists of songs, dances, short films, and short plays. Among the themes Diwang Pinay has tackled through the years are “Kilos Kababaihan: Hearts Beating for the Movement” (Women’s Movement: Hearts Beating for the Movement), 2012; “Labanan ang Pang-aapi sa Ating mga Makabagong Bayani” (Resist the Enslavement of Our Modern Heroes), 2013; and “Kasaysayan ng Kababaihang Migranteng Manggagawa” (The Story of the Woman Migrant Worker), 2014.

 

Individual Artists

Theater work by Filipinos is not limited to organizations or companies, as established theater artists in the Philippines have continued their work in their sites of migration. One example is Anton Juan, a professor of theater at the University of Notre Dame, who has directed Oscar Wilde’s Salome, 2006, using the Japanese kabuki theater form and thepangalaydance; Griselda Gambaro’s Antigona Furiosa, 2011, a play that retells Sophocles’s Antigone; and his own play Shadows of the Reef, 2013, which uses Lenten rites of crucifixions and flagellations in the Philippines as metaphors for poverty and suffering, the plight of children working as sea divers, and the exploitation of women. Active both in the international theater community and in local concerns, Juan is a board member of the International Playwrights’ Forum and has spearheaded the Theatre and Social Concerns project with juvenile prison residents, for which he received the Center for Social Concerns Award for social engagement. Before coming to the United States, Juan was also the founding artistic director of Step of Angels Theatre in Athens, Greece.

Other professional and community-based theater artists who have worked or are still working in the United States are Arcenas, Obispo, Valdez, and Katigbak who are based in New York; designer Clint Ramos; actor Bernardo Bernardo, based in Los Angeles; theater professor and director Edgardo de la Cruz who taught at California State University East Bay; former Tanghalang Pilipino artistic director Herbert Go, and actor Olga Natividad; former PETA member Bing Magtoto; former UP professor Nenita Pambid; UP Repertory Company alumni Elena Buensalido Mangahas and Boots Pascual; and former DUP members Joseph Pe and Margaret Guzman.

Theater artists have also been active in many other countries, whether as temporary migrants or immigrants. Theater actress Monique Wilson, who played Kim in Miss Saigon from 1989 to 1992, stayed on in London for a few years after graduating with a master’s degree from the Central School of Speech and Drama to teach in the drama school. In London, Wilson also performed as Juliet in Romeo and Juliet, Anne in Richard III, Cleopatra in Anthony and Cleopatra, Marjorie in The Country Wife, and Vittoria in The White Devil. In France, Connie Chua started her theater work by directing Kutsilyo, Pamaypay and Yantok (Knife, Fan, and Stick), 2007 and 2012, for the Episcopal Church of Saint Paul, and youth plays, and by giving theater, dance, and music workshops. She has recently been involved in the use of theater to articulate the rights of domestic workers and empower them. Based in Germany, actor-singer Lanie Sumalinog has performed not only as Kim in Miss Saigon, but also in Les Miserables, 1998, and Wicked, 2007. In Australia, writer-performer Merlinda Bobis has staged one-woman shows of her plays Daragang Magayon: Cantata of a Warrior Woman, 2006, and River, River, 2009. In Japan, director Jose Estrella staged Elsa Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House featuring theater artists Jina Umali, Matthew Santamaria, and Nerissa Sarmiento Saito (who once trained under Naty Crame-Rogers) in 1995. Umali, Santamaria, and Saito had earlier teamed up with playwright Charlson Ong to produce Ang Kalayaan sa Buhay ni Loreta Tanaka (Freedom in the Life of Loreta Tanaka), 1995.

Certain common characteristics may be observed in the works of these Filipino migrant theater companies, groups, and individuals: first, the use of language to mark the production, through bilingual titles and scripts incorporating Filipino, Ilocano, Visayan, and other Philippine languages; second, the interdependence between artists and Filipino communities to ensure survival; third, the strategies learned from local theater companies—namely, PETA, Peryante street theater group, Repertory Philippines, Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas)—having a great influence in the site of migration; and fourth, the artists’ participation in discourses of migrant labor, human rights, gender equality, and globalization. Written by Joi Barrios

CIRCA Pintig, based in Chicago is composed of two groups: Pintig, founded in 1991 by a group of artists, activists, professionals, and community organizers, and the Center for Immigrant Resources and Community Arts (CIRCA), founded in 2001. The two groups came together in 2006 to form a community theater company and a community education and outreach organization. Among the group’s leaders are artistic director Angela Mascarenas, composer Louie Pascasio, Levi and Christy Aliposa, Daisy Castro, Ginger and Larry Leopoldo, and Divina Calo. The group’s body of work interrogates Philippine American colonial relations and articulates the migrant experience through Chris Millado’s adaptation of America Is in the Heart, 1992, a novel by Carlos Bulosan; Rody Vera and Louie Pascasio’s Bells of Balangiga, 1997, remounted in 2007; Larry Leopoldo’s Scent of Home , 2006 and 2014, an adaptation of Bienvenido Santos’s short stories; Lani Montreal Bermudez’s Dama, 2002 and 2014; and Noel Alumit’s Mr. and Mrs. LaQuesta Go Dancing, 2009 and 2013.

Similarly, Carlos Bulosan Theater (formerly the Carlos Bulosan Cultural Workshop) based in Ontario, Canada, has been staging plays since 1982, with the aim of producing “theatre that reflects social and political issues affecting the Filipino and the broader community.” Founded in 1982 by Fely Villasin and Martha Ocampo, it has produced works such as Fely Villasin’s If My Mother Could See Me Now/Inay Kung Alam Mo Lang, 1989 and 1990, a play on domestic workers; Nina Lee Aquino and Nadine Villasin’s Miss (Oriented), 2003, which examines the politics of culture identity through the eyes of three contestants in the beauty pageant “Miss Pearl of the Orient”; People Power, 2006, restaged in 2008 and 2010, a play on the 1986 EDSA Revolt that ended the Marcos dictatorship; In the Shadow of Elephants, 2013, which was on the Philippines’s history of resistance against colonial rule; and the annual Tales from the Flipside. Key members of the group include Leon Aureus (the artistic director), Rose Cortez, Nicco Lorenzo, Christine Mangosing, and N. Villasin, all collaborators in the staging of both People Power and In the Shadow of Elephants, as well as Board President Rina Espiritu. The theater company partners with the Kapisanan Philippine Centre for Arts and Culture for community events and facilitates education workshops on Philippine history.

In the United Kingdom, Philippine Theatre UK, led by its artistic director Ramon Castillanes Teñoso and managing director Maurice Newberry, has produced around 15 original plays since it was founded in 2002. A graduate of the University of the Philippines (UP) with a master’s degree in psychology, Teñoso had worked for the CEO of the Society of London Theatres/Theatrical Management. He also wrote a stage adaptation of Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1998, and Debt (Death) Trap , 1998. Teñoso has served as the company’s playwright, director, and trainer. The company has trained more than 100 Filipino and British actors. Among the pioneering works of Philippine Theatre UK are Birthmark, 2004, a play about a gay man, a lesbian, and a straight man living together; Pater Noster (Our Father), 2006, which focuses on the life of Filipino seafarers; Four Ladies, 2007, which is about four famous Filipinas—namely, Imelda Marcos, Corazon Aquino, Susan Roces, and Gloria Arroyo; Migrants, 2012; and The Enchanted Bird, a retelling of the metrical romance Ibong Adarna, 2014.
Community Theater Groups

The production of plays, however, is not limited to theater companies. In some cases, organizations or community groups stage their plays through a cultural section or teams of artists. In others, individual Filipino playwrights/performers stage their own works or have them produced by other companies.

An example is the Filipina Women’s Network, which staged Eve Ensler’s Vagina Monologues, with performances either in both Filipino and English or English only, in San Francisco and New York in 2004-13. First directed by Elena Buensalido and Bernardo Bernardo and later by Bettina Santos Yap, the production integrated songs such as “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” (In the Cradle’s Rocking), “Ili-ili,” and “Babae” (Woman). In its 9th and 10th years, the former all-Filipina cast members were joined by other Asia-Pacific women to reflect both the diversity of the city and the collaborative work of Asia-Pacific women.

One of the earliest groups to have performed in the United States was Sining Bayan, which was active from 1973 to 1981, and which defined itself as the cultural arm of the national democratic organization Katipunan ng mga Demokratikong Pilipino. In the book Puro Arte: Filipinos on the Stages of Empire (2013), Lucy Mae San Pablo Burns studied the plays performed by the group, and noted that “Sining Bayan rendered their work as a vehicle to popularize their political agenda, and as an organizing tool” (86). Burns also explained that although Ermena Vinluan was the driving force, crucial to the creative process of the group was collective work, thereby challenging mainstream theater processes. Among the group’s works cited by Burns are Isuda ti Imunal/They Who Were First, which focused on Filipino migrant workers; Warbrides, on Filipina war brides; Mindanao, on Southern Philippines; Sakada, on peasant workers; Narciso and Perez, on two Filipina nurses who were victims of racism; Tagatupad/Those Who Carry On, on the eviction of International Hotel residents in San Francisco; and Ti Manyuna/Those Who Led the Way, on the Filipino labor community in Hawaii. Burns underlines the following strategies employed by the group: narratives that show the triumph of collective struggle against oppressive forces, as informed by Augusto Boal’s theater of the oppressed; shifts in action when actors address audience members, making them central to the play; defamiliarization of popular culture; and negotiations of space (75-94).

Similarly influenced by the framework that theater plays a role in the Filipino people’s struggles, Teatro ng Tanan was formed in San Francisco in 1989. With the leadership of key artists Chris Millado, Julia Camagong, Mara Torres, Marlette and Bingo Marasigan, guest director Edgardo de la Cruz, and later, Allan Manalo, the group produced the collectively written Kin/Kamag-anak, 1989, on identity, immigration, and activism; Rene Villanueva’s Botong, 1991, on the life of National Artist Carlos V. Francisco; and Chris Millado’s PeregriNasyon , 1993, on the parallel lives of farmers and farmworkers in the Philippines and the United States during the American colonial period. The company disbanded in the mid-1990s.

The influence of the national democratic movement endures, however, as seen not only in professional groups such as Ma-yi Theatre Company but also in loosely organized cultural groups and networks affiliated with larger political organizations. Two examples are Linangan Cultural Network in the Netherlands and LIKHA Filipino Migrants Organization in Hong Kong. Linangan Cultural Network, formerly People’s Artist Network, was formed in 2006 by former PETA artists Jun Saturay and Mitchy Mallorca Saturay, and Netherlands-based Irish artist Martin Travers. Many of its members are Netherlands residents with different ethnic backgrounds: Poojah Pant (Nepali), Guney Brusk (Kurdish), Denise Yildirim (Dutch-Kurdish), and the Saturay children Nwel, Hiyasmin, Ilena, and Marikit (Filipino). Informed by strategies of street theater such as the use of giant puppets, clowning and mimicry, and reenactments, the network has articulated issues such as human rights, immigrant rights, and geopolitics through Checkpoint 101, 2007, a presentation on the Apartheid Wall in Palestine; A Sad State of Freedom, 2007, a street dramatization of Nazim Hikmet’s poem, focusing on human rights in the Philippines, the Abu Gharaib prison, and Palestine; Grieving Mothers, 2010, a mask/movement theater piece on poverty, injustice, and human rights during the term of President Benigno Aquino III, performed in Amsterdam; an untitled giant puppet play performed on International Workers’ Day, 1 May 2011, in Rotterdam; and Kapi’s Magic Trick, 2014, a clown act on workers’ struggles.

LIKHA Filipino Migrants Cultural Organization, an affiliate of United Filipinos in Hong Kong, Migrante–HK, and BAYAN (Bagong Alyansang Makabayan)–Hong Kong and Macao, was established in 1992 but became inactive for many years until it was reactivated in 2006. Since most of its members are domestic workers and migrant organizers like Aaron Ceradoy, Shiela Tebia, Aurelia Gatchalian, Maricel Redita, Karen Garcia, Lalyn Lopez, and Jezelle Mendez, its performances tackle issues on the intersections of labor, migration, and gender: Binibining OWW A(Miss OWWA), 2003; Si Maria sa Mga Kuko ng Ahensiya (Maria in the Claws of the Agency), 2014; and Balagtasan: Lagay ng Mamamayan (Verbal Joust: the Conditions of Citizens), 2014; and several dance movement interpretations of songs such as “Babae Ka” (You Are a Woman) and “Manggagawa” (Worker).

Labor and women’s issues are also presented in the United States through occasional and annual productions by groups such as the Committee for the Protection of Workers’ Rights (CPWR), a support group of Kilusang Mayo Uno in the Philippines, and General Assembly Binding Women for Reforms, Integrity, Equality, Leadership, and Action (GABRIELA) USA, the US chapter of GABRIELA Philippines. In 2011, CPWR’s artists Pendong and Cynthia Aban of the musical group Ang Grupong Pendong composed and performed Piketlayn Cantata (Picket Line Cantata) on the parallel struggles of caregivers and DOLE pineapple plantation workers. The play was restaged by Pintig in 2015. Annually since 2002, GABRIELA’s chapters in the United States, such as FIRE in New York and Babae in San Francisco, have mounted Diwang Pinay (Spirit of the Filipina), which consists of songs, dances, short films, and short plays. Among the themes Diwang Pinay has tackled through the years are “Kilos Kababaihan: Hearts Beating for the Movement” (Women’s Movement: Hearts Beating for the Movement), 2012; “Labanan ang Pang-aapi sa Ating mga Makabagong Bayani” (Resist the Enslavement of Our Modern Heroes), 2013; and “Kasaysayan ng Kababaihang Migranteng Manggagawa” (The Story of the Woman Migrant Worker), 2014.
Individual Artists

Theater work by Filipinos is not limited to organizations or companies, as established theater artists in the Philippines have continued their work in their sites of migration. One example is Anton Juan, a professor of theater at the University of Notre Dame, who has directed Oscar Wilde’s Salome, 2006, using the Japanese kabuki theater form and thepangalaydance; Griselda Gambaro’s Antigona Furiosa, 2011, a play that retells Sophocles’s Antigone; and his own play Shadows of the Reef, 2013, which uses Lenten rites of crucifixions and flagellations in the Philippines as metaphors for poverty and suffering, the plight of children working as sea divers, and the exploitation of women. Active both in the international theater community and in local concerns, Juan is a board member of the International Playwrights’ Forum and has spearheaded the Theatre and Social Concerns project with juvenile prison residents, for which he received the Center for Social Concerns Award for social engagement. Before coming to the United States, Juan was also the founding artistic director of Step of Angels Theatre in Athens, Greece.

Other professional and community-based theater artists who have worked or are still working in the United States are Arcenas, Obispo, Valdez, and Katigbak who are based in New York; designer Clint Ramos; actor Bernardo Bernardo, based in Los Angeles; theater professor and director Edgardo de la Cruz who taught at California State University East Bay; former Tanghalang Pilipino artistic director Herbert Go, and actor Olga Natividad; former PETA member Bing Magtoto; former UP professor Nenita Pambid; UP Repertory Company alumni Elena Buensalido Mangahas and Boots Pascual; and former DUP members Joseph Pe and Margaret Guzman.

Theater artists have also been active in many other countries, whether as temporary migrants or immigrants. Theater actress Monique Wilson, who played Kim in Miss Saigon from 1989 to 1992, stayed on in London for a few years after graduating with a master’s degree from the Central School of Speech and Drama to teach in the drama school. In London, Wilson also performed as Juliet in Romeo and Juliet, Anne in Richard III, Cleopatra in Anthony and Cleopatra, Marjorie in The Country Wife, and Vittoria in The White Devil. In France, Connie Chua started her theater work by directing Kutsilyo, Pamaypay and Yantok (Knife, Fan, and Stick), 2007 and 2012, for the Episcopal Church of Saint Paul, and youth plays, and by giving theater, dance, and music workshops. She has recently been involved in the use of theater to articulate the rights of domestic workers and empower them. Based in Germany, actor-singer Lanie Sumalinog has performed not only as Kim in Miss Saigon, but also in Les Miserables, 1998, and Wicked, 2007. In Australia, writer-performer Merlinda Bobis has staged one-woman shows of her plays Daragang Magayon: Cantata of a Warrior Woman, 2006, and River, River, 2009. In Japan, director Jose Estrella staged Elsa Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House featuring theater artists Jina Umali, Matthew Santamaria, and Nerissa Sarmiento Saito (who once trained under Naty Crame-Rogers) in 1995. Umali, Santamaria, and Saito had earlier teamed up with playwright Charlson Ong to produce Ang Kalayaan sa Buhay ni Loreta Tanaka (Freedom in the Life of Loreta Tanaka), 1995.

Certain common characteristics may be observed in the works of these Filipino migrant theater companies, groups, and individuals: first, the use of language to mark the production, through bilingual titles and scripts incorporating Filipino, Ilocano, Visayan, and other Philippine languages; second, the interdependence between artists and Filipino communities to ensure survival; third, the strategies learned from local theater companies—namely, PETA, Peryante street theater group, Repertory Philippines, Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas)—having a great influence in the site of migration; and fourth, the artists’ participation in discourses of migrant labor, human rights, gender equality, and globalization.

article_title: Sources and Influences in Philippine Theater

text:
The sources for drama plots and characters, and styles of presentation in Philippine theater include history, folklore, foreign and indigenized literature, global theater trends and styles, and Philippine lifeways and real-life events. All of these are rich material for theater.

The rituals and dances of indigenous theater evolved from day-to-day needs: rice planting and harvest, birth and death, courtship and marriage, illness, and rites of passage. They therefore drew from events and belief in the symbolic and actual characters and actions that made the ritual. The Maranao rice-planting ritual called kashawing, for example, uses food and water, farmers and intercessors, along with invocations and offerings to the spirits. Dances mime occupations like fishing, hunting, and fruit gathering, as well as rites of survival like battle and courtship.

The komedya has plots and characters from medieval European romances—from Britain and France, from Spanish and Portuguese history and lore, from the lives of saints, and from combinations of these. From these materials come the buhay na pinagdaanan (the life history) of characters such as Principe Baldovino, Doce Pares de Francia, Prinsipe Atamante, Rodrigo de Villa, Haring Villarba, and Don Juan Tiñoso. These stories were taken directly from the metrical romances probably brought in by Spanish soldiers, written in the native languages in the awit and korido, read and chanted in the different regions and languages, and then transformed into drama by enactment on stage.

The sinakulo and other religious dramas and dramatizations of the Spanish colonial period draw mainly from the pasyon and the Bible, but also from related and apocryphal writings. The elaborate salubong, for example, is built on the supposed meeting of Jesus and Mary after the Resurrection, which is not recorded in the gospels. The sinakulo fleshes out eight days of performances with Biblical narratives from the Creation to the Assumption of Mary into Heaven, as well as vignettes from the awit and korido, magazine stories, and folk belief about such characters as Dimas and Gestas, Boanerhes and Samuel Belibet, Veronica and Simon Cirineo, Virgen Maria and Pedro and Judas. From the search for the Holy Cross have been spun plays and romances involving the empress Elena and the emperor Constantino and characters from the Old and New Testaments.

Real life strides onstage in the drama and the sarsuwela, which depart from the Spanish models by building theater around the Filipino family: parents and children obedient or otherwise; husbands and wives in conflict or cooperation; their vices like cockfighting and panggingge (card game); concerns like politics, courtship, marriage, and making a living; and tensions between lover and beloved, landlord and tenant, master and servant, employer and employee. Although these situations were often modulated into the happy endings devoutly wished by both writers and viewers, they were based on daily life and in sum are often social comedies and commentaries.

The sources for modern drama start with real life—day-to-day happenings witnessed or heard about, accounts in newspapers and magazines, news heard over the radio or on television, political and social experience. Manny D. Pambid’s Buhay Batilyo, Hindi Kami Susuko (Batilyo Life, We Will Not Surrender), 1975, was based on a Fanny A. Garcia feature article about the life of a batilyo (fish stevedore) in the Navotas fish port. Al Santos’s Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata (May 21 and Other Chapters), 1977, came from the real-life experiences of Valentin de los Santos and the massacre of the Lapiang Malaya. Malou Jacob’s Juan Tamban, 1978, started with a news item in the papers about a boy who fell ill from eating insects that triggered curiosity and research and resulted in a full-length play. Jacob’s Macliing Dulag, 1988, dramatizes the life of the Kalinga leader who was assassinated for his opposition to the Chico River Dam Project. Reuel Molina Aguila’s Walang Maliw (Unfading), 2009, draws parallelisms from Jonas Burgos’s abduction in 2007 and proves that political disappearances happened not only during martial law but continues to the present.

History, being the “real life” of the past, has been a rich lode that contemporary Philippine theater has mined well, especially during the martial law era, when the only safe way to speak of the present was to present the past as seen in plays on the Philippine Revolution against Spain, like Bonifacio Ilagan’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), 1978, and Langit Ma’y Magdilim (Though the Sky Darkens), 1979. Connections between past and present may also be inferred from the choice of characters and events of different eras like in Adrian Cristobal’s The Trial/Ang Paglilitis, 1961, which depicts the trial of Andres Bonifacio, the supremo of the Katipunan; Domingo Landicho’s Unang Alay (First Offering), 1975; Charley de la Paz’s musical 1896, 1996; Lito Tiongson’s Ang Walang Kamatayang Buhay ni Juan de la Cruz Alyas … (Isang Kronika ng Digmaang Pilipino-Amerikano 1900-1902) (The Deathless Life of Juan de la Cruz Alias … A Chronicle of the Filipino-American War 1900-1902), 1976; Jose Y. Dalisay Jr’s Sugatang Lawin (Wounded Hawk); Isagani R. Cruz’s Josephine, 1978; and Elsa Martinez-Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House, 1987. Other historical plays are Bienvenido Lumbera’s Bayani (Hero), 1984, a musical about Jose Rizal; Paul Dumol’s Francisco Maniago, 1988, on the leader of a village in Mexico, Pampanga, who led a revolt against polo y servicios (forced labor) and bandala (forced sale of goods to government) enforced by the Spaniards; Malou Jacob, Rene Villanueva, and Honorio Magbalic’s Teresa, Gregoria, Teodora, 1993, on women’s role in the revolution; Bernardo Aguay and Jazmin B. Llana’s Simeon A. Ola, 1995, which depicted the life of the hero from Guinobatan, Albay; Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis at Pagkamatay ni Jose Rizal: Mga Teksto at Konteksto (The Trial and Death of Jose Rizal: Texts and Contexts), 1996, on the life and works of the National Hero; Jovy Miroy’s Anak ng Bayan (Son of the People), 1996, on Andres Bonifacio; Jacob, Magbalic, and Rene O. Villanueva’s Ang Anak at ang Kanyang Ina (The Child and His Mother), 1996, monologues on Jose Rizal and Teodora Alonso; Dumol’s Ilustrado: Ang Buhay ni Rizal, The Musical (Educated Native: The Life of Rizal, The Musical), 1996; Sonny Cristobal’s M. H. del Pilar: Pasyong Dapat Ipag-alab (M. H. del Pilar: Passion That Should Inflame), 1996, which highlighted del Pilar as a writer; Dumol’s Aguinaldo 1899, 1998, which depicted the life of the general of the Philippine Revolution while examining political issues during the period; Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), 2007, a sarsuwela on the women of Malolos; Christine Bellen’s Batang Rizal (The Young Rizal), 2007, a children’s play; Ed Maranan’s EJ: A Rock Musical, 2008, on the lives of Evelio Javier and Edgar Jopson; Rody Vera’s Tandang Sora: Ang Lola Nating Bayani (Tandang Sora: Our Hero Grandmother), 2012, on the mother of the revolution; Floy Quintos’s Ang Huling Lagda ni Apolinario Mabini (The Last Signature of Apolinario Mabini), 2014, and Tiongson’s Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior), 2015, which focused on the brains and conscience of the revolution. Most of these plays suggest parallelisms with the present and invite questions and solutions.

 

Contemporary issues—fleshed out in fictive characters and situations—have been another source of materials, especially for drama in the Marcos era, when the threat of closure and arrest made playwrights write scripts that could be defended against military questioning. Corruption and oppression are illustrated in Reuel Molina Aguila’s In Dis Korner (In This Corner), 1977, which is about fight fixing; Malou Jacob’s Anatomiya ng Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption), 1992, about the network of corruption in a typical government office; and in Layeta Bucoy’s Las Mentiras de Gloria (Gloria’s Lies), 2008, and Walang Kukurap (Let No One Blink), 2012, about political dynasties and traditional politics characterized by nepotism, corruption, and impunity. Poverty’s many faces and causes are seen in Nonilon Queaño’s Alipato (Spark), 1975, a story about a slum community; Queano’s Ang Pagbabalik ng Musikero (The Musician’s Return), 1978, which is about informal settlers who are forced to live in a space reserved for the dead; Rene O.Villanueva’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), 1980, set in a home for the aged; Bienvenido M. Noriega’s Batang Pro (Child Prostitute), 1985, which depicts the lives and struggles of three child prostitutes; Rogelio Sicat’s Tatalon, 1986, a jeepney driver’s monologue; and Anton Juan Jr’s Shadows of the Reef/Mga Anak ng Dagat, 2004, which dramatizes the plight of muro-ami (reef hunter) boys in a poverty-stricken fishing village.

The military is brought to life with a comic pen in Tony Perez’s Bombita, 1981; education in Ritchie Valencia’s Iskolar ng Bayan (Scholar of the People), 1976, and Al Santos’s Ang Sistema ni Propesor Tuko (Professor Gecko’s Way), 1980; the 1986 snap elections in Reynaldo and Ella Jamoralin’s Pasiya ng Bayan (People’s Verdict), 1986; women’s issues in Chris Millado’s Usapang Babae (Women Talk), 1990; Joi Barrios’s Damas de Noche (Women of the Night), 1991, and Liza Magtoto’s Tumawag kay Libby Manaoag (Call Libby Manaoag), 1998; human rights in Oratoryo ng Bayan, 1983; and traditional local politics in Layeta Bucoy’s Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan (Doc Resureccion: Will Heal the Nation), 2009. Peasants are the central characters in Marina Feleo-Gonzalez’s Dahong Palay (Rice Leaves), 1983, and Negros Theater League’s Tiempos Muertos (The Dead Season), 1987; and workers in Bonifacio Ilagan’s Welga! Welga! (Strike! Strike!), 1972, Tanghalang Silangan’s Ang Pabrika (The Factory), 1982, and Teatro Pabrika’s Kabuhayang Tagpi-tagpi (Patchwork Life), 1989.

Literature, folk or otherwise, is certainly one of the richest sources for Philippine theater. Fictive life presents transformed or imagined experience, which in the translation into enacted fiction or drama is further transformed and enriched. Folklore is an endless and endlessly rich source because it includes myths—the imagined history of the race—and legends, epics, tales, folk life, and lore. It is a long-running tradition with bases in all ethnic groups and has been a rich source for theater. Folktales have provided plots and characters for such plays as Jean Garrot Edades and Charlotte Chorpenning’s play for children, Juan and the Magic Fruit, 1949; Mig Alvarez Enriquez’s epics for stage, Lam-ang, Labaw Donggon, and Bantugan, 1953; Alberto Florentino’s adaptation of The Legend of Mariang Makiling, 1956; Jose Lardizabal’s Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot), 1969, a pageant written for the inauguration of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, which, like Ricaredo Demetillo’s award-winning The Heart of Emptiness Is Black, 1975, draws from the story of the 10 datus of Borneo (which incidentally was adjudged folklore rather than history by the Maragtas Symposium); and Al Santos’s Si Juan Tamad vs Paltos V (Lazy Juan vs Paltos V), 1979. Bienvenido Portugal’s Bidasari, 1988, draws its material from the Maranao epic Darangen, examining the concept of heroism while highlighting the value of collective action toward change. Steven Patrick Fernandez’s Ranaw: Isang Alamat (Ranaw: A Legend), 1986, is about the hero Bato Lakungan who was said to be the ancestor of Iliganons, Maranaos, Maguindanons, and Higaonons. Edward Perez’ Baloy !, 1988, and Ang Babaylan (The Shaman), 1989, are based on Panay legends and folklore. Nicolas Pichay’s Hudhud: An Ifugao Romance, 2004, is a contemporary adaptation of the epic of the Ifugao—specifically, the first episode titled “The Filling of the Scabbard,” as told and chanted by Apu Baket, an 80-year-old Ifugao woman. Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Labaw Donggon, 2013, is a musical adaptation of the Panay epic that fuses the indigenous and the contemporary as seen in the costumes, music, and dance. Rody Vera adapted the Bikol epic in Ibalong, 2013, by creating a dance-musical using neoethnic rock to bring the material closer to the younger generation.

Folklore contributed more than just stories to the plays of Sining Kambayoka of Marawi City. Mga Kuwentong Maranao (Maranao Tales), 1974, integrates 13 folktales about the trickster Pilandok. The literary material was merged by author-director Frank Rivera with other folk elements—the bayok or verse debate, dances, and songs—to produce a unique theater distilled from Maranao folk culture. He included the malong (a piece of clothing that is a “wall” creating privacy) as costume/scenery/prop color statement; motifs and visuals from folk art; movements from folk dance and martial arts; and the bayok as chorus and dialogue. The success of the play—370 performances in the first eight years—shows how rich a mine and how effective a theater vehicle folklore can be. Sining Kambayoka produced more plays based on folklore such as Isang Alamat ng Sarimanok (A Legend of Sarimanok), 1974; Maharadia Lawana, 1977, a dramatization of the epic; and Ang Paglalakbay ni Radiya Mangandiri (Rajah Mangandiri’s Journey), 1993, PETA’s adaptation of the same epic.

A number of plays for children are based on folk material. These include Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Manok at ang Lawin (The Chicken and the Hawk), Ang Magkakapatid at ang Tsonggo (The Siblings and the Monkey), and Kung Paano Pinatay ng mga Ibaloi ang Higante (How the Ibaloi Killed the Giant), all staged in 1974, as well as her puppet play Abadeja: Ang Ating Sinderela (Abadeja: Our Own Cinderella), 1977; and plays written by Bienvenido Portugal like Korido, 1987, which features characters like Don Juan Teñoso, Bernardo Carpio, Mariang Kalabasa, and Bidasari, 1988, which is based on the epics Indarapatra at Sulayman (Indarapatra and Sulayman) and Darangen. Folk literature is also the source of Christine Bellen’s Si Pilandok at ang Bayan ng Bulawan (Pilandok and the Town of Gold), 2010; Liza Magtoto’s Dugtong-Dugtong na Sumbong (Series of Complaints), 2010; and Arthur Cassanova’s Si Kusog at ang Mahiwagang Bakawan (Kusog and the Magic Mangrove), Ang Paglilitis sa Hukuman ni Sinukuan (The Trial in the Court of Sinukuan), Ang Mahiwagang Tandang (The Magic Rooster), Si Diwatakasalipan at si Tarabuasao (Diwatakasalipan and Tarabuasao), and Si Juan Bahag (Loincloth Juan), all presented in 2015.

From folklore too have come motifs in such diverse plays as Jose Rizal’s Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig), 1880, which features the precolonial Diwata, and Domingo Landicho’s Dupluhang Bayan (People’s Poetic Joust), 1975, which uses folk legends, like the creation of the brown man and of the first man and woman, and the fable of the monkey and the turtle, as breaks and illustrations between the manggagawa-magsasaka (laborer-farmer) verse debates in the manner of theduplo. The libretto of Bienvenido Lumbera’s Tales of the Manuvu, 1977, draws from Manuvu creation and other myths collected by anthropologist E. Arsenio Manuel.

Folk life and customs have been sources for such plays as Al Santos and Nic Cleto’s Bodong, 1976, which is about the peace pact of the Cordilleras; Al Santos, Rody Vera, and Denisa Reyes’s Diablos (Demons), 1989, which creates dance drama from ritual; Reynaldo “Tootsie” Jamoralin’s Si Bulusan nan si Agingay (Bulusan and Agingay), 1990, which draws from Bikol folklore and utilizes the pantomina, a local courtship dance to highlight the celebration of love between the two characters; and Al Santos, Joey Ayala, and Agnes Locsin’s Encantada (Enchantress), 1992, which blends folk belief, ritual, faith, music, and lifeways into dance and drama.

Plays based on folklore have used single characters, single stories, story cycles, scenes, values—retold, embellished, reinvented. They appeal because they draw from the wells of community memory, tradition, and consciousness—they are not just characters and situations but ways of being, seeing, and doing as well. Folklore is, after all, the first chapter of a people’s history and of a nation’s communal story.

The pasyon, although strictly speaking not borne out of our folk tradition, being of Biblical origin, has functioned as folk material and is an important source for Philippine drama. From it came not only the sinakulo as written by the folk writers in the different regions but also the Mary (i.e., the compleat, the suffering mother), Magdalene (i.e, the reformed woman and the “prostitute with the golden heart” archetype), and Christ (i.e., the suffering savior) figures of fiction and drama, which are all found in the sarsuwela and the drama, as well as in modern plays and films. The Christ story has also been the source of such plays as Aurelio V. Tolentino’s Bagong Cristo (New Christ), 1907, and the contemporary sinakulo with Christ as farmer, fisher, or one of the urban poor. Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Papet Pasyon (The Passion of Christ in Puppetry) adapted and Filipinized the story of Jesus for the young Filipino audiences. It has been staged every Palm Sunday since 1985 by Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, not only to make the young audiences grasp the meaning of the life and sufferings of Jesus but also to depict Filipino culture and traditions.

The awit and korido, which bred the komedya, also resulted in Rio Alma and Tito Climaco’s rock musical Bernardo Carpio, 1976; Rene O. Villanueva’s contemporary komedya Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1987; and Tony Perez’s 1988 pop musical version of Florante at Laura, with music by Nonong Buencamino. The korido Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird) is the progenitor of Paul Dumol’s existentialist Pag-awit ng Adarna (When the Adarna Bird Has Sung), 1970; Elmer Gatchalian’s Ang Tiririt ng Ibong Adarna (The Song of the Adarna Bird), 1994; Tony Perez’s Sa Pugad ng Adarna (In the Adarna Bird’s Nest), 1997; and Vladimeir Gonzales’s adaptation of Adarna, 2013.

The novels of Rizal, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), have seemed to be, to many Filipinos, both fiction and history, and have grown a family tree of plays and performances. Both have been made into operas and films. Felipe Padilla de Leon composed the opera Noli Me Tangere, with lyrics by Guillermo Tolentino in 1953, and El Filibusterismo in 1970. Noli has been adapted by Jomar Fleras into Kanser (Cancer), 1980, one of the most often performed numbers in the repertory of Bulwagang Gantimpala. Bienvenido Lumbera created the libretto of Noli Me Tangere: The Musical, 2011, with music by Ryan Cayabyab. In the year of the Fili centenary in 1991, Floy Quintos’s Fili, Jose Bernard Capino’s Filibustero (Filibuster), and El Filibusterismo: The Musical by Paul Dumol and Jovy Miroy, with music by Ryan Cayabyab, were staged. In 1995, Quintos adapted the Fili again in Isang Panaginip na Fili (A Dreamed Fili), 2008. Nicanor G. Tiongson created Noli at Fili Dekada 2000 (Noli and Fili in the Decade of the 2000s), 2008, which, while adhering to the structure of Rizal’s novels, highlights pressing sociopolitical issues in the early 2000s.

Stories from Fili had earlier been retold in Paul Dumol’s powerful three-act play Kabesang Tales (Cabeza Tales), 1975, in which 27 scenes in Brechtian style present the conflict between the peasant Tales and the friar, and the situation that made him turn to violence. Sisa from Noli has been the subject of Rosauro dela Cruz’s Ang Misteryo ng Hapis ni Sisa (The Mystery of Sisa’s Suffering), 1975, and a noh play by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa: Isang Noh sa Laguna (Sisa’s Quest: A Noh in Laguna), 1976. Sisa joins Maria Clara and Salome, two other women from the novels, in Chris Millado and Nick Pichay’s three one-act plays, Kutsilyo, Pamaypay, at Yantok (Knife, Fan, and Cane), 1984, which all take the woman’s perspective—a viewpoint from which few plays in the Philippine repertoire have been written. Floy Quintos reinterprets the character of Maria Clara in Suor Clara, 2010, by transforming her from the novel’s submissive individual into an empowered woman. Many readers take the Rizal novels as history; so perhaps do the writers of plays. Playwrights do find some of their work already done for them, since Rizal had already vividly described and fleshed out the people and the places of his historical milieu.

Other examples of the use of literary sources by Philippine playwrights include Wilfredo Virtusio’s Vida, 1969, which has, as one of the principal characters, an old man named Selo, who obviously refers to the Tata Selo in Rogelio Sicat’s famous short story who in turn seems to draw his name and much of his anger from Selo, the father of Tales in Fili. Nick Joaquin himself turned his story “Three Generations” into Fathers and Sons, performed in translation as Mga Ama, Mga Anak, 1977, and his Summer Solstice into the play Tatarin, 1978. Stevan Javellana’s Without Seeing the Dawn became the play Silang Nalugmok sa Dilim (Those Who Fell in the Dark), 1984, by Dennis Marasigan. Bienvenido Lumbera’s Nasa Puso ang Amerika, 1984, reveals its source in its title—Carlos Bulosan’s autobiographical America Is in the Heart. Rene O. Villanueva adapted Edgardo Reyes’s novel in his play Sa Kuko ng Liwanag (In the Claws of Light), 1993. Ariel Valerio created a stage version of Ceres S.C. Alabado’s novel Kangkong 1896, 1996, which is about the Katipunan and the Philippine Revolution, told from the point of view of a teenager. H. Francisco Peñones Jr’s Kantada ni Daragang Magayon, Mandirigma (Cantata of Daragang Magayon, Warrior Woman), 2000, is a musical-dance drama based on Reynaldo Jamoralin’s adaptation of Merlinda Bobis’s Cantata of Daragang Magayon, Warrior Woman, 1993. Bienvenido Lumbera’s Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), 2002, is a sarsuwela inspired by “Hibik Namin” (Our Plea), a poem published in Heraldo Filipino on 17 Feb 1899, which calls attention to the Filipino women who were raped by the American soldiers. Liza Magtoto’s Agnoia, 2002, is based on Horoscope, a short story by Eli Guieb III. Christine Bellen’s Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 2005, is based on the collection of children’s stories by Severino Reyes. Rody Vera adapted F. Sionil Jose’s novels in plays such as Mass, 2005, and Ang Mga Huwad (The Pretenders), 2007. Anton Juan Jr’s Hinabing Pakpak ng Ating Mga Anak (The Woven Wings of Our Children), 2008, pays tribute to fellow playwright Rene O. Villanueva by creating a play that weaves his poetry, children’s stories, and plays to depict the plight of Filipino children in society. Bellen also adapted Villanueva’s Unang Baboy sa Langit (First Pig in Heaven), 2009. Bienvenido Lumbera adapted Lope K. Santos’s classic novel on socialism in Banaag at Sikat: Isang Rock Musical (Glimmer and Light: A Rock Musical), 2010. Rodolfo Vera’s Umaaraw, Umuulan, Kinakasal ang Tikbalang (Sun Shining, Rain Pouring, Horse Demons Wed) , 2011, is a children’s play adapted from Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s short story titled “The Magic Circle.”

To these sources for theater can be added the other arts. The art of Juan Luna, for example, is a central motif in Bienvenido Noriega Jr’s Juan Luna, 1982, while that of Carlos “Botong” Francisco is evident in Rene O. Villanueva’s play Botong, 1988. Noriega’s Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1987, is based on the life and music of composer Nicanor S. Abelardo. Jose Javier Reyes created the libretto for Katy!, 1988, on the life and times of Katy de la Cruz, the “Queen of Philippine Vaudeville and Jazz.” Noriega wrote the libretto of Kenkoy Loves Rosing, 1992, based on the komiks story, as told by Romualdo Ramos and as illustrated by Tony Velasquez. Floy Quintos’s Atang, 2008, pays homage to the National Artist for music and theater Honorata “Atang” de la Rama and introduces kundiman (love songs) she popularized, a bodabil song by Katy de la Cruz, and a poem by Amado V. Hernandez.

Popular culture—such as films, music, comic books, and graphic novels—is one of the most prevalent sources of plays, as theater artists make the most of the audiences’ familiarity with the source material. Manny Pambid wrote Canuplin: Isang Improbisasyon sa Buhay at Mga Palabas ng Isang Komedyanteng Pilipino (Canuplin: An Improvisation on the Life and Shows of a Filipino Comedian), 1980, about the life of Canuto Francia, Filipino stage performer and magician who became famous for his impersonation of Charlie Chaplin in Filipino movies and the local bodabil stage. Mario O’Hara wrote Insiang, 2002, based on the classic film, which was originally a teleplay he wrote in 1973 for the television series Hilda. Ricky Lee wrote the script and Vince de Jesus created the musical compositions of Himala: The Musical, 2003, based on the film Himala (Miracle). Chris Martinez wrote Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal, 2004, based on Carlo Vergara’s graphic novel Ang Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Zsazsa Zaturnnah (The Amazing Adventures of Zsazsa Zaturnnah). Nicolas Pichay made the book and lyrics of Maxie: The Musical , 2005, based on the film Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros). Freddie Santos’s Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2015, was adapted from the film and komiks of the same title.

Playwrights have also developed musicals using popular songs of musical bands or composers. Ed Maranan’s EJ: Ang Pinagdaanang Buhay nina Evelio Javier at Edgar Jopson (EJ: The Lives of Evelio Javier and Edgar Jopson), 2008, used songs by the rock band The Dawn. Sa Wakas (At Last), 2013, was created by Andre Nicolai Pamintuan and Marianne Abuan using songs by rock band Sugarfree. Rak of Aegis, 2014, by Liza Magtoto featured the songs by rock band Aegis. Chuva Choo Choo: The Mr. Kupido Musicale, 2015, by George de Jesus III, used songs by Vehnee Saturno.

Theater styles and trends from East and West have also been sources for theater. Brechtian theater, for example, resulted not only in successful and effective translations and adaptations, such as Ang Pabilog na Guhit na Tisa, 1977, from The Caucasian Chalk Circle, and Ang Buhay ni Galileo, 1981, from Galileo Galilei, but also in plays using the approach and/or the techniques of epic theater. Rolando S.Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason), 1972, has been eminently successful in teaching Brechtian theater. Paul Dumol’s Brechtian approach in Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), 1968, and Kabesang Tales, 1975, have proven its effectivity in the Philippine situation. Other plays that were influenced by the theater philosophy and works of Brecht are Al Santos’s Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata (May 21 and Other Chapters), 1977; Bonifacio Ilagan’s Estados Unidos bersus Cruz, Abad at Tolentino (United States versus Cruz, Abad and Tolentino), 1981; Dong del os Reyes’s Bien Aligtad, 1985; and Jose Y. Dalisay Jr’s Ang Butihing Babae ng Timog (The Good Woman of the South), 1992. Brechtian elements also characterize Ateneo’s ENTABLADO productions such as Sampung Mga Daliri (Ten Fingers), 2010; Juan Tamban, 2013; Isang Gabi, FB na Mapanglaw (One Night, A Solitary FB), 2014; and Gulo ng Gugulong na Ulo (Trouble from a Head Roll), 2015. Augusto Boal’s Theater of the Oppressed has also been used in the short image and forum theater pieces by groups such as the Philippine Educational Theater Association and Peryante.

The realism developed in Western literature is seen early in the sarsuwela and drama of the first decades of Philippine theater, and has grown strong in contemporary theater. The social realism of many plays during the martial law era, like Juan Tamban and Buhay Batilyo , draws the individual in the context of society, and thus renders his reality. Rene O. Villanueva’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), 1980, which focuses on the lives of four male residents of a home for the aged, used modern realism to reflect on the theme of conflict and death. The psychological realism of plays like Tony Perez’s Biyaheng Timog (Trip to the South), 1984; Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), 1988; Oktubre, Noong Tayo’y Nagmamahalan Pa (October, When We Were Still in Love), 1993; and Nobyembre, Noong Akala Ko’y Mahal Kita (November, When I Thought I Love You), 1994, portray the individual as a product of his inner landscape, which thus renders his humanity. Floy Quintos’s Fake, 2011, examines the last days of Jose Marco, who successfully foisted his forgeries of the Code of Kalantiao and La Loba Negra (The Black She-Wolf) on the public until his fraud was exposed by historian Henry Scott.

Because the sources are varied and numerous, influences on Philippine theater are many and deep. The influence of Spanish literature, both religious and secular, and theater produced the content and style of all the religious dramas and dramatizations, the komedya, and later the sarsuwela and the drama. Although these forms have already been studied in theses, articles, and books, further explorations into them and into Spanish theater keep turning up more echoes and transmutations (e.g., the idea of the comic, the concept of villainy, the philosophy of staging, the romance mode, the honor principle, etc.) that suggest further study.

Anglo-American influences, which entered through the educational system, the English language, and popular culture, are seen in the idea of the legitimate theater, the content and style of modern and contemporary plays, stagecraft and acting and directorial techniques, stage technology, and the theatrical trends or movements tried, adapted, combined, and transmuted such as realism, expressionism, and the theater of the absurd. Although these influences definitely dominate in Philippine theater, there have been inputs from other theaters as well, notably Japanese (kabuki, Noh, kyogen, Black Tent modern theater), Indonesian, Chinese (the Chinese opera performed in the provinces and sometimes referred to as “Chinese moro-moro,” the political plays of the Cultural Revolution), and European (mime, Brechtian theater).

All these sources and influences have resulted in a philosophy of theater that is culture- and community-based, as was indigenous theater, but has been enriched through history by strands and branches that developed, by other concepts such as idea theater, teaching theater, social and politicaltheater, theater of awareness and conscientization, as well as by the need and purpose of the playwright and/or theater group.

Many other influences enter in different proportions and manners, what with the contemporary artist now on the global stage because of greater opportunities such as troupe tours, artist collaborations, attendance in international conferences, and workshops in other countries; and greater visibility as his or her accomplishments are easily disseminated nowadays. At the artist’s core, however, are strong Malay (the native strain), Hispanic, and Anglo-American influences that are most visible especially when seen in contrast with the theater of Southeast Asian countries.

The sources from which Philippine theater draws its substance remain predominantly local, as they should, since Philippine drama is Philippine life. Contemporary and historical events, current issues, folklore, literature, and the other arts have provided themes, motifs, characters, situations, values, even whole dramas. The particular combination of Philippine life and Hispanic and Anglo-American theater, forged by history and circumstance, is what makes Philippine theater uniquely Filipino. Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Galileo S. Zafra

article.value: The rituals and dances of indigenous theater evolved from day-to-day needs: rice planting and harvest, birth and death, courtship and marriage, illness, and rites of passage. They therefore drew from events and belief in the symbolic and actual characters and actions that made the ritual. The Maranao rice-planting ritual called kashawing, for example, uses food and water, farmers and intercessors, along with invocations and offerings to the spirits. Dances mime occupations like fishing, hunting, and fruit gathering, as well as rites of survival like battle and courtship.

The komedya has plots and characters from medieval European romances—from Britain and France, from Spanish and Portuguese history and lore, from the lives of saints, and from combinations of these. From these materials come the buhay na pinagdaanan (the life history) of characters such as Principe Baldovino, Doce Pares de Francia, Prinsipe Atamante, Rodrigo de Villa, Haring Villarba, and Don Juan Tiñoso. These stories were taken directly from the metrical romances probably brought in by Spanish soldiers, written in the native languages in the awit and korido, read and chanted in the different regions and languages, and then transformed into drama by enactment on stage.

The sinakulo and other religious dramas and dramatizations of the Spanish colonial period draw mainly from the pasyon and the Bible, but also from related and apocryphal writings. The elaborate salubong, for example, is built on the supposed meeting of Jesus and Mary after the Resurrection, which is not recorded in the gospels. The sinakulo fleshes out eight days of performances with Biblical narratives from the Creation to the Assumption of Mary into Heaven, as well as vignettes from the awit and korido, magazine stories, and folk belief about such characters as Dimas and Gestas, Boanerhes and Samuel Belibet, Veronica and Simon Cirineo, Virgen Maria and Pedro and Judas. From the search for the Holy Cross have been spun plays and romances involving the empress Elena and the emperor Constantino and characters from the Old and New Testaments.

Real life strides onstage in the drama and the sarsuwela, which depart from the Spanish models by building theater around the Filipino family: parents and children obedient or otherwise; husbands and wives in conflict or cooperation; their vices like cockfighting and panggingge (card game); concerns like politics, courtship, marriage, and making a living; and tensions between lover and beloved, landlord and tenant, master and servant, employer and employee. Although these situations were often modulated into the happy endings devoutly wished by both writers and viewers, they were based on daily life and in sum are often social comedies and commentaries.

The sources for modern drama start with real life—day-to-day happenings witnessed or heard about, accounts in newspapers and magazines, news heard over the radio or on television, political and social experience. Manny D. Pambid’s Buhay Batilyo, Hindi Kami Susuko (Batilyo Life, We Will Not Surrender), 1975, was based on a Fanny A. Garcia feature article about the life of a batilyo (fish stevedore) in the Navotas fish port. Al Santos’s Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata (May 21 and Other Chapters), 1977, came from the real-life experiences of Valentin de los Santos and the massacre of the Lapiang Malaya. Malou Jacob’s Juan Tamban, 1978, started with a news item in the papers about a boy who fell ill from eating insects that triggered curiosity and research and resulted in a full-length play. Jacob’s Macliing Dulag, 1988, dramatizes the life of the Kalinga leader who was assassinated for his opposition to the Chico River Dam Project. Reuel Molina Aguila’s Walang Maliw (Unfading), 2009, draws parallelisms from Jonas Burgos’s abduction in 2007 and proves that political disappearances happened not only during martial law but continues to the present.

History, being the “real life” of the past, has been a rich lode that contemporary Philippine theater has mined well, especially during the martial law era, when the only safe way to speak of the present was to present the past as seen in plays on the Philippine Revolution against Spain, like Bonifacio Ilagan’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), 1978, and Langit Ma’y Magdilim (Though the Sky Darkens), 1979. Connections between past and present may also be inferred from the choice of characters and events of different eras like in Adrian Cristobal’s The Trial/Ang Paglilitis, 1961, which depicts the trial of Andres Bonifacio, the supremo of the Katipunan; Domingo Landicho’s Unang Alay (First Offering), 1975; Charley de la Paz’s musical 1896, 1996; Lito Tiongson’s Ang Walang Kamatayang Buhay ni Juan de la Cruz Alyas … (Isang Kronika ng Digmaang Pilipino-Amerikano 1900-1902) (The Deathless Life of Juan de la Cruz Alias … A Chronicle of the Filipino-American War 1900-1902), 1976; Jose Y. Dalisay Jr’s Sugatang Lawin (Wounded Hawk); Isagani R. Cruz’s Josephine, 1978; and Elsa Martinez-Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House, 1987. Other historical plays are Bienvenido Lumbera’s Bayani (Hero), 1984, a musical about Jose Rizal; Paul Dumol’s Francisco Maniago, 1988, on the leader of a village in Mexico, Pampanga, who led a revolt against polo y servicios (forced labor) and bandala (forced sale of goods to government) enforced by the Spaniards; Malou Jacob, Rene Villanueva, and Honorio Magbalic’s Teresa, Gregoria, Teodora, 1993, on women’s role in the revolution; Bernardo Aguay and Jazmin B. Llana’s Simeon A. Ola, 1995, which depicted the life of the hero from Guinobatan, Albay; Paul Dumol’s Ang Paglilitis at Pagkamatay ni Jose Rizal: Mga Teksto at Konteksto (The Trial and Death of Jose Rizal: Texts and Contexts), 1996, on the life and works of the National Hero; Jovy Miroy’s Anak ng Bayan (Son of the People), 1996, on Andres Bonifacio; Jacob, Magbalic, and Rene O. Villanueva’s Ang Anak at ang Kanyang Ina (The Child and His Mother), 1996, monologues on Jose Rizal and Teodora Alonso; Dumol’s Ilustrado: Ang Buhay ni Rizal, The Musical (Educated Native: The Life of Rizal, The Musical), 1996; Sonny Cristobal’s M. H. del Pilar: Pasyong Dapat Ipag-alab (M. H. del Pilar: Passion That Should Inflame), 1996, which highlighted del Pilar as a writer; Dumol’s Aguinaldo 1899, 1998, which depicted the life of the general of the Philippine Revolution while examining political issues during the period; Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), 2007, a sarsuwela on the women of Malolos; Christine Bellen’s Batang Rizal (The Young Rizal), 2007, a children’s play; Ed Maranan’s EJ: A Rock Musical, 2008, on the lives of Evelio Javier and Edgar Jopson; Rody Vera’s Tandang Sora: Ang Lola Nating Bayani (Tandang Sora: Our Hero Grandmother), 2012, on the mother of the revolution; Floy Quintos’s Ang Huling Lagda ni Apolinario Mabini (The Last Signature of Apolinario Mabini), 2014, and Tiongson’s Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior), 2015, which focused on the brains and conscience of the revolution. Most of these plays suggest parallelisms with the present and invite questions and solutions.
